Subject: [PLUG] Colors in the 'ls' output
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403010107130.6865@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 1 Mar 2004, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> WTF is /etc/DIR_COLORS?


# Configuration file for the color ls utility
# This file goes in the /etc directory, and must be world readable.
# You can copy this file to .dir_colors in your $HOME directory to
# override the system defaults.

# COLOR needs one of these arguments: 'tty' colorizes output to ttys, but
# not pipes. 'all' adds color characters to all output. 'none' shuts
# colorization off.
COLOR tty

# Extra command line options for ls go here.
# Basically these ones are:
#  -F = show '/' for dirs, '*' for executables, etc.
#  -T 0 = don't trust tab spacing when formatting ls output.
OPTIONS -F -T 0

# Below, there should be one TERM entry for each termtype that is
colorizable
TERM linux
TERM console
TERM con132x25
TERM con132x30
TERM con132x43
TERM con132x60
TERM con80x25
TERM con80x28
TERM con80x30
TERM con80x43
TERM con80x50
TERM con80x60
TERM cons25
TERM xterm
TERM rxvt
TERM xterm-color
TERM color-xterm
TERM vt100
TERM dtterm
TERM color_xterm
TERM ansi
TERM screen
TERM kon
TERM kterm

# EIGHTBIT, followed by '1' for on, '0' for off. (8-bit output)
EIGHTBIT 1

# Below are the color init strings for the basic file types. A color init
# string consists of one or more of the following numeric codes:
# Attribute codes:
# 00=none 01=bold 04=underscore 05=blink 07=reverse 08=concealed
# Text color codes:
# 30=black 31=red 32=green 33=yellow 34=blue 35=magenta 36=cyan 37=white
# Background color codes:
# 40=black 41=red 42=green 43=yellow 44=blue 45=magenta 46=cyan 47=white
NORMAL 00       # global default, although everything should be something.
FILE 00         # normal file
DIR 01;34       # directory
LINK 01;36      # symbolic link
FIFO 40;33      # pipe
SOCK 01;35      # socket
BLK 40;33;01    # block device driver
CHR 40;33;01    # character device driver
ORPHAN 01;05;37;41  # orphaned syminks
MISSING 01;05;37;41 # ... and the files they point to

# This is for files with execute permission:
EXEC 01;32

# List any file extensions like '.gz' or '.tar' that you would like ls
# to colorize below. Put the extension, a space, and the color init
# string.  (and any comments you want to add after a '#')
.cmd 01;32 # executables (bright green)
.exe 01;32
.com 01;32
.btm 01;32
.bat 01;32
.sh  01;32
.csh 01;32
.tar 01;31 # archives or compressed (bright red)
.tgz 01;31
.arj 01;31
.taz 01;31
.lzh 01;31
.zip 01;31
.z   01;31
.Z   01;31
.gz  01;31
.bz2 01;31
.bz  01;31
.tz  01;31
.rpm 01;31
.cpio 01;31
.jpg 01;35 # image formats
.gif 01;35
.bmp 01;35
.xbm 01;35
.xpm 01;35
.png 01;35
.tif 01;35




From Rob.Anderson at nike.com  Mon Mar  1 08:39:02 2004
From: Rob.Anderson at nike.com (Anderson, Rob (Global Trade))
Date: Mon Mar  1 08:39:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] scp problem
Message-ID: <200403011637.i21GbqQl024369@barrierb241.nike.com>

I get this same error when trying to scp files using OpenSSH to a remote system running F-Secure's sshd. I'm not sure that you are having the exact same issue, but the problem in my case is that the OpenSSH scp passes a "-t" option to the remote side to specify the target directory for the files being copied, and F-Secure interprets this "-t" to mean "compatibility mode". There is a clear incompatibility between F-Secure's scp and OpenSSH. I have a case open with F-Secure and they are being very stubborn about even acknowledging that this is an issue. If at all possible, I would recommend to anyone considering anything but OpenSSH to reconsider. Often times companies want to have a vendor responsible for their software and therefore refuse to implement open source solutions. In this case, F-Secure is not taking responsibility and therefore there is no value added by choosing a proprietary solution.

-Rob Anderson

From keith at ahapala.net  Mon Mar  1 09:04:02 2004
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Mon Mar  1 09:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Samba troubles
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0402292039170.13576-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0402292039170.13576-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <20040301171130.GA15418@ahapala.net>

On Sun, Feb 29, 2004 at 08:49:41PM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
> I'm trying to setup would should be a fairly simple Samba configuration
> for someone.
> They have a dual-boot server with Windows Server 2003 and RH 9.  There's a
> FAT32 partition that is mounted read/write for the world on the Linux
> side.  I then want to share this out on the network.  Here's my smb.conf:
> 
> [global]
> workgroup = somecompanyworkgroup
> security = share
> 
> [Public]
> path = /mnt/e/Public
> read only = no
> guest only = yes
> 
> 
> Pretty simple...  and it works great when I test it on my home network.
> But when a Win2K client on their network tries to access the Samba server,
> this message is given:
> 
> "There are currently no logon servers available to service the logon
> request."
> 

Matt,

It looks like your Win2003 server is the PDC and when you boot the RH9
side there is no PDC to authenticate to (unless the RH9 is set to be a
PDC in other smb.conf parameters).

The section of the smb.conf manpage entitled "NOTE ABOUT
USERNAME/PASSWORD VALIDATION" might help.

HTH,
Keith

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Mon Mar  1 14:12:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)
Date: Mon Mar  1 14:12:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Mail to two IMAP servers
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0402271110340.31858@pecos.madboa.com>
References: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0402271157000.3131-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org> 
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0402271110340.31858@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <1078093500.2874.7.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Fri, 2004-02-27 at 11:13, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Fri, 27 Feb 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:
> 
> > Hmmm...  OK, let's start over.  Ignore the Linux box at the moment.
> > Mail comes into the NT box.
> 
> Arrrgh! You said that mail was being received by Postfix! Now you're
> saying that mail is really being received by some (unknown) software
> on the NT box?
> 
> I want to help, but the information you're giving is maddeningly
> incomplete.
> 
> So, I want to know ... If I send a message to someone at yourclient.com,
> what is the *exact* path it takes to get to someone's inbox? I want to
> know every machine and every piece of software in the mix.
> 
> -- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

Maybe your company should buy another domain name for a year and set up
a Linux mail server the way you want it to replace the existing one. 
With virtual domains, it seems like it would be fairly easy to make your
new site replace the existing one later but I don't even think you need
to go there.  At $35 a year from register.com, you're not entangling
your old system with a new one you want to demonstrate to your employer.
For that matter, why test this on the Internet at all?  Depending on
your company resources, it should be fairly easily to build a simulated
Internet to demonstrate what needs to be demonstrated.  Figure out how
to kick start install the configuration you need for the company and
your good to go as long as you have a window to be down in.  I suppose
the existing server could be put in backup mode and imap taken off it
or the imap ports closed during your upgrade.  As long as there is
enough space on the NT box, you shouldn't lose any email during the
upgrade.

M

On Sun, 29 Feb 2004, cabbey wrote:
> I've not had this particular problem, but you may want to see what bios
> version the 2940u2w card is flashed to.  If you have a different system
> you can get it to run in and boot to floppy, then you could flash it to
> latest version (if not already).

The flash update worked!  I had to put the card in a different machine, of
course, in order to boot form a dos floppy (which was incredibly hard to
make, given that I don't really have any proprietary software in the
house).

I was VERY worried about the BIOS update because the card is marked with a
Dell part number and so very well could be an OEM card and the Adaptec
site is plastered with notices about flashing OEM or imbedded products and
the world-ending consequences of doing same.

I also had the manual that came with the card and the manual says nothing
about Dell and the Dell support site has no bios updates for the card...
so I took a chance.

Phew.

From jack at bonyari.com  Mon Mar  1 19:50:02 2004
From: jack at bonyari.com (Jack Morgan)
Date: Mon Mar  1 19:50:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] E-mail attachments not seen by recipient
In-Reply-To: <4043F867.8090FB75@gencom.us>

On Mon, Mar 01, 2004 at 06:58:48PM -0800, D. Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> Rich,
> 
> Newer versions of Outlook absoulutly restrict attachments.  See the following
> links:
> 
>   http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;318515
> 
>   http://support.microsoft.com/default.aspx?scid=kb;en-us;829982
 
This is not completely true. Outlook only restricts "dangerous"
attachments such as .exe, .vbs, etc. This is Microsoft's effort to prevent
users from shooting themselves in the foot by launching viruses or other
malicious programs.

All Microsoft based file types and any "normal" business application file
type works fine in Outlook.

As to your problem, I'd try sending that pdf file to yourself, or to
another email account you have that is outside your network (I assume
your sending from work) If you can receive it fine, you can assume its
something on her end. You might even have her try Outlook Express or some
other email client besides Outlook. I use Outlook at work and have never
had a problem with pdf files.

On Mon, 1 Mar 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

> To those of you who work in a mixed-OS environment:
> 
>   Is there something a user must do to her installation of Outrage that
> would make attachments I send visible? Over the past couple of days I've
> sent three pdf attachments to a colleague and she tells me that nothing was
> there. I strongly suspect a configuration problem, but I have no idea what
> it might be or how to guide her to a solution.

Recent MS updates have been making changes to a working installation of
Outlook.  The two worst are changing the SMTP authorization settings (turn 
them off) and cranking up the security (or what passes as security) 
settings.

Have her start Outlook, Select Tools, Select the Security TAB and then
look for something about attachments.  I get to deal with this almost
daily but since I don't have Outlook on any systems at home I can't
remember the exacting item in the Security Settings TAB.  (Only because
I've taken users through this so much -- and it ain't my job even -- can I
remember how to get this far.)


I used to be VERY anti-MS product.  But then I realized it's an excellant 
revenue stream.  I have to make up excuses to visit businesses that have 
Linux based servers (several of them became good friends) but I'm always 
visting the MS based sites 'cause that c**p is always breaking.

find . -type d -print

> find . -type d -print

Assuming you don't want anything but the subdirectories in the current
directory, you'll want the maxdepth and mindepth options too:

  find . -type d -maxdepth 1 -mindepth 1

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From cabbey at attbi.com  Tue Mar  2 10:24:01 2004
From: cabbey at attbi.com (cabbey)

Subject: [PLUG] More SCSI woes. -- RESOLVED
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0402291339160.6865@shaft.bitmine.net> <40427805.1010400@attbi.com> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403011814550.6865@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <4044083F.8050800@attbi.com>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:

>On Sun, 29 Feb 2004, cabbey wrote:
>  
>
>>I've not had this particular problem, but you may want to see what bios
>>version the 2940u2w card is flashed to.  If you have a different system
>>you can get it to run in and boot to floppy, then you could flash it to
>>latest version (if not already).
>>    
>>
>
>The flash update worked!  I had to put the card in a different machine, of
>course, in order to boot form a dos floppy (which was incredibly hard to
>make, given that I don't really have any proprietary software in the
>house).
>  
>
That other guy who mentioned the bios settings may have been onto 
something - that the settings were fubar'd and causing the mobo conflict 
issues (hit "alt-a" to enter I believe).  I personally prefer to get all 
my BIOS up to date (particularly when they're over 4 versions old). 
 I've had problems with the 2940UW older BIOS not supporting w2k pro 
bootable CD (I believe bios version 1.32), but flashing to the latest 
2.20 bios resolved the boot problem.

>I was VERY worried about the BIOS update because the card is marked with a
>Dell part number and so very well could be an OEM card and the Adaptec
>site is plastered with notices about flashing OEM or imbedded products and
>the world-ending consequences of doing same.
>  
>
Ayup,I've had the very same worries myself with Dell and Gateway sticker 
labels on some of my AHA-2940UW cards.  The one thing that seems to be 
key here is to ensure that the on-screen BIOS message does not have an 
"S" in it (true indication of OEM card).  I've flashed about 10 of these 
cards so far, and haven't had a problem yet (none had the "S" in the 
on-screen BIOS message) - in fact, I made a slight edit to their batch 
file, in order to allow the same disk to be used over and over (no more 
saving old bios, no more checking if old bios already exists on floppy - 
something like that).

>I also had the manual that came with the card and the manual says nothing
>about Dell and the Dell support site has no bios updates for the card...
>so I took a chance.
>
>  
>
Just curious, why did you bother going from 2940UW to 2940U2W?  From 
what I have been able to gather, most U2W drives are limited by an 
~18-23MB/s transfer rate to/from media - sure there will be the rare 
occasional 40MB/s (or 80MB/s with the U2W) bursts to/from disk cache, 
but that should be essentially negligable.  Unless there are particular 
cases where this burst mode actually pays off?

The only time I could see U2W being beneficial, is if you get some of 
the newer SCSI U160/320 15K drives that support 50-65MB/s transfer rates 
to/from media - but then you're talking $4++ per gig (just the drive 
alone).  Of course there is also RAID, a separate beast that I can 
easily see needing U2W (I just picked up a nice AAA-131U2 and have 64MB 
ECC EDO DIMM on the way to replace that measily 2MB default cache)...

I love using old SCA 18GB drives (ST118202LC) with the 2940UW, nice and 
fast *enough* - and pretty economical on a $/gig scale.  I also picked 
up a nice old P2L97-S, which has an aic-7880 (essentially 2940UW) on it, 
which will soon be running a celeron 733.    :)  

Oh, and to keep it slightly on-topic, I use these things in many 
dual-boot w2k/redhat8 boxes (have used redhat 6.2, 7.3, 8.0 and 9 - but 
9 simply seemed to miss the mark in terms of 
performance/stability/flexibility), and need to mess with mandrake next 
me thinkz...

From mikeraz at patch.com  Tue Mar  2 14:02:02 2004
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Tue Mar  2 14:02:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Listing only directories
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403021300460.29127@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403020843130.28360@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403021230530.6865@shaft.bitmine.net> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403021300460.29127@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040302220043.GA29391@patch.com>

the -d option tells ls to "list directory entries instead of contents"
not to be confused with "list entries that are directories rather than the contents of the argument"

default behavior for ls you provide a directory as an argument is to list the files contained in the directory.

so `ls -d .` would list the dot, as you pointed out earlier

if you have have a directory ./foo with contents of bar and baz

[patch at tire currdir]# ls foo
bar  baz
[patch at tire currdir]# ls -d foo
foo

Jeme could have simplified his example by suggesting `ls -d *` while assuming that you were referring to the current working directory.  for the current working directory `ls -d *` and `ls -d ./*` are synonymous.

On Tue, 2 Mar 2004 08:35:22, Paul Johnson <baloo at ursine.ca> wrote:
> Does having to hit Ctrl-C to copy, and and Ctrl-V
> to paste really have to be mandatory?  Why not just do it the right
> way, select copies, middle-click pastes?  

Because when Apple pioneered the use of cut/copy & paste (ca. 1981),
they used ^X, ^C, and ^V.  When MS stole their look & feel, it only made
sense to take their well-known keyboard shortcuts too.  :-)

I agree that highlight & center-click is often more convenient, but the
well-known shortcuts that have been around since the first real
application of this idea are every bit as much the "right" way.

$.02,

Dylan

without hand entering all the data. If I'm wrong about this,

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Mar  2 21:45:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue Mar  2 21:45:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Quickbook to GNUcash
Message-ID: <20040303054305.GA4588@gate.kl-ic.com>

Quickbooks to GNUcash?  Oh, how I wish!!!  That is one of two apps
that keeps me tied to Win4Lin (the other being a CAD app that I am
working right now to replace). 

Even if I got my files converted over, somehow, I need to convert
them back for my accountant.  However, my accountant is getting old
and it is about time to train a new, young, and hungry one.

For those of you that don't know what Ed and I are talking about, 
Quickbooks is the full business ledger big brother of Quicken.  It
has all the magic mojo for employees, structured debt and receivables,
all sorts of things a 5 to 50 employee business needs.  Unfortunately,
the fine folks at Intuit made Quickbooks write-only;  the .QBW format
appears to be encrypted.  Oh, and they give free samples to all the
accountants in the world, so guess what they suggest to their clients.

Those darl-for-brains! 

For a one way conversion, though, there may be an option.  The latest
versions of Quickbooks have an XML option, I am told.  The data can
be exported as XML, which should be relatively painless to convert 
to GNUcash format (for everything that fits, at least).  So, we write
a converter,  share the cost of one expensive Quickbooks upgrade,
then run all our sets of books through the two conversion processes.

Then we run an accountant through the conversion process.

I don't have time, and don't need another project.  However, perhaps
there is some out-of-work person that is looking for a project and a
small business.  I can loan that person manuals for Quickbooks 5 and
Quickbooks 2000 pro (the last version before XML, I believe).
Quickbooks is one of those "register over the phone" programs, so no
loaning copies, even if it wasn't wrong anyway.

Keith

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Wed Mar  3 06:40:04 2004
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Wed Mar  3 06:40:04 2004
Subject: [PLUG] 802.11b PCMCIA for a Redhat 6.2 laptop? 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Tue, 02 Mar 2004 16:15:07 PST."
             <1078272907.4226.110.camel@denk.nakedape.priv> 
Message-ID: <20040303143954.884FF8EE4@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Thanks to all for the responses.  I was able to get a used Belkin
F5D6020 with the Prism chipset at Belmont Computers.  In order to
get it working, here's what I did.

Upgraded kernel to last one released by redhat, 2.2.24

Built wireless-tools.  At this point, the card might have worked using
the wvlan_cs driver supplied by redhat, but my configuration was wrong,
though I didn't know it at the time.

Removed kernel-pcmcia-cs rpm.  Built latest pcmcia-cs, 3.2.7.  Got an
oops whenever cardmgr tried to load the orinoco modules.

Built pcmcia-cs-3.1.34.  No more oops, but problems with my config files.

Finally realized that I had lowercase characters for my MAC address in
the wireless.opts file.  When the configuration scripts run, they
expect the MAC address to be uppercase.  After correcting this, the
card started working.


BTW, the high output card (200 mW, http://www.netgate.com/EL2511.html)
that Russell mentioned is $65.  The company is in Spokane. They also
sell some interesting antennas.

galen

> > > Does having to hit Ctrl-C to copy, and and Ctrl-V
> > > to paste really have to be mandatory?  Why not just do it the right
> > > way, select copies, middle-click pastes?  
> > 
> > Because when Apple pioneered the use of cut/copy & paste (ca. 1981),

And we usually retire ideas after a few years, right?  That must be why
we're still using bash, BIND, vi[m], etc. etc.  SMTP has been
sub-optimal for years but we're still using *that*, aren't we?  

Standards have tremendous value, whether or not they are optimal
standards.  Fact is, most of what we do on a daily basis is because of
something that made sense in the 1960's or 1970's.  Whether or not it
makes sense now is frequently irrelevant.


> Everyone else has moved on.

Have they?  Many X11 apps support ^C and ^V, including Evo and Mozilla. 

Highlight-and-click is a great technique, but it makes pasting *over*
another selection more cumbersome.  And it's often harder on a laptop.

Choice is good.  There's no need to anoint one "right" way to do such a
common thing.

$.02 more,

Dylan

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Wed Mar  3 12:26:01 2004
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed Mar  3 12:26:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless cards for portables (continued)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403030905140.32399@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403030905140.32399@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1078345502.10147.26.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Wed, 2004-03-03 at 09:09, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   According to the folks at Emperor Linux, there are two cards that they
> know work with linux and my Sony Vaio 505: an 802.11b Orinoco Gold ($100) by
> Lucent and an 802.11b/g by 3Com (model not specified but they sell it for
> $150). I know their prices are high for I bought additional RAM locally for
> about 1/3rd of what they charge for it.
> 
>   I've looked on pricewatch and ENU but cannot find a 3Com b/g card. What
> local sources have folks here used (in addition to Belmont Computers), and
> what HOWTO do I read to get it working when I find a card?

Not an answer to what you're asking directly... but...

I'm using an Airlink Plus card.  $30 or so at Fry's.  It's a Prism2
chip.  Really pretty crappy, but it was really pretty cheap.  I've had
driver issues up the wazzoo in my 2.6 kernel, but under 2.4 I haven't
had any issues at all.  There are three sets of drivers that work with
Prism2 based cards; in-kernel Orinoco (might have misspelled that), the
linux-wlan-ng drivers (which I personally dislike), and the HostAP
drivers (which are the ones I am actually using now).

Before my Airlink Plus, I was using an Atmel based card.  It was a
Belkin, I spent about $60 on it at the BX.  It was a really good card. 
Recently, a guy rewrote the drivers for the 2.6 kernel and did a *very*
good job.  I've been very happy with his drivers.  I was pretty happy
with the SF drivers (originally closed-source drivers until Atmel
released the code, all GPL'd like) until I switched to 2.6... they had
some sort of leak somewhere that caused the drivers to go kaput after
about 250MB of data went over the card.

The Atmel had the cheap Prism2 beat out in terms of range and, IMHO,
quality of drivers.

Rob

From athlonrob at axpr.net  Wed Mar  3 13:46:02 2004
From: athlonrob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed Mar  3 13:46:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless cards for portables (continued)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403031242560.393@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403031242560.393@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1078350350.10147.33.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Wed, 2004-03-03 at 12:44, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Because I've not used any of these, does it make any practical difference
> between the slower, 'b', cards and the faster, 'g', capable cards?

Speed and range.  I understand the 802.11G frequency doesn't travel as
far as 802.11b's 2.1GHz.  I haven't actually read any tests to back that
up, mind you, it's just what I've heard in the rumor mill.  :-)

Speed; the 802.11b cards will give you 11Mbps.  If you're copying big
files around, you'll notice.  It takes a few minutes to move a 300MB
file over the link.  However, if you're not moving any big files over
the link, you'll never notice you aren't on a hard-wired connection. 
802.11G runs at 54Mbps, roughly half as fast as most wired connections. 
Oh, and cost... the 'g' stuff is still more expensive.

Rob

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Mar  3 17:30:02 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Mar  3 17:30:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Data recovery in Portland
In-Reply-To: <1078353593.15834.79.camel@jaguar.c-ware.com>
References: <1078353593.15834.79.camel@jaguar.c-ware.com>
Message-ID: <27642-89576@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 3 Mar 2004, Holger Stephan holger001-at-frogleg.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Question: Do you know of a data recovery service here in Portland? I
> have some pictures on CDs that seem to be corrupted and I'd like to
> recover.

To directly answer your question, I don't have any personal experience
with data recovery in Portland.  However, I've had excellent luck using
"readcd" which comes with "cdrecord" to recover damaged CD-ROMs.  Whatever
data is there, it will be able to pull off if coupled with a good CD-ROM
drive.  (I.e. Plextor)

Grab the latest cdrecord from:

http://www.fokus.gmd.de/research/cc/glone/employees/joerg.schilling/private/cdrecord.html

Build it, and run the command:

cdrecord -scanbus

That will give you the SCSI device list on your system.  Identify the one
for your CD-ROM drive and run:

readcd dev=0,0,0 f=/tmp/recovered-file.iso speed=1 retries=1024

(substitute 0,0,0 for your correct device)

This will read the disk as slowly and carefully as it can, retrying 1024
times on each error.  Hopefully at each damaged point the ECC will "get
lucky" and form a correctable read.

If the CD has been seriously damaged (i.e. backing has peeled off or been
badly scracted) there may be nothing you (or anyone) can do.

Data recovery services tend to be VERY expensive, and probably won't do
anything more than what "readcd" does.

  -- Steve

pips-sc64_63s-2.6.2-1.i386.rpm
pips-sc64_63s-cups-2.6.2-1.i386.rpm

error: Failed dependencies:
        libcrypto.so.0.9.6 is needed by pips-sc64_63s-cups-2.6.2-1
        libssl.so.0.9.6 is needed by pips-sc64_63s-cups-2.6.2-1

These libraries are in the openssl rpm; I have version ...0.0.7a instead
of ..0.9.6.  I ignored these ssl libraries via

rpm -i --nodeps pips-sc64_63s-2.6.2-1.i386.rpm

app reported that the Epson C64 was installed; so far so good.

after that without printing anything on them.

From phillk6751 at comcast.net  Wed Mar  3 22:07:01 2004
From: phillk6751 at comcast.net (phillk6751 at comcast.net)
Date: Wed Mar  3 22:07:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless cards for portables (continued)

> On Wed, 2004-03-03 at 18:09, Dave Clemans wrote:
> > > 
> > > Speed and range.  I understand the 802.11G frequency doesn't travel as
> > > far as 802.11b's 2.1GHz.  I haven't actually read any tests to back that
> > > up, mind you, it's just what I've heard in the rumor mill.  :-)
> > > 
> > 
> > 802.11g and 802.11b are exactly the same radio frequency; just a 
> > different encoding method.  The standard using a different radio 
> > frequency is 802.11a.
> 
> Why do all of the 802.11g devices say they run in the 5 Ghz range?  And
> we all know that 802.11b is using the 2.4 Ghz range.  I haven't played
> much with 802.11a devices, but I seem to recall that they also run in
> the 2.4 Ghz range.
> 
> Just a little confused.
> 
> Derek Loree

Okay, here's whats going on(from somone who's passed the CISCO 1 cirriculum) with the latest, and most popular wireless standards.

802.11a has a short range, operates at 54Mbits, and uses the 5ghz spectrum, and is incompatible with 802.11b(i.e. if one is running, the other CANNOT within the same physical area), 802.11b has a moderate range, operates at 11Mbits, and uses the 2.4ghz spectrum, 802.11g is a technology(OFDM) that allows 802.11a and 802.11b to coexist in the same physical area. 

Oh, and the actual throughput of wireless is much lower than you would expect. 11Mbps is closer to 2 to 4 Mbits actual, and 54Mbps is closer to 20 to 26 Mbits. The reason for these is that the CSMA/CA(carrier sense multiple access / collision avoidance) is similar to CSMA/CD on wired, although when a computer successfully recieves a packet, it uses up roughly 50% of the bandwidth with an AWK to let the sending host know the packet was recieved.

Another thing to proceed caution with is other devices such as 2.4ghz wireless phones, 5 ghz wireless phones, and bluetooth. Supposedly bluetooth and wi-fi can peacefully coexist(although i haven't tried), although bluetooth and 2.4ghz wireless phones and wi-fi "b" cannot, and same with wi-fi "a" and 5ghz phones....this is a touchy subject and i'm not completely sure as some may be able to get away with it and others may not.

I hope this helps you in determining which is better for your needs.

-Phil



From dgc at easystreet.com  Wed Mar  3 22:34:02 2004
From: dgc at easystreet.com (Dave Clemans)
Date: Wed Mar  3 22:34:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless cards for portables (continued)
In-Reply-To: <1078374426.6949.28.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403030905140.32399@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>	 <1078345502.10147.26.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403031242560.393@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>	 <1078350350.10147.33.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>	 <40468FCF.6020603@easystreet.com> <1078374426.6949.28.camel@fastlinux.homenet>
Message-ID: <4046CDD1.6010200@easystreet.com>

> 
> Why do all of the 802.11g devices say they run in the 5 Ghz range?  And
> we all know that 802.11b is using the 2.4 Ghz range.  I haven't played
> much with 802.11a devices, but I seem to recall that they also run in
> the 2.4 Ghz range.
> 

802.11g devices are not using 5ghz; they also use 2.4ghz.  It's the 
encoding method that lets them send "potentially" 54megabits.  To let 
"g" and "b" devices be somewhat compatible, "g" devices can fall back to 
the encoding method used by "b" devices.

802.11a is 5ghz.

If an 802.11b or 802.11g devices happens to hit the same frequency as a 
wireless phone in the 2.4ghz band, yes there can be interference.  You 
can play with channel assignments to try to work around it.  You can 
also (for example) get 2.4ghz interference from flourescent lights, 
microwave ovens, etc.

I supose the same thing is true of the newer 5ghz wireless phones and 
802.11a; if they happen to hit exactly the same frequence there will be 
interference.

 From what I've seen, 802.11a is disappearing to some extent from the 
general consumer marketplace.

There are also non-standard versions of 802.11b and 802.11g; advertised 
as having 22meg and 108meg throughput.  If I remember right they're 
using paired channels.  With the emergence of "g" the non-standard 22meg 
devices seem to be going away; the last time I was in Fry's all the 
22meg stuff was on closeout sale.

dgc




From phillk6751 at comcast.net  Wed Mar  3 23:36:01 2004
From: phillk6751 at comcast.net (phillk6751 at comcast.net)
Date: Wed Mar  3 23:36:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Wireless cards for portables (continued)
Message-ID: <030420040735.13330.5d16@comcast.net>

> the 2.4ghz spectrum, 802.11g is a technology(OFDM) that allows 802.11a and 
> 802.11b to coexist in the same physical area. 

Sorry for the slight mistake....802.11g introduces 54Mbits to an enviornment that allows 802.11b devices and 802.11g devices to coexist on the 2.4ghz band, although 802.11a still may not exist. And when an 802.11b device exists on that 802.11g enviornment, the 802.11g cards revert to B as to not interfere with the B card...which can dramatically reduce performance on the G card. There is also a difference in the encoding schemes between the 3 technologies.

The devices that allow 802.11b and 802.11a are the "dual band" wireless AP's which have a much higher price, although can allow interopability between the 3 standards(A, B, and G).

this article is a tad outdated, although might prove useful...

http://www.netgear.com/pdf_docs/ABGs_of_Wireless_2.03.1.pdf

 -Phil

On Thu, 4 Mar 2004, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> My state legislator has sent me a survey asking my opinion on several
> issues. He has a box for "things you think should be laws". I was
> thinking it would be fruitful if I mentioned the attempted Open Source
> bill. How do we think the best way to reference this would be? It would

Personally, I would reference it in broader terms.

"Publicly funded work should belong to the public and benefit the public
as a whole.  This includes copyrightable or patentable works developed
through public development projects or public research funds.  One good
start toward this ideal would be encouraging the adoption of Free and Open
Source software by public agencies."

You can reference the House and Senate bill numbers cited in PLUG
archives.

On Thu, 4 Mar 2004, Brian Beattie wrote:

> Does anybody know of any web-based system admin tools besides webmin? 
> I'm looking for something a lot lighter weight, but not holding my
> breath.

webmin can be lighten a lot by going to the webmin configuration area
and only including the modules one needs to have.  Moreover, I think
some of the modules can be lighten a bit by using the configuration
tab or whatever for the module itself - altho this isn't generally
sufficient.  I know we had to write or rewrite a number of modules
for Micro Sharp's Netule project, and in many ways this approach 
worked very well.

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Thu Mar  4 14:45:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)
Date: Thu Mar  4 14:45:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] $100M from Microsoft to SCO
In-Reply-To: <20040304214422.GD24933@nellump.net>
References: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0403040825210.20482-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
	<20040304183524.GA27676@ursine.ca>  <20040304214422.GD24933@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <1078439839.16361.68.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

On Thu, 2004-03-04 at 13:44, Paul Mullen wrote:
> On Thu, Mar 04, 2004 at 10:35:24AM -0800, Paul Johnson wrote:
> > On Thu, Mar 04, 2004 at 08:26:50AM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > > This saga is getting more and more entertaining everyday...
> > > 
> > > http://www.opensource.org/halloween/halloween10.html
> > 
> > You lowballed it.  It was 100 megadollars, not 86.  Read the whole
> > thing.
> 
> Wow, now that just changes everything. For Pete's sake, Matt. Get it
> right next time!

Is there any will at SCO anymore to profit on it's own merits?  How are
other companies doing?  The real argument against Microsoft and SCO
is that their business model isn't profitable.  There seem to be many
people with the myopic view of selling software and the "my project,"
syndrome.  Partially, the educational system where textbook monopolies
are so strong despite educational need is probably partially to blame. 
There's a lot of room for improvement at community colleges for example
where often times some proprietary software system doesn't work and
instructors get in competition with the institutions IT staff.  What I
see happening is people increasingly coming to the conclusion that
computers are junk.  This happened with cars at one time causing 
the U.S. auto manufacturer to incur major losses.  I hope it gets
fixed long before major losses occur, I'm not so sure that won't 
require future legislation though.

I'm reluctant to jump too fast, but I do get the impression that either
new laws are needed or old laws need to be enforced in the case of SCO.
If the courts can be bribed into treating Linux as someone's legal
property, we have far greater problems than Linux's future to worry
about.  If Microsoft is losing massive amounts of money on this though,
maybe it's evening the playing field.  The more Microsoft loses on
failed litigation so long as it maintains a predatory business model,
the better.

On Wed, 2004-03-03 at 22:33, Dave Clemans wrote:
> > 
> > Why do all of the 802.11g devices say they run in the 5 Ghz range?  And
> > we all know that 802.11b is using the 2.4 Ghz range.  I haven't played
> > much with 802.11a devices, but I seem to recall that they also run in
> > the 2.4 Ghz range.
> > 
> 
> 802.11g devices are not using 5ghz; they also use 2.4ghz.  It's the 
> encoding method that lets them send "potentially" 54megabits.  To let 
> "g" and "b" devices be somewhat compatible, "g" devices can fall back to 
> the encoding method used by "b" devices.
> 
> 802.11a is 5ghz.

I was confused, I didn't realize that 802.11a is capable of 54Meg/s
communication.  The marketing people are doing a good job of avoiding
the fact that 802.11a is on the way out.

> If an 802.11b or 802.11g devices happens to hit the same frequency as a 
> wireless phone in the 2.4ghz band, yes there can be interference.  You 
> can play with channel assignments to try to work around it.  You can 
> also (for example) get 2.4ghz interference from flourescent lights, 
> microwave ovens, etc.
> 
> I supose the same thing is true of the newer 5ghz wireless phones and 
> 802.11a; if they happen to hit exactly the same frequence there will be 
> interference.
> 
>  From what I've seen, 802.11a is disappearing to some extent from the 
> general consumer marketplace.


Something I still don't get is why 802.11a cannot be run in the same
physical space as the other 802.11 devices.  It seems to me that the
frequencies are far enough apart that there should be no interference,
so what prevents them from coexisting?


> There are also non-standard versions of 802.11b and 802.11g; advertised 
> as having 22meg and 108meg throughput.  If I remember right they're 
> using paired channels.  With the emergence of "g" the non-standard 22meg 
> devices seem to be going away; the last time I was in Fry's all the 
> 22meg stuff was on closeout sale.

They were pushing 108Meg stuff last time I was there, but I had never
heard of it, which makes me think that it is a proprietary dual radio
device, that is not really capable of 108Meg/s throughput, but can
transmit and receive simultaneously.  Some marketing guy then added 54
and 54 to make it seem like a very fast device.  This is all conjecture
though, because, like I said, I had never heard of it until that fateful
visit to Fry's.

Getting less confused as time goes on, thanks to all of you.

Derek Loree

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Thu Mar  4 19:39:01 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)
Date: Thu Mar  4 19:39:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Routing through non bridged DSL...
Message-ID: <1078457413.17632.23.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I had my cisco DSL-500 bridged because I couldn't masquerade through it.
Is this the case with the Actiontec 1520's that are so common now too?

One curiosity is if there is an alternative to masquerading that would
work with the DSL-500 Cisco box in it's non bridged configuration.

I know you can do aliasing where I wonder if that and a combination
of source and destination nat on a Linux router would do the trick?

It normally has a private subnet in it's normal mode.  The idea would
be to have a one to one correspondence between alias ip addresses and
local ip addresses of machines I want to grant Internet access to. 
Essentially, my idea is to take any packet that shows up on say the
external alias and rewrite the destination address so that it
gets to the internal host.  For packets going out from an internal
host, source nat could be employed to change the source address
to the alias equivalent.  

How is gateway's address used by host-a?

----------    -----------    ---------------
| host-a |----| gateway |----| remote-host |
----------    -----------    ---------------

The machine host-a presumably creates a packet with it's 
source address destined for remote-host, but it's sent to 
the gateway first.  Aren't there only two ip addresses 
in an IPv4 packet?

Does host generate a packet with the source address set to 
the gateway, or does every ip packet have a routing address 
in addition to source and destination addresses?  Is the 
packet with the source of host and the destination broadcast?  
That can't be, the gateway address is needed on host to get 
out.

Mike De La Mater <mikedela at ipns.com> wrote:
> I'd like to use my FC1 box to forward certain messages from the
> evolution client to another e-mail address.

Have you considered using procmail?  That way, you don't have to have

> It looks like one of the options is to pipe a message to a shell command
> in my evolution v1.4.5. 

Are you *sure* Evo doesn't offer a "forward" or "bounce" action?

> What would that command look like? 

 | mail -t you at elsewhere.net -s "Message Subject" 

That is, pipe through the "mail" command, with options to specify the
recipient and subject.

***Mac OS X Panther for Unix Geeks
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0596006071
If you are disoriented by the new Mac environment, this book will get you
acclimated. It's a guide to understanding the BSD Unix system and
challenging Panther-specific components. It includes an overview of the
Terminal application and Panther's filesystem and startup processes, as
well as coverage of LDAP and NetInfo, Fink and Darwin Ports, and the Apple
X11 distribution for running X Windows applications. The book also
features a manpage-style reference to the undocumented commands that come
with Panther.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/mpantherunix/

Chapter 14, "MySQL and PostgreSQL," is available free online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/mpantherunix/chapter/index.html


***Dancing Barefoot--Finally Available!
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0596006748
Wil Wheaton--blogger, geek, and Star Trek: The Next Generation's Wesley
Crusher--gives us five true tales of life, love, and the absurdities of
Hollywood in "Dancing Barefoot." Far from the usual celebrity tell-all,
this book is a vivid, personal account of Wil's search for his true self.
If you've ever fallen in love, attended a Star Trek convention, or
pondered the meaning of life, you'll find a kindred soul in the pages of
"Dancing Barefoot."
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/barefoot/


***WebLogic: The Definitive Guide
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 059600432X
"WebLogic: The Definitive Guide" presents a 360-degree view of the world
of WebLogic. An exhaustive treatment of the WebLogic server and management
console answers any question that developers, administrators, and system
architects might think to ask. From building, packaging, and deploying
applications to optimizing the runtime WebLogic environment, dealing with
security issues, and understanding Enterprise APIs, this book provides
detailed analysis, thorough explanations, and clear examples to help you
master this powerful and complex application server.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/weblogictdg/

Chapter 18, "XML," is available free online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/weblogictdg/chapter/index.html


***Mac OS X 10.3 Panther Little Black Book
Publisher: Paraglyph Press
ISBN: 1932111867
"Mac OS X 10.3 Panther Little Black Book" features techniques to help
intermediate and experienced Mac users get the most out of the new Panther
operating system. This book includes extensive coverage of Panther's new
networking and printing features, high-speed Finder searching
capabilities, system preferences, font manager, Font Book, applications
including iChat AV and iPhoto, and the much improved mail system. With
access to hundreds of immediate solutions to everyday dilemmas, you'll
learn how to solve problems, perform critical tasks, and maximize your 
use of OS X.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/1932111867/


***Adobe Photoshop CS One-on-One
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0596006187
"Adobe Photoshop CS One-on-One" clears the fog, taking you from graphics
newbie to Photoshop warrior. This full-color book from Photoshop master
Deke McClelland includes a CD with nearly two hours of professionally
produced video tutorials that feature Deke and relate to the book's
written instructions, giving you an up-close and personal training
experience that simulates the classroom environment. You'll travel step by
step through real-world projects that help you gain Photoshop proficiency,
and along the way, you'll get a good dose of graphics theory, best
practices, and tips for avoiding Photoshop disasters.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/adobephoto/


***Dreamweaver MX 2004: The Missing Manual
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0596006314
"Dreamweaver MX 2004: The Missing Manual" helps first-time and experienced
web designers bring stunning, interactive web sites to life. A
step-by-step annotated tutorial takes readers through the construction of
a state-of-the-art commercial web site, complete with Flash buttons,
Cascading Style Sheets, and dynamic databases. You'll learn how to create
and when it's appropriate to use web features such as forms, animations,
and pop-up windows. And you'll learn scores of undocumented workarounds
and shortcuts. With over 500 illustrations and a handcrafted index, this
book is the ultimate atlas for Dreamweaver MX 2004.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/dreammx2004tmm/

News From O'Reilly & Beyond

---------------------
General News
---------------------
***We're Bringing Back RepKover Lay-Flat Bindings
Lay-flat bindings are back. Readers of O'Reilly books will once again be
able to plop their book next to a terminal or on a cafe table and be sure
that it will stay open to the page they're perusing. O'Reilly is
reinstating the RepKover binding, which allows the interior of a book to
"float" free from its cover. More durable and flexible than a traditional
perfect binding, the RepKover binding allows the interior of a book to lay
flat when open. The bindings will start appearing in bookstores
immediately. Going forward, all new books will be produced with the
much-loved lay-flat binding (except for books that are too thin or thick
for the RepKover process).


***The Uganda Digital Bookmobile 
Inspired by his experience on the road with the Internet Bookmobile,
Richard Koman, along with Brad deGraf, founded Anywhere Books, an
organization dedicated to deploying the bookmobile approach in development
contexts. In turn, Koman and deGraf partnered with the National Library of
Uganda to create the Uganda Digital Bookmobile. Koman writes about his
experience in Uganda with this project, which included the set up of
scanning stations and a printing system at the National Library in
Kampala.
http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/q/articles


***Wallace Wang's Unusual Career: Stand-up Comedian & 
Computer Book Author
"Wally Wang, 'Steal This Computer Book 3,' knows firsthand the importance
of sticking with even the most far-reaching New Year's resolutions. On
Jan. 1, 1990, the Detroit native resolved to dive headfirst into a
stand-up comedy career. The decision might not have been a monumental one,
except that Wang had never even set foot in a comedy club." Read the rest
of this story in this recent "Las Vegas Sun" article:
http://www.lasvegassun.com/sunbin/stories/read/2004/jan/23/516226302.html

Steal This Computer Book 3 
Publisher: No Starch Press
ISBN: 1593270003
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/1593270003/

---------------------
Open Source
---------------------
***Amazon and Open Source
Amazon realized early on that amazon.com was more than just a book site,
more in fact than just an e-commerce site. It was becoming an e-commerce
platform. Open source has been a key part of the Amazon story, and
although Amazon has closed code, it has created its own "architecture of
participation" that may be even richer than that of many open source
software development communities. Tim shares his thoughts in the 
latest Ask Tim.
http://www.oreilly.com/pub/a/oreilly/ask_tim/2004/amazon_0204.html


***Mod_python's PSP: Python Server Pages 
For simple web sites, inlining code in the pages themselves is shockingly
effective. For more complex sites, it can even work with good MVC design.
Fear not, Pythonistas, mod_python's PSP brings the power and clarity of
Python to web programming. Grisha Trubetskoy explains.
http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/python/2004/02/26/python_server_pages.html


***Day in the Life of #Apache 
Rich Bowen tackles yet another common Apache dilemma in the latest
installment in this series based on his conversations on the IRC channel,
#apache. This week he delves into the sometimes confusing world of
modules: when to enable them, when to disable them, and why.
http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/apache/2004/02/26/apacheckbk.html

---------------------
Mac
---------------------
***Cleaning iPhoto 
When you have thousands of images in iPhoto and don't have time to cull
them manually, scripting starts to look very appealing. brian d foy shows
you some helpful AppleScripts and Perl scripts you can use to clean up
your iPhoto libraries.
http://www.macdevcenter.com/pub/a/mac/2004/02/27/cleaning_iphoto.html


***bash on Mac OS X 
In the migration from Jaguar to Panther, one of the lesser-discussed
changes has been the switch from tcsh to bash as the default shell (for
new accounts). In this article, David Miller delves into affected areas,
such as aliases and environment variables, to help you make the
transition.
http://www.macdevcenter.com/pub/a/mac/2004/02/24/bash.html

---------------------
Windows
---------------------
***Inside IIS 6 
With the release of Windows Server 2003, Microsoft has made significant
changes in how IIS works. Mitch Tulloch brings you up to speed on what's
new, and gives you insider tips on how to take advantage of it.
http://www.windowsdevcenter.com/pub/a/windows/2004/03/02/inside_iis.html


***Protect Yourself Against Kerberos Attacks 
The only way to defend yourself is to understand your attacker in-depth.
This excerpt from the recently released "Security Warrior" by Cyrus
Peikari and Anton Chuvakin details Kerberos attacks. Read it and prepare
yourself.
http://www.windowsdevcenter.com/pub/a/windows/excerpt/swarrior_ch14/index1.html

---------------------
Java
---------------------
***Configuring JBoss 4.0 JDBC Connectivity 
JBoss uses the HypersonicDB by default, but with a few configuration
changes, it can use any JDBC-equipped database. Deepak Vohra shows how to
use Oracle, Sybase, MySQL and other databases with JBoss.
http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2004/02/25/jbossjdbc.html

---------------------
Web
---------------------
***The Ideal Digital Photographer's Workflow, Part 3 
You can achieve greater control over the quality of the images produced by
your new digital camera if you shoot them in RAW format. Trouble is, it
can take an inordinate amount of time to convert RAW images into something
your image-editing program can use. In Part 3 of Ken Milburn's series on
creating ideal digital photography workflows, he details several steps you
can take to save hours of RAW-process work after every shoot. Ken is the
author of the upcoming "Digital Photography: Expert Techniques."
http://www.oreillynet.com/pub/a/javascript/2004/02/24/digital_photography.html

.NET
---------------------
***O'Reilly Learning Lab's .NET Certificate Series
Learn .NET programming skills and earn a .NET Programming Certificate from
the University of Illinois Office of Continuing Education. The .NET
Certificate Series is comprised of three courses that give you the
foundation you need to do .NET programming well. The courses are: Learn
XML; Learn Object-Oriented Programming Using Java; and Learn C#. Enroll
now in all three courses and save over $500.
http://oreilly.useractive.com/courses/dotnet.php3


***Developing Web-Service-Driven, Smart Mobile Applications 
Working with web services and other network protocols that were designed
with broadband in mind can become a real burden to making applications
really mobile. But there is hope. Michael Yaun walks through the design
and implementation of a complete end-to-end mobile application that solves
these difficult problems.
http://www.ondotnet.com/pub/a/dotnet/2004/02/23/mobilewebserviceapps.html

New Releases
----------------------------------------------------------------
***Linux Pocket Guide
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0-596-00628-4
"Linux Pocket Guide" gets you up to speed quickly on day-to-day Linux use.
The book begins with general concepts like files and directories, the
shell, and X windows, and then presents detailed overviews of the most
essential commands. You'll learn each command's purpose, usage, options,
location on disk, and even the RPM package that installed it. Throw in a
host of valuable power user tips and a friendly, accessible style, and
you'll find this practical, to-the-point book a small but mighty resource
for Linux users. 
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/linuxpg/

Sample excerpts are available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/linuxpg/chapter/index.html.


***Ethereal Packet Sniffing
Publisher: Syngress
ISBN: 1-932266-82-8
"Ethereal Packet Sniffing" is the first book available on Ethereal, the
premier open source protocol analyzer for Windows and Unix. Ethereal
offers more protocol decoding and reassembly than any free sniffer out
there, and this book will show you how to make the most of it. You'll
learn how to use Tethereal, the command-line version of Ethereal; install
and build Ethereal from source; pinpoint network problems using filters to
manage network operations and traffic; import and export files between
Ethereal and various compatible products; and so much more.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/1932266828/


***Getting Started with LEGO Trains
Publisher: No Starch Press
ISBN: 1593270062
Learn to build LEGO Trains, from setting up train tracks to building
custom freight cars. Jacob H. McKee, an authority on LEGO Trains, teaches
basic building techniques and shares some of his most fascinating and
original train designs. You'll learn how to build a North American-style
locomotive, a 1940's refrigerator car, and an intermodal container car,
plus you'll gain the skills to create your own designs. Four color
throughout.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/1593270062/


***iPod & iTunes: The Missing Manual
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0-596-00658-6
iTunes and the iTunes music store aren't just for Mac fans anymore. Anyone
running Windows XP or 2000 can now cash in on all the capabilities of this
music store jukebox. Our new version of "iPod & iTunes: The Missing
Manual" has been thoroughly updated to reflect these changes. No matter
what kind of music moves you, this book will help you get much more out of
your iPod--and much more into it.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/ipodtmm2/


***Check Point Next Generation with Application Intelligence 
Security Administration
Publisher: Syngress
ISBN: 1-932266-89-5
>From the authors of Syngress's best-selling "Check Point NG Security
Administration" comes the definitive work on Check Point's latest product
release: Check Point NG Feature Pack 4. No competing book covers every
product contained within FP 4 (SMART, SecurePlatform, SecureXL, ClusterXL,
and Performance Pack). Although not a study guide, this book will cover
all objectives on Check Point's CCSA exam and a free exam simulator will
be available from syngress.com
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/1932266895/


***Hardware Hacking: Have Fun While Voiding Your Warranty 
Publisher: Syngress
ISBN: 1932266836
"Hardware Hacking" is for people who dream of running Linux on an Xbox and
opening a garage door with a PDA. To successfully hack consumer and SOHO
electronic devices, you need knowledge of electrical engineering,
operating systems, software coding, and mechanics; the first part of this
book is a primer on these topics. Then the real fun begins. You'll learn
how to hack mobile devices (PDAs, cell phones), gaming systems (Xbox,
PS/2, Atari), audio/visual equipment (TiVo boxes, home theater PCs),
computer equipment (iMacs, laptops, mini-motherboards), and much more.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/1932266836/


***Oracle Essentials, 3rd Edition: Oracle Database 10g
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0-596-00585-7
"Oracle Essentials, 3rd Edition: Oracle Database 10g" distills a vast
amount of knowledge into an easy-to-read volume. The new edition of this
classic book covers the full range of Oracle's features and technologies,
including the product line, architecture, data structures, networking,
concurrency, and tuning. With a new overview of Oracle 10g, as well as
coverage of recent releases 9i and 8i, this book provides everything you
need to install and run Oracle databases. If you're new to Oracle or
upgrading to Oracle 10g, you'll find this comprehensive guide essential.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/oressentials3/

Chapter 1, "Introducing Oracle," is available online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/oressentials3/chapter/index.html


***Squid: The Definitive Guide
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0596001622
Squid is the most popular web caching software in use today, and it works
on a variety of platforms including Linux, FreeBSD, and Windows. Written
by Duane Wessels, the creator of Squid, this book will help you configure
and tune Squid for your particular situation. Newcomers to Squid will
learn how to download, compile, and install code. Seasoned users will be
able to dive into advanced topics such as high-performance storage
options, rewriting requests, HTTP server acceleration, monitoring,
debugging, and troubleshooting Squid.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/squid/

Chapter 8, "Advanced Disk Cache Topics," is available online.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/squid/chapter/index.html

Open Source
---------------------
***Things Squid Administrators Should Know
New users often struggle with the same frustrating set of idiosyncrasies
involved in learning Squid, the popular web caching software. Here are six
things you should know about using Squid from the get-go, from Duane
Wessels, creator of Squid and author of "Squid: The Definitive Guide."
http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/onlamp/2004/02/12/squid.html


***A Ticketing System for a Three-Tiered Architecture

user interface from the data store from the application logic. Of course,

process. Elena Garderman and Howard Feldman explain how adding a ticketing
system can improve the process.
http://www.onlamp.com/pub/a/onlamp/2004/02/12/ticket_system.html

Subject: [PLUG] Samba troubles
In-Reply-To: <20040301171130.GA15418@ahapala.net>

On Mon, 1 Mar 2004, Keith Nasman wrote:

> On Sun, Feb 29, 2004 at 08:49:41PM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > I'm trying to setup would should be a fairly simple Samba configuration
> > for someone.
> > They have a dual-boot server with Windows Server 2003 and RH 9.  There's a
> > FAT32 partition that is mounted read/write for the world on the Linux
> > side.  I then want to share this out on the network.  Here's my smb.conf:
> > 
> > [global]
> > workgroup = somecompanyworkgroup
> > security = share
> > 
> > [Public]
> > path = /mnt/e/Public
> > read only = no
> > guest only = yes
> > 
> > 
> > Pretty simple...  and it works great when I test it on my home network.
> > But when a Win2K client on their network tries to access the Samba server,
> > this message is given:
> > 
> > "There are currently no logon servers available to service the logon
> > request."
> > 
> 
> Matt,
> 
> It looks like your Win2003 server is the PDC and when you boot the RH9
> side there is no PDC to authenticate to (unless the RH9 is set to be a
> PDC in other smb.conf parameters).
> 
> The section of the smb.conf manpage entitled "NOTE ABOUT
> USERNAME/PASSWORD VALIDATION" might help.
> 
> HTH,
> Keith

Yeah, that was the problem, I guess.  So I added the necessary lines to
smb.conf to make it a PDC, added the users and their passwords, and the
users were then able to browse the public shares.
Thanks,
~M




From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Mar  5 21:55:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri Mar  5 21:55:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] hdparm and partition tables
Message-ID: <20040306055401.GB29920@gate.kl-ic.com>

Last night in my presentation I mentioned that hdparm doesn't reread
the partition table for disks after hotswapping.

With help from Elliott Mitchell, and the source for /sbin/hdparm,
I learned that when loading a new drive, I should be typing:

hdparm -zb 0 /dev/backup    instead of hdparm -b 0 /dev/backup

RTFSC, I guess.  Of course, once you know the correct nomenclature,
RTFM also applies.

Mea Culpa.  For punishment, I shall read the Collected Wisdom of
Darl McBride.  All done.

Keith

a section on it.

What annoys me is that I get so much spam that has invalid addresses
in it where I can't seem to enable Postfix's header checking without
blocking legitimate email.  It seems that a lot of legitimate sites
either aren't forward listed or reverse listed, but they aren't
consistent.  I need a rule that implements an inclusive or on 
reverse and forward address checks, but does Postfix offer this?
Maybe intro to SQL next term will suggest new approaches to
the problem.

The other trick I'd like to pull is processing mail with perl so that
I can extract certain words mixed in with trash characters where this
stuff gets through spamassassin undetected otherwise.

my server where the server it tries to bounce to 550's it.  For once
it would be nice to see more legitimate emails in my logs than bounces,
etc.  If I 550 an attempt by someone to send email to me, it's stuck
in their cache, right?  I would think if I didn't let somebody connect
to me to send email that they would give up at some point.  Is it
normal to get a lot of apparently unregistered dsl addresses in spam?
For the infinite bounce problem, I've automated a defer cache sweep,
though I seem to be sweeping at least two to three messages a day.

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Mar  7 01:01:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun Mar  7 01:01:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] linux on one floppy?
In-Reply-To: <1078649247.2326.4.camel@x1-6-00-40-f4-82-41-d5>
References: <1078649247.2326.4.camel@x1-6-00-40-f4-82-41-d5>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403070053551.9438@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sun, 7 Mar 2004, jarrod wrote:
> is there a distro that still fits on one floppy. I found some HOWTOs on
> how to build one yourself but it take two floppys. I would like to find
> a distro that I can use as a portable bash prompt. nothing more other
> then being able to store text files and get into vim.

Uh... you're talking about a fairly hefty piece of software, then.

jbrelin at person:~$ ls -l /bin/bash /usr/bin/vim
-rwxr-xr-x    1 root     root       551548 Sep 25  2001 /bin/bash*
-rwxr-xr-x    1 root     root       756860 Sep  3  2001 /usr/bin/vim*
jbrelin at person:~$ file /bin/bash /usr/bin/vim
/bin/bash:    ELF 32-bit LSB executable, Intel 80386, version 1 (SYSV),
dynamically linked (uses shared libs), stripped
/usr/bin/vim: ELF 32-bit LSB executable, Intel 80386, version 1 (SYSV),
dynamically linked (uses shared libs), stripped

That's pretty much one full floppy right there... no kernel, no init, no
nothin'.

Now, if you want something smaller, you might be able to squeeze ash and
elvis-tiny onto a floppy with a very bare kernel, but you'd be pushing it.

But you might be looking for something more like a root-boot floppy that
is essentially a rescue kernel and one of the mini-shell/swiss army knife
utilities like busybox.

What's the purpose of such a thing?  Isn't this why God made Knoppix?

J.

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Mar  8 11:59:01 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Mar  8 11:59:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] NTFS read/write
In-Reply-To: <20040308170258.GA27303@ursine.ca>
References: <20040308080005.79429.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403080757520.30674-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
	 <20040308170258.GA27303@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <1078778499.6380.264.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Mon, 2004-03-08 at 09:02, Paul Johnson wrote:

> On Mon, Mar 08, 2004 at 07:59:03AM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
>  
> > Well, as long as you only want to rewrite existing files with exactly the
> > same size...
> 
> ...or any file if you want to use Linux 2.6.

The 2.6 kernel's NTFS write support is very limited... I believe it is
more limited than 2.4's, but it is *safe* to use.  With 2.6, you're able
to write anything to pre-existing files, so long as you do not alter the
file's size.  That's it.

The 'Captive' NTFS driver, on the other hand, is able to use Windows
files to do the hard work of playing the NTFS game.  You're able to read
and write properly...

I don't understand why nobody has heard of this thing... it has so many
uses (fixing b0rk3d windoze computers accounting for almost all of the
uses).

Rob

From mikeraz at patch.com  Mon Mar  8 17:48:02 2004
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Mon Mar  8 17:48:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Samba, LDAP, and my sanity.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403081713340.9438@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403081702290.30944-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403081713340.9438@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20040309014550.GE9611@patch.com>

On Mon, Mar 08, 2004 at 05:16:11PM -0800, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> The fact is, I don't even really care about LDAP.  I just want Samba to do
> what I want it to do without a Windows Domain Controller.
> 
> It seems like a fairly straightforward thing.  "Samba Single Sign-On
> How-To"  Why doesn't it exist?  Is it because it's not possible?

I believe you're asking the wrong question.  The answer lies not in SAMBA, 
but in PAM.  PAM controls with authentication methods are considered 
for your environment.  PAM orders the sequence of authentication tries.
PAM is your friend.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Mar  8 18:00:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Mar  8 18:00:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Samba, LDAP, and my sanity.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403081427240.9438@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403081427240.9438@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1078797543.6092.11.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Mon, 2004-03-08 at 14:30, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> Am I crazy?  When I create users by hand, they don't authenticate.  When I
> try to set "security = domain", testparm tells me it's "not recommended".
> And when I read the docs at samba.org, it appears as though this only
> works when you've got a Winders server doing the real authentication.

Right.  'security = domain' is for when the Samba server is a MEMBER of
an SMB domain, rather than domain controller or stand-alone server.  One
of the latter of the two cases is what you want; both require 'security
= user'.

Exactly how are you creating users by hand?  What does your smb.conf
look like?  Are your LDAP ACLs too tight?  Does does an entry created by
this 'by hand' method look like (hint: ldapsearch)?

> What gives?  Is there a better HOW-TO on this?

Well, there are several, but taking a little time to understand LDAP
would make it easy; LDAP is a big technology to assimilate along with
the mix of Samba authentication.  That said, you don't HAVE to use LDAP
if you don't need replicated authentication (such as having a Backup
Domain Controller)--you can keep everything in flat files (passwd,
smbpasswd, group) like you've always been able to with Samba 2.2.

Wil

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Mon Mar  8 19:09:01 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Mon Mar  8 19:09:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Samba, LDAP, and my sanity.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403081812310.9438@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403081427240.9438@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <1078797543.6092.11.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403081812310.9438@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1078801734.6092.76.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Mon, 2004-03-08 at 18:19, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> I started with "security = user", but then the Samba-3 How-To said that
> domain security was the way to go for "single sign on".  I figured I was
> closer to the right track before.

I don't think you really want to try for "single sign-on"; SSO is more
like Kerberos, where all the services on your network are authenticated
only once, when the user logs in to his machine.  It supposedly can be
achieved with Kerberos, but I haven't done the setup or tested enough to
know how many clients actually support the required authentication
mechanisms.

> > Exactly how are you creating users by hand?
> 
> smbldap-useradd
> 
> > What does your smb.conf look like?
> 
> Uh... it's a little long, but it's totally consistent with your wiki
> SambaLdapIntegration example.

The global section is really the only interesting thing.

> > Are your LDAP ACLs too tight?
> 
> I don't think I've configured any.

That's probably why; OpenLDAP defaults IIRC to read-only access by
anonymous (or anyone else) and read-write access to the rootdn only. 
Now that I look at my doc, I totally left off the ACL stuff, because I'd
intended to add it later in different sections for master and slave LDAP
servers.

I'm assuming you're behind a reasonably protected network and there
aren't script kiddies continuously looking for any hole to get in, so
why don't you try a wide-open ACL by setting the default access to
'write' (just add a line 'defaultaccess write' to slapd.conf) and
restart.  See if you can add a user with smbldap-add that works
afterwards; my guess is the addition fails.

> > Does does an entry created by this 'by hand' method look like (hint:
> > ldapsearch)?
> 
> I've never used ldapsearch and a cursory glance at the man page doesn't
> make a usable command line obvious.

ldapsearch -x -D <ROOTDN> -W -b <basedn> -h <ldaphost> \
objectclass=sambaSamAccount

The -x is the key part that's easy to over-look.

> I couldn't get that to work, either, though.  I am MORE than willing to
> forego LDAP in exchange for something that actually works.  (Though,
> again, the Samba-3 How-To Collection basically pushes you away from
> anything but LDAP.)

Well, it does for PDC/BDC setups, because it's the only way to do it
reliably.  Unless your setup is more complicated than I've been able to
infer, you don't need a PDC/BDC setup.  That said, I think the LDAP ACL
is probably the most immediately missing part.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                                 wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

*   Naked Ape Consulting                 http://nakedape.cc  *

From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Mar  8 19:22:01 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)

On Mon, 8 Mar 2004, Randall Lucas wrote:

> Alternatively, does anyone know of a good Linux-based
> syntax-highlighting IDE that supports Perl (I could just tunnel an X

Do you need a full-blown IDE, or just a syntax-highlighting editor? If
the latter, your choices are many:

* vim
* emacs
* gedit (2.4.x; I don't think 2.2.x does syntax highlighting)
* kate (KDE Advanced Text Editor)

and a gazillion others. I happen to be partial to vim, but they'll all
do the job.

On the IDE side of things, Googling for 'linux perl ide' returns a few
interesting links.

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Mon Mar  8 23:43:02 2004
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon Mar  8 23:43:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Samba, LDAP, and my sanity.
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403081702290.30944-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403081713340.9438@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <slrnc4qtg5.i59.aaron@aluminum.bavariati.org>

Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> wrote:
> On Mon, 8 Mar 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:
>> I've been struggling with Samba too.  I recently picked up an excellent
>> book, "The Official Samba-3 HOWTO and Reference Guide." ISBN:
>> 0-13-145355-6
>
> We don't all have US$40-50 to throw down on documentation.  There's, you
> know, food and stuff to consider first.

Nice of Russell to point out a free source for the info.

> The fact is, I don't even really care about LDAP.  I just want Samba to do
> what I want it to do without a Windows Domain Controller.

Ah.  OK, no other NT server?  Then you want Samba to be the PDC
[Primary Domain Controller].  LDAP is a separate issue, save it for
later.

http://www.mandrakeuser.org/docs/connect/csamba6.html
http://www.samba.org/samba/docs/man/Samba-HOWTO-Collection.html

That said, here's a couple Samba-PDC LDAP howtos:
http://www.unav.es/cti/ldap-smb-howto.html
http://www.mandrakesecure.net/en/docs/samba-pdc.php




From aaron at speakeasy.org  Mon Mar  8 23:52:02 2004
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon Mar  8 23:52:02 2004
Subject: [plug] Mounting a linux drive on a Windows box via tunnel
References: <404CB616.1AF16AAA@tercent.net>
Message-ID: <slrnc4qu1v.i59.aaron@aluminum.bavariati.org>

Randall Lucas <rlucas at tercent.net> wrote:
>
> I have two locations behind firewalls, and I'd like to do a little web
> editing using a Windows-based editor, with the files on a remote Linux
> box.  The firewalls have 80, 443, and 22 punched through for http/s and
> ssh.

1. SCP everything over and back.  CygWin has scp, and some Windows GUI
SSH clients support SCP as "file transfer".

2. Get WebDAV working on the Linux web servers.  On Windows it's
called "Web Folders".

3. SSH in and use a Real Editor. ;)

A "here's a nickel, kid" B

Why won't my mailserver give up and stop littering my logs with
Connection refused?  I blocked these addresses locally later, 
my mailserver was getting rejected messages from these ip 
numbers before I blocked them locally.  What triggered trying
to send to these addresses and Connection refused
in the first place?  Am I looking at bounce attempts, or am
I infected with an email generator?

I'd like to get checking for A and MX records working, the 
error from email not getting in from pluglist to me hopefully 
shows the problem.  The mailhub I want to fix, goose, can look 
up lists.pdxlinux.org and the ip address using the host command 
no problem.  So why am I getting Sender Domain not found?  Does 
postfix use a different command than host that is broken or 
something?

I'm starting to think that's what needed is an SQL database
and some heuristics to set up temporary blocking if this is
the same guy on DSL or Cable doing this.  It seems like I'm
getting the same message from the same place multiple times,
but on the other hand, there is some slight variation that
looks like nothing more than random garbage characters.  I
wish something could be done to make it easier to defeat
mass email generators.  A USAA magazine listed a poll
that says 94% of people are angry about Internet porn 
and Internet spam.  Spamassassin isn't catching junk
that's hidden by garbage characters, but I'd prefer 
not to let spam get in in the first place.  I don't want
to spend time writing filters, if I can avoid that.

I think using blacklist sites and DNS verification isn't 
working because of DNS problems.  It's hard to see what 
those problems are though because DNS seems to work just 
fine.  I don't have a correct init script for dual DNS 
which I am needing to run.  I have two chroot jails for
a lan and an Internet DNS server where I want to restrict
my internal DNS server to querying by my lan and the 
outside servers to queries from Internet hosts which 
I have attempted to implement by how I bind the servers 
to my interfaces.  I don't know if Bind 9 can run one
dns server that acts as two with different network
views, but that sure would be nice.  I've always wanted
to implement my own domain system on my lan so I can use
name_of_the_room.home, but dns only seems to be desinged
for one naming hierarchy so I've used my externally
registered name internally.




From kenb at nu-world.com  Tue Mar  9 15:05:02 2004
From: kenb at nu-world.com (Ken Barber)
Date: Tue Mar  9 15:05:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] New Linux class at LCC
Message-ID: <200403091432.42050.kenb@nu-world.com>

Spring Term will commence in about three weeks and with it will 
come some changes in the Linux sysadmin classes at LCC.

The current class will be split into two classes, called Level 1 
and Level 2.  The official descriptions of these classes are 
here...

http://www.lanecc.edu/cont_ed/cont_ed/cc_menu_classes.html#10

... but thanks to insanely early deadlines the official 
descriptions are little more than guesses at what the Linux 
landscape was going to look like right about now.  What follows 
are more recent (and useful) descriptions of the two classes.

We're still following the Red Hat model for training, and now that 
we know what RH is doing with Enterprise Linux training & 
certification we're kinda sorta doing things that are similar.  

LEVEL ONE

The first-level class will cover what's needed to build, install, 
troubleshoot and maintain Linux workstations.  We won't do any 
server stuff at all except ssh and peer-to-peer file sharing with 
'doze boxen.

More details will be available after I create the syllabus 
(hopefully within the next week) but this is what I envision 
right now:

*	Basic Stuff that has been holding back some of the 
less-experienced students in my current classes, such as shell 
basics, grep & regular expressions and networking essentials.

*	Other basics such as filesystem structure and tools, process 
control, package management and local user & group management.

*	Basic host security.

*	Connecting workstations to various enterprise services such as 
NIS, NFS and so forth.  Yeah, I know they're lame but for some 
reason the certification testers are still requiring knowledge & 
experience in that stuff.  No, I don't get it either.  

I probably won't get around to Netware and LDAP interoperabilty 
this term but I hope to cover it in this course sometime in the 
future. I'm kind of waiting for the dust to settle around the 
Novell/SUSE thing.

Basically, Level One will cover most of the stuff needed for 
obtaining an RHCT.  It should be noted that LCC is not a 
Redhat-blessed training facility; we're only covering the topics, 
we're not preparing people to take the exam.

LEVEL TWO

The second-level class will cover most of the ground that is in 
the typical RHCE portion of a Redhat certification exam.  Again, 
this should not be construed as a class that will prepare anyone 
to actually sit for the exam, it's just a description of the 
topics that will be covered.

In this class we will build secure servers (and as much network 
infrastructure as can be done in the lab that we use):

Firewalls, routers, DNS and DHCP servers.  Web and mail (SMTP, POP 
and IMAP) servers.  NFS, NIS and Samba servers, including domain 
authentication for, and interoperability with, 'doze domains.  
Management of large numbers of machines.  And at some point 
(probably not this term), after we know what the Netware/Linux 
landscape is going to look like, hopefully Netware & LDAP 
interoperability.

More information will be available after I get the syllabus 
written, hopefully in the next week.

You can register on-line for either of these classes (or, if you 
know any newbies, for the "Intro to Linux" class) at LCC's 
website (lanecc.edu).  

Please feel free to forward this to anyone whom you think might be 
interested.  Any questions, just ask!

Thanks,

Ken




From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Tue Mar  9 15:17:01 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
