On Tue, 2004-03-09 at 14:32, Ken Barber wrote:

> We're still following the Red Hat model for training, and now that 
> we know what RH is doing with Enterprise Linux training & 
> certification we're kinda sorta doing things that are similar.  

I've got to say... you lose about 25 points in my book when you base a
class entirely around a single distribution.  RedHat does too many
things that other distros don't to be considered 'The Linux' ... I,
personally, feel Slackware is about as close as you can get to a
non-special distribution, but I realize many people don't like it.  It's
easy to teach distribution-agnostic skills with such a distro, however.

I realize you're aiming specifically for RHCE stuff, and would probably
call it intro to RedHat Linux if you could put RedHat in the title of
the class, but I really just dislike classes calling themselves 'Linux'
classes when they are, in fact, RedHat classes.  Linux != RedHat.

Rob

From keith at ahapala.net  Tue Mar  9 15:41:02 2004
From: keith at ahapala.net (Keith Nasman)
Date: Tue Mar  9 15:41:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] command of the day
Message-ID: <20040309234845.GG6175@ahapala.net>

Although I've used lsof before I don't know why I didn't come across
this earlier.

keith at r31:~$ lsof -i | head -n 4
COMMAND    PID  USER   FD   TYPE DEVICE SIZE NODE NAME
evolution 1634 keith   38u  IPv4   4040       TCP 10.0.0.199:32850->presto:imap2 (ESTABLISHED)
ssh       2790 keith    3u  IPv4   6429       TCP 10.0.0.199:32941->ahapala.net:ssh (ESTABLISHED)
synergys  2856 keith    5u  IPv4   6958       TCP *:24800 (LISTEN)

one command gets you all the commands, pids, users, ports and
connections on one screen. If you run it as root you'll see ALL the
network connections.

Keith

Although there's a much newer and revised tool about to come out (and

version is better than just about anything, IMO. (Which is really just

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Tue Mar  9 17:43:03 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Darkhorse)
Date: Tue Mar  9 17:43:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Implementing only whitelisted allowed to stop spammers...
Message-ID: <1078882464.26612.108.camel@goose.robinson-west.com>

I've been thinking about the need to close the smtp port 
to spammers to really stop them where it would take a lot 
of research and a lot of iptables rules to block every 
single spammer. A lot of spam comes from innocent sites 
that have been infected by a worm or virus.  In the 
interest of processing time and aware that spamassassin 
isn't always effective, I'm considering blacklisting 
all addresses and maintaining a whitelist for each
user.

Graylisting is an option, but it may stop legitimate 
email since some servers won't retry.  

A perhaps less risky approach involves the use of a 
database and maybe some Perl script.  My idea is to 
pull the headers out of email from untrusted sources 
using Perl and update a running SQL database with them.  
The goal being, have a record of email headers for the 
purpose of helping local users update their white lists.  
All you need to see is the subject and the source to 
know if you want an email, email messages that aren't 
from white listed addresses can be processed so that 
the header is sent to the intended recipient in a new 
message with a special reply address when that address 
hasn't been encountered before.  If they delete this 
processed message instead of replying, they don't get 
the message and the source stays black listed.  They 
also don't get any virus or worm this way since they 
don't have the body yet.  This calls for all but one
email address that will be special to be black listed
for all senders initially.  It means finding out if
an attempt to transmit to the special address is being
made before SMTP gives the ok to send the message.

The biggest problem is how to make this work with a 
mailing list.  It requires white listing the address 
of every single person on that list.  The advantage 
is that I don't have to keep lists of the addresses 
of abusers where there are probably millions.  The 
computer would grind to a halt if I had a million 
ip tables rules to explicitly deny individual spam 
sites.

Ideally if SMTP can get who the sender will be and
the subject without allowing the remote site to
transmit the message body in cases of distrust
putting that information into a useful format, 
Perl won't be needed and this system can prove 
to be a vast improvement over local filtering
for spam and malware.  It changes the game to
on recipient request instead of on sender's 
whim.

I'm thinking about a special email address where
the recipient always gets a special message with just
the header of the sender's message, but that 
could be a royal pain.  The problem I'm trying to solve
over simple white listing and black listing is allowing
for growth by permitting new potential email sources
to send their email address by attempting to send an 
email in the normal way. 




From Tim.Bruce at fiserv.com  Tue Mar  9 17:50:03 2004
From: Tim.Bruce at fiserv.com (Bruce, Tim)
Date: Tue Mar  9 17:50:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Gnome Panel
Message-ID: <008A26A81DAD96489E7D4FCF259849982DEEB5@eft01ms01.eft.fiserv.net>

Ok, I'll bite.  I know that most people RTFM, but have you checked the Gnome
Administrator's Guide (Gnome2.x-system-admin-guide) (I didn't see a specific
version).  It is available from http://gnome.org/learn/.  I noticed in the
first few pages it references the gconf and gconfd applications, as well as
several others.

Further, in my environment (Red Hat 9), I have the following directories /
files in my home directory:

<d> .gnome
<d> .gnome2
<d> .gnome2_private
<d> .gnome_desktop
<d> .gnome_private
<f> .gtkrc-1.2-gnome2
<f> %gconf.xml

(where <d> represents a directory and <f> represents a file).

Exploring through these I see lots of options, but I see that there are a
lot of files in /etc/gnome-vfs-2.0/modules that you might want to look at as
well.

I hope that helps you......

Did you check for zombies or reboot the system?  I was cleaning up my
~/tmp directory the other day and deleted a directory full of sockets,
which 'lsof' told me were unused.  Well, lsof lied or I deleted
something else because any subsequent GNOME apps I started spewing
connecting errors wrt the ORB, so I logged out and forcibly restarted
the X server and then things became even stranger--text labels were
missing from the error message boxes I got (I could tell they were error
boxes based on the icons).  I switched back to a console shell and found
there were some zombied gnome-terms, so I killed their parents and any
other X clients I found and everything has been copacetic since.

  [heinlein at pecos heinlein]$ ping appl-ecosys.com
  PING appl-ecosys.com (216.99.206.23) 56(84) bytes of data.

> 
> 1)  Folks have told you time and again... just use spamassassin.  It works
> like freakin' magic and will take care of nearly every piece of garbage
> you get.  It's been suggested a thousand times and you insist on doing
> insane things to block messages instead of just using the one and only
> method outside of shutting down mail services entirely that actually
> WORKS.

No, it doesn't.  My ISP is struggling with worms where a lot of
the stuff I'm getting does not filter and it's disingenuous of 
you to put political pressure on someone to filter trash that 
has no right to be on the Internet in the first place.  It 
shouldn't be filtered, it should be stopped.  Some 
stuff that filters with spamassassin and some doesn't.  
On a DSL connection, you need to discourage wasteful
SMTP traffic because you don't have much bandwidth in the first
place.  If you don't block spam from coming in, you don't 
discourage it.  Unfilterable, unstoppable, UCE is illegal in some
states.  Why do you assume I can filter it?  Do you think I'd
ask how to stop spam that I'm filtering successfully
on a list that has given me so many helpful suggestions?  

I take issue with the comment that everyone has told me just to
filter.  They haven't.  In fact there has been talk on here about
gray listing which I've used as a reference to look into it.  I
don't feel it's strong enough though.  The dynamic of you send me
email only if I want you to can't be established with filtering 
alone.  I don't have problems with taking an aggressive stance, 
trying to keep up with new filtering methods is absurd.
I find it offensive that someone manipulates my server to 
send me messages I don't want to hear.

As a Calc III student I can say with certainty that there is no such
thing as magic.  The filtering approach to spam is failing to address
the bandwidth loss issue and the intense pressure that worms, etc. 
are putting on mail systems.  A lot of drug ads are getting around, 
I guess drug companies feel the return on negative advertisement 
is worth the bad publicity and anger people will feel.

What are needed are Internet police and advertising rules that strictly
forbid methods that make it hard to filter UCE and other junk mail.  The
SMTP protocol needs to be retired because it was not designed for a
network the size of the Internet with so many hostile mail sources.

Subject: [PLUG] Remote login via ssh
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0403092120420.12437@pecos.madboa.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403081959300.28998@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0403090744110.28415@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
	<Pine.LNX.4.56.0403091853041.12793@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.58.0403092120420.12437@pecos.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <86y8q9w537.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Paul" == Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com> writes:

Paul> [...] When you're 105 miles from your LAN, does ping show you
Paul> the IP address you expect to see for appl-ecosys.com?

The other thing that Zot suggested once that _really_ helped me zero
in on a ssh problem was to run a debugging daemon at a random port,
and progressively invoke verbosity, strace and gdb to the daemon until
clarity is achieved.  One of the non-DNS possibilities is a key problem
(since they seem to be indexed by hostnames).

Since you say you can ssh to the IP number, you ought to be able to
arrange the daemon.  [Aside: You also said that "ssh -vv hostname"
hung after some messages, but didn't say what the messages were.
Those might be relevant and helpful.]

For a similar debugging session, see:  
  <http://lists.pdxlinux.org/pipermail/plug/2003-December/027033.html>

which says, essentially:

  On the remote (server) host, run:

    # sshd -D -d -p 2222 > /tmp/debug-log 2>&1 &

  To attach strace (but skip this unless it proves necessary), use a
  command like:

    # strace -f -o /tmp/strace-sshd -p <pid-of-sshd-you-just-started>

  On the client, run:

    $ ssh -p 2222 -v <remote-hostname>

... then inspect /tmp/debug-log on the server host to achieve
enlightenment.  If this fails to bring the lightbulb you are looking
for, try again with the strace and look at the /tmp/strace-sshd you
thus created.

The port number 2222 is arbitrary (substitute your own if you prefer).

If your server host is hidden inside your network, you will need to
forward the port appropriately at the firewall.  Something like:

  # iptables -t nat -I PREROUTING -i eth0 -p tcp --dport 2222 -j DNAT --to 192.168.xxx.yyy

where eth0 is assumed to be the firewall's external interface and
192.168.xxx.yyy is the internal address of the server host.

And then apply the universal Feynman Problem Solving Algorithm:

  1. write down the problem

  2. think real hard

  3. write down the answer

That's what I'd do, anyway.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Mar 10 07:38:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Mar 10 07:38:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Remote login via ssh
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403100551340.18371@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403081959300.28998@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.58.0403090744110.28415@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403091853041.12793@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.58.0403092120420.12437@pecos.madboa.com>
 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403100551340.18371@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0403100726130.373@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 10 Mar 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

> > When you're 105 miles from your LAN, does ping show you the IP
> > address you expect to see for appl-ecosys.com?
>
>   Yes. Consistently.

Hmm. Russell's suggestion about setting up a debugging sshd is a good
one, probably the first I'd try. Here are a couple other semi-wild
ideas:

1. Are you running nscd? (ps or pidof will show you.) If so, does
   stopping it and/or restarting it make a difference?

2. Is there any mention of appl-ecosys.com in /etc/hosts? If so, does
   removing it help? If not, does adding it help?

3. Same drill with /etc/resolv.conf (careful here, however, because it
   might be autogenerated by your dhcp client)

4. You mentioned earlier in this thread that "ssh -vv" tended to stop
   in the same place each time. Can you identify what's going on when
   it stops?

5. Have you tried wrapping ssh in strace to see what's up? E.g.,

     strace -o /tmp/ssh.trace ssh appl-ecosys.com

   Then have a look at the last entries in /tmp/ssh.trace to see which
   system calls are running when things fail.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

On Wed, 2004-03-10 at 10:01, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> > Does anyone know how to configure Samba so that the "My Documents"
> > folder maps to the user's home directory on the Linux server?
> 
> If you mean the "My Documents" folder on the Windows desktop, then I
> believe the setting is made on the client side, not within Samba.

Absolutely correct. Right click the shortcut onthe win desktop, change
the location to \\server\share and you're off like a gallon of milk. You
might move their docs over from the local machine, too since most of win
users do not understand that the folder on their desktop is not actually
the my documents folder. 

My kids had their "my documents" on my redhat workstation for nearly a
year before they noticed.

Okay- now I see. Samba is about the only software I know of that does
not have direct access to windows core components. (security joke)

Sounds like you need a registry hack to switch the desktop icon, and and
a batch file that moves the contents. I do not know where the registry
keeps the values for the shortcut, but you could search for and export
that part of the registry, tweak it for each user and then put it in
their share. Tell them to run (click on) them, adding the registry
values, assuming your win boxen are all the same flavor.

How many desktops are we talking about?

From barryb at proaxis.com  Wed Mar 10 11:19:02 2004
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Wed Mar 10 11:19:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Samba: Map "My Documents" to Linux home directory?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403101120420.1758-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
References: <1078942248.20740.80.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403101120420.1758-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <20040310191812.GA16251@edge>

On Wed, Mar 10, 2004 at 11:22:33AM -0700, Matt Alexander wrote:
> On Wed, 10 Mar 2004, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> 
> > On Wed, 2004-03-10 at 10:01, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> > > > Does anyone know how to configure Samba so that the "My Documents"
> > > > folder maps to the user's home directory on the Linux server?
> > > 
> > > If you mean the "My Documents" folder on the Windows desktop, then I
> > > believe the setting is made on the client side, not within Samba.
> > 
> > Absolutely correct. Right click the shortcut onthe win desktop, change
> > the location to \\server\share and you're off like a gallon of milk. You
> > might move their docs over from the local machine, too since most of win
> > users do not understand that the folder on their desktop is not actually
> > the my documents folder. 
> 
> I was hoping Samba could setup this association automatically in their
> domain profile so I didn't have to visit each desktop...

I have done this when the Samba machine is the domain controller.
This may be more elaborate than is necessary, but it works.

in smb.conf general section you put
logon script = logon.bat

the logon.bat file on the server in the netlogon share looks like
c:\windows\wscript  \\mypdcserver\netlogon\RegChange.VBS

and the RegChange.VBS looks like
-------------
Dim WSHShell
Set WSHShell = WScript.CreateObject("WScript.Shell")
WSHShell.RegWrite "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Internet Explorer\Main\Start Page","http://www.google.com","REG_SZ"
-------------

You just have to substitute the correct registry key for the location of the "My Documents" folder
I think it will be this, 
WSHSHell.RegWrite "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Shell Folders","\\server\share","REG_SZ"
but I have not tested it.

Then as each user logs on, their folder location gets changed.

You should make the file permissions on the RegChange.VBS and the logon.bat pretty tight.

Bill Barry

From gilmanhunt at comcast.net  Wed Mar 10 16:55:03 2004
From: gilmanhunt at comcast.net (gilmanhunt at comcast.net)
Date: Wed Mar 10 16:55:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] CVS branching question
Message-ID: <031120040053.9429.49dd@comcast.net>

I'm working at my new job, happily slaving away for the man, when he asks me to check out a module from the cvs repository. So I do. Then he asks me to make it a branch of my very own. So I do. Following the instructions in this cvs document...

http://www.loria.fr/~molli/cvs/doc/cvs_toc.html
and specifically this section:
http://www.loria.fr/~molli/cvs/doc/cvs_5.html#SEC51

The docs say that this "branch creation" is sticky; and so I won't need to play with it until we merge again. However, I've created a new file and added it (cvs add filename) to the branch and then committed it (cvs commit filename). And now, if I look at the directory with my new-found-friend Cervisia (a graphical front end to cvs) it has tags for all the files with my branch name _except_ the file I added and committed, which implies that the new file I added is on the trunk rather than on my branch.  

So the question I have is -- did I do it >wrong?< 

And this CVS thang is really cool- I can see using it with "wordpress" (blogware tool at wordpress.org) to make my changes and keep my changes in place with their updates (because I"m running an old version and I'd like to upgrade but ... well... you get the idea).   I was using RCS before, so I'm not a version-systeming virgin, but CVS is a sweet sweet love.

Your help is, as always, appreciated.

-Russ



From Rob.Anderson at nike.com  Wed Mar 10 17:01:02 2004
From: Rob.Anderson at nike.com (Anderson, Rob (Global Trade))
Date: Wed Mar 10 17:01:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] CVS branching question
Message-ID: <200403110100.i2B10SbH023623@barrierb241.nike.com>

You did it right. All the files have been branched except the file you added, which you need to explicitely branch, since it was not present when you created the branch tag for the existing files. CVS is very cool :)

-Rob Anderson

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Wed Mar 10 17:24:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed Mar 10 17:24:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Win-XP Dialup
In-Reply-To: <380-220043310233246129@bctonline.com>
References: <380-220043310233246129@bctonline.com>
Message-ID: <1078968182.5546.92.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Wed, 2004-03-10 at 15:32, Chaz Sliger wrote:

> Anyone have experience with Win-XP Dialup?

Not much... but far too much...

> I can get a dialup internet connection established, but the system
> drops the link when I switch users.

...so I emailed my WinXP guru, who said:

When you have an active dialup connection and "Log Off" you are met with
a box that says...
 
"The dialup networking connection "xxx" is currently active.  Would you
like to close the connection  Yes/No"
 
This is true with a standard dialup connection, not so with AOL. The AOL
program closes when you log off.
 
If you just "Switch Users" without logging off then even AOL will
provide the other user profiles with Internet access, since the programs
running on the original profile do not close.
Scott

Rob

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Mar 11 15:27:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Mar 11 15:27:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Samba... one more time.
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403111517220.28958@shaft.bitmine.net>

OK, I've started from scratch.

No LDAP... nothing fancy.

<quote src=/etc/samba/smb.conf>
[global]
   workgroup = RKD
   server string = %h server (Samba %v)
   wins support = yes
   dns proxy = no
   log file = /var/log/samba/log.%m
   max log size = 1000
   syslog = 0
   panic action = /usr/share/samba/panic-action %d
   security = user
   encrypt passwords = true
   passdb backend = tdbsam guest
   obey pam restrictions = yes
   guest account = nobody
   invalid users = root
   unix password sync = yes
   passwd program = /usr/bin/passwd %u
   passwd chat = *Enter\snew\sUNIX\spassword:* %n\n
*Retype\snew\sUNIX\spassword:* %n\n .
   socket options = TCP_NODELAY
   domain master = yes
   logon script = logon.cmd
   logon path = \\%N\profiles\%u
   logon drive = H:
   logon home = \\%N\%u
   domain logons = yes
   local master = yes
   prefered master = yes
   os level = 65
   add machine script = /usr/sbin/useradd -g 300 -c "Machine %u" -d
/dev/null -s /bin/false %u
</quote>

I have no idea what's wrong here.

I've created a sambausers, sambamachines, and sambaadmin groups.

I've created a handful of system users with /bin/false as their shell and
sambausers as their primary group (one of which is called
"administrator").

I've added a subset of these to the sambaadmin group ("administrator" is a
member of that subset).

I then ran `net groupmap add ntgroup="Domain Admins" unixgroup=sambaadmin`.

I've created an account for a machien.  The account name ends in a $.

For each of the members of sambausers, I have run `smbpasswd -a` with
their username as the final argument and added a password.

And yet, when I attempt to configure a W2K machine to join the domain, it
fails.  When it is the machine for which I have already created a machine
account, it still asks for a username and password "with permission to
join the domain".  I give it the administrator username and password and
it comes back with a logon failure.

What gives?  Next steps?

Two days behind schedule and desperate -
J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

>    add machine script = /usr/sbin/useradd -g 300 -c "Machine %u" -d
> /dev/null -s /bin/false %u
> </quote>
> 
> I have no idea what's wrong here.
> 
> I've created a sambausers, sambamachines, and sambaadmin groups.
> 
> I've created a handful of system users with /bin/false as their shell and
> sambausers as their primary group (one of which is called
> "administrator").
> 
> I've added a subset of these to the sambaadmin group ("administrator" is a
> member of that subset).
> 
> I then ran `net groupmap add ntgroup="Domain Admins" unixgroup=sambaadmin`.
> 
> I've created an account for a machien.  The account name ends in a $.
> 
> For each of the members of sambausers, I have run `smbpasswd -a` with
> their username as the final argument and added a password.
> 
> And yet, when I attempt to configure a W2K machine to join the domain, it
> fails.  When it is the machine for which I have already created a machine
> account, it still asks for a username and password "with permission to
> join the domain".  I give it the administrator username and password and
> it comes back with a logon failure.
> 
> What gives?  Next steps?
> 
> Two days behind schedule and desperate -
> J.

I had this trouble with a Win2000 machine once and it had something to
do with the Win machine not the Samba Server. Is it all W2k machines or
one in particular?  Anyway it turned out the W2k machine had a Samba
sign on to a the same Samba server with a different directory.  The old
sign on tried at boot to use the out of date info to sign on and failed
because that directory no longer existed.
Problem was solved when w2k was reinstalled(school machine; they just
write preconfigured system to all the machines).  
-- 
Bill Spears <bspears at easystreet.com>

From m at phxlinux.org  Thu Mar 11 17:57:02 2004
From: m at phxlinux.org (Matt Alexander)
Date: Thu Mar 11 17:57:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Samba... narrowing it down.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403111659310.28958@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403111842470.13109-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>

On Thu, 11 Mar 2004, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> 
> OK, so I got smbclient to allow to connect to a share on the localhost as
> a samba only user.  That seemed like success.
> 
> But still, when any of the W2K machines tries to join the domain, I get
> "Logon failure: invalid username or bad password" (or very similar words).
> 
> I would think that I had an authentication issue with the samba server,
> but that's clearly not the case because I can authenticate with smbclient.
> 
> Perhaps W2K is using a different authentication scheme?  That seems wrong.

Here's my smb.conf:

[global]
workgroup = testdomain
netbios name = Samba
server string = Samba PDC
domain master = yes
domain logons = yes
wins support = yes
interfaces = eth1 172.16.1.10
bind interfaces only = true
socket options = IPTOS_LOWDELAY TCP_NODELAY SO_RCVBUF=8192 SO_SNDBUF=8192
add user script = /usr/sbin/useradd -m %u
delete user script = /usr/sbin/userdel -m %u
add group script = /usr/sbin/groupadd %g
delete group script = /usr/sbin/groupdel %g
add user to group script = /usr/sbin/usermod -G %g %u
add machine script = /usr/sbin/useradd -s /bin/false -d /dev/null %u
logon path = \\%L\Profiles\%u
logon drive = H:
logon home = \\%L\%U
os level = 65
idmap uid = 15000-20000
idmap gid = 15000-20000
hosts deny = all
hosts allow = 172.16.1. 127.0.0.1
obey pam restrictions = yes
force create mode = 0777
force directory mode = 0777
force security mode = 0777
force directory security mode = 0777

[netlogon]
comment = Network Logon Service
path = /var/lib/samba/netlogon
admin users = root,m
guest ok = yes
browseable = no

[Profiles]
comment = Roaming Profile Share
path = /var/lib/samba/profiles
read only = no
profile acls = yes


I create a Linux user account on the Samba box and add that user to the
smbpasswd file "smbpasswd -a <username>".  Then on the Win2K box, I change
it to the Samba domain (after it prompts me for a domain admin/pass),
reboot, and then login to the Win2K box with one of the users I created on
the Samba box in the domain.  So I never add the machine accounts to the
Samba server directly.  This is handled for me when I change the client to
the new domain using the 'add machine script' section of smb.conf.
I still need to understand what's going on with the profiles directories
better because the only way I could get profile information to be saved
after a user logged out was to force the permissions to be wide open on
the server.  Hopefully I can lock this down soon as I learn more about how
this works.
~M

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Thu Mar 11 19:31:02 2004
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (E. Rogan Creswick)
Date: Thu Mar 11 19:31:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Acroread EULA window
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403111752190.27920@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403111752190.27920@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <16465.12010.485146.938433@bebop.local>

Rich Shepard writes:
 >   Using the '-geometry' option applies only to the document windows, not the
 > EULA window. Does anyone have a suggestion for how to shrink the silly thing
 > so I can get rid of it once and for all? Taking the top window frame and
 > shrinking the window shrinks it from the top; the bottom is still
 > unavailable.

Some options:

     -  Shrink from the top, then move it up (I don't think this
        actually works in this case).
     -  up your res. to be > than 768 vertical (obviously not an
        option all the time..)
     -  up the res and use a virtual desktop (gets arround the issue
        above)
     -  Change WM's temporarily (Enlightenment supports the
        alt-movement)
     -  Create two or more desktops (or workspaces--terminology changes
        based on WM) such that windows span from one to the other.
     -  drop in an extra video card an use xinerama to spread your
        desktop across both cards (orient the screens vertically).
           Note that this does _not_ require two monitors.
     -  I imagine you could copy your .acrobat or .adobe or whatever
        from another computer and restart acrobat.
     -  There may be an accessability tool that could help, or a
        keyboard sequence that lets you select the "accept" button
        w/out seeing it.


Hope something works, I've had this issue in the past, but I've always
had an enlightenment install arround.  By the way, gnome/kde have long
ago passed E in terms of required resources.. at least untill dr17 is
released ;). 

--Rogan

>     What do people use for drawing network diagrams, organization
> charts, and the like?  The tools I have used for this do the job, but

XCircuit is intended to be a schematic layout and capture app, but it
works pretty good as a general-purpose drawing program, too. It saves
the files it creates as PostScript.

<http://xcircuit.ece.jhu.edu/>

I've always found dia frustrating to use, and xfig downright
excruciating.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Mar 11 21:10:03 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Mar 11 21:10:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] spam first time in my life!!!!!!
In-Reply-To: <1079058935.9298.2.camel@x1-6-00-40-f4-82-41-d5>
References: <1079058935.9298.2.camel@x1-6-00-40-f4-82-41-d5>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0403112056070.12437@pecos.madboa.com>

On Thu, 11 Mar 2004, jarrod wrote:

> I have never had spam until about a month ago. I started getting a
> lot of shit in my mail. I have never payed attention to all the spam
> talk because it never effected me. Now that I have it I look on
> google and there is so much info that it is mind boggling.
>
> Any suggestions were to start? My ISP is comcast.

I get dozens, sometimes hundreds, of pieces of spam per day from my
comcast account. I rarely see any of them.

1. Grab your mail using fetchmail. Comcast supports POP over SSL, so
   you can encrypt your session if you so desire. Here's a
   ~/.fetchmailrc snippet:

   poll mail.comcast.net proto pop3
     user "remote-you", with password "password", is "local-you" here,
     ssl,
     sslfingerprint "86:4B:ED:3A:64:CE:70:D4:56:C1:DE:57:C6:92:AC:19"

2. Using procmail (or sieve or whatever), feed all inbound mail to
   SpamAssassin 2.63. Here's a ~/.procmailrc recipe:

   # scan all inbound messages under 200K in size for spam
   :0fw
   * < 200000
   | /usr/bin/spamassassin

   # send spam to spam folder
   :0
   * ^X-Spam-Flag: YES
   .spam/


   For better performance, read up on using spamd/spamc instead of the
   the spamassassin script.

3. Season SpamAssassin to taste in ~/.spamassassin/user_prefs:

   # See 'perldoc Mail::SpamAssassin::Conf'
   required_hits      4.00
   use_bayes          1
   bayes_min_spam_num 100
   bayes_min_ham_num  100
   rewrite_subject    0
   report_header      1
   report_safe        0
   use_terse_report   1
   defang_mime        0
   ok_languages       en de
   ok_locales         en de
   rbl_timeout        10
   # too many spammers are abusing this header set
   score HABEAS_SWE 0.0

Happy spam killing!

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri Mar 12 08:36:01 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Mar 12 08:36:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] RPM dependency problem
In-Reply-To: <8A331D75F9F3CD4CA589854776E6F2E60255BB37@hq-ex01.christenson.dom>
References: <8A331D75F9F3CD4CA589854776E6F2E60255BB37@hq-ex01.christenson.dom>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0403120824580.12437@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 12 Mar 2004, Morthland, Cam wrote:

> Anyone have any insight?
>
> [root at black tmp]# rpm -Uvh php-4.1.2-7.3.6.i386.rpm
> warning: php-4.1.2-7.3.6.i386.rpm: V3 DSA signature: NOKEY, key ID
> db42a60e
> error: Failed dependencies:
>         libcrypto.so.2 is needed by php-4.1.2-7.3.6
>         libgd.so.1.8 is needed by php-4.1.2-7.3.6
>         libpng.so.2 is needed by php-4.1.2-7.3.6
>         libssl.so.2 is needed by php-4.1.2-7.3.6
>         libstdc++-libc6.2-2.so.3 is needed by php-4.1.2-7.3.6

For the libstdc++-libc6.2-2.so.3, you'll need the compatability rpm:

  compat-libstdc++-6.2-2.9.0.16.i386.rpm

The gd and png libraries are easy to find:

  gd-1.8.4-4.i386.rpm
  libpng-1.0.14-0.7x.4.i386.rpm

I'm a bit unsure of which openssl package will satisfy the *.so.2
dependencies; it'll be one of the following:

  openssl-0.9.6b-35.7.i386.rpm
  openssl095a-0.9.5a-23.7.3.i386.rpm
  openssl096-0.9.6-23.7.i386.rpm

All of these packages are available via the Fedora Legacy site:

  http://download.fedoralegacy.org/redhat/7.3

Original release rpms are in the os/ directory; later fixes are in the
updates/ tree.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

Date: Fri Mar 12 10:20:06 2004
Subject: [PLUG] RPM dependency problem - More Info
In-Reply-To: <8A331D75F9F3CD4CA589854776E6F2E60255BB40@hq-ex01.christenson.dom>
References: <8A331D75F9F3CD4CA589854776E6F2E60255BB40@hq-ex01.christenson.dom>
Message-ID: <20040312181918.GA5873@accesscom.com>

On Fri, Mar 12, 2004 at 10:06:47AM -0800, Morthland, Cam wrote:
>
> [root at black tmp]# rpm -Uvh   php-4.2.2-17.2.i386.rpm  
> warning: php-4.2.2-17.2.i386.rpm: V3 DSA signature: NOKEY, key ID
> db42a60e
> error: Failed dependencies:
>         libgd.so.1.8 is needed by php-4.2.2-17.2
> 
> [root at black tmp]# rpm -Uvh gd-1.8.4-4.i386.rpm 
> warning: gd-1.8.4-4.i386.rpm: V3 DSA signature: NOKEY, key ID db42a60e
> error: Failed dependencies:
>         libpng.so.2 is needed by gd-1.8.4-4
> 
> [root at black tmp]# rpm -Uvh libpng-1.2.2-16.i386.rpm
> warning: libpng-1.2.2-16.i386.rpm: V3 DSA signature: NOKEY, key ID
> db42a60e
> Preparing...                ###########################################
> [100%]
>         package libpng-1.2.2-16 is already installed
> 
> [root at black tmp]# rpm -Uvh gd-1.8.4-4.i386.rpm 
> warning: gd-1.8.4-4.i386.rpm: V3 DSA signature: NOKEY, key ID db42a60e
> error: Failed dependencies:
>         libpng.so.2 is needed by gd-1.8.4-4
>  

What version of Red Hat are you running?  What version of Red Hat did
you get the httpd, php, libpng, and gd packages that you are trying to
install?  Try doing "rpm -q httpd php libpng gd".   

You can also investigate the dependencies manually: "rpm -q --provides
libpng" tells you what libpng provides.  "rpm -qp --requires
gd-1.8.4-4.i386.rpm" tells you what the package requires.  "rpm -q
--whatprovides libpng.so.2" tells you if anything provides that
dependency.

You might want to install yum or apt.  They do the dependency
resolution and download the packages.  I use the versions from
http://freshrpms.net/.

 - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/

W32.Beagle at mm!zip is a detection for password-protected .zip files that
carry executables belonging to the W32.Beagle at mm family of mass-mailing
worms. 

The following variants contain password-protected .zip files as email
attachments:

W32.Beagle.F at mm 
W32.Beagle.G at mm 
W32.Beagle.H at mm 
W32.Beagle.I at mm 
W32.Beagle.J at mm 
W32.Beagle.K at mm

Note: The W32.Beagle at mm family of worms cannot infect a computer unless the
.zip file is opened, the random password is entered, and the executable file
contained within is executed.

From gilmanhunt at comcast.net  Fri Mar 12 14:44:02 2004
From: gilmanhunt at comcast.net (gilmanhunt at comcast.net)
Date: Fri Mar 12 14:44:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] more cvs confusion
Message-ID: <031220042243.16100.4c14@comcast.net>

My new love, CVS, is sobbing incoherently. Perhaps some more help from a CVS porn star would help =)

Scenario:
I have checked out from the repository, and branched my changes (using cvs tag -b javascript). Now, I've edited the index.php file, and I've tried to commit it, and it won't commit to my javascript branch (and so, natcherally, I fubarred the trunk's index.php, to the consternation of all). And I've gone on to add a directory (/jscript) but when I try to commit the files in that directory, either manually or with cervisia, the branch names do not "take" the javascript tag. 

In fact, the version numbers on the jscript directory look like "1.1" rather than "1.2.1.2" -- but that's just because I wrote the whole shebang and committed it rather than checking and rechecking the files. But, since these files are part of the branch, shouldn't they look like the (magic version number) 1.1.1.1 - having 4 places?

I can fix the index.php issue; but how do I convince cvs to put the /jscript directory in the javascript branch and not in the trunk? The RCS/Entries file doesn't even have the "javascript" tag at the end of the lines.



From Rob.Anderson at nike.com  Fri Mar 12 15:10:03 2004
From: Rob.Anderson at nike.com (Anderson, Rob (Global Trade))
Date: Fri Mar 12 15:10:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] more cvs confusion
Message-ID: <200403122308.i2CN8pvF011116@barrierb241.nike.com>

> -----Original Message-----
> From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org
> [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On Behalf Of
> gilmanhunt at comcast.net
> Sent: Friday, March 12, 2004 2:43 PM
> To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
> Subject: [PLUG] more cvs confusion
> 
> 
> My new love, CVS, is sobbing incoherently. Perhaps some more 
> help from a CVS porn star would help =)
> 
> Scenario:
> I have checked out from the repository, and branched my 
> changes (using cvs tag -b javascript). Now, I've edited the 
> index.php file, and I've tried to commit it, and it won't 
> commit to my javascript branch (and so, natcherally, I 
> fubarred the trunk's index.php, to the consternation of all). 
> And I've gone on to add a directory (/jscript) but when I try 
> to commit the files in that directory, either manually or 
> with cervisia, the branch names do not "take" the javascript tag. 

If you do a cvs status on the files in this directory, do the files show that they are from the javascript branch? If not, do a "cvs update -r javascript" to update them to the branched version. Then edit index.php and check it in. To undo the fubarred index.php on the trunk you can run "cvs admin -o 1.x index.php". This command will delete version 1.x from the repository. BE CAREFUL WITH "cvs admin -o"!!!

> 
> In fact, the version numbers on the jscript directory look 
> like "1.1" rather than "1.2.1.2" -- but that's just because I 
> wrote the whole shebang and committed it rather than checking 
> and rechecking the files. But, since these files are part of 
> the branch, shouldn't they look like the (magic version 
> number) 1.1.1.1 - having 4 places?

You are correct about the version numbers, but these should only be seen after a commit has taken place on the branch, until then you will see things like 1.3 or 1.8. After a commit on the branch you will see somethink like 1.3.1.1 and 1.8.1.1. I seem to remember that one must first create the branch with "cvs tag -b", then update to the branch with "cvs update -r" before the file in the local sandbox have the branches sticky tag. 

> 
> I can fix the index.php issue; but how do I convince cvs to 
> put the /jscript directory in the javascript branch and not 
> in the trunk? The RCS/Entries file doesn't even have the 
> "javascript" tag at the end of the lines.

In CVS directories are not version, so there is no way to tell CVS that the directory goes on the branch. You must brach the file and then update to the branch. Run "cvs status" to be sure that the branch sticky tag shows up before you edit and commit.

-Rob Anderson (The John Holmes of version control)

provided by the libpng10 package; that's probably the one you need to
install to get gd installed.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Mar 12 15:59:02 2004

Date: Fri Mar 12 15:59:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Real time screen capture
Message-ID: <20040312235740.GB26514@gate.kl-ic.com>

Are there any applications that do real-time full-motion screen capture
for X-Windows displays, perhaps over the network?  I would like to be
able to run an animation, or show something being typed, and capture 
what it does to a file, without slowing down the machine, but also 
without smoothing over the irregularities and jerkiness of the rendering.
There is probably a big Heisenberg factor here, and I am probably out
of luck, and instead should just feed the VGA output into a dedicated
recorder.  Still...

I would like to apply this to live computer demos that are part of
presentations.  Rather than have everyone watch while I laboriously set
up that particular bit of a demo, it would be handy to show video clips
of the demonstration instead, edited for brevity, and capable of being
stopped to point things out.  Video clips used that way would really
speed up and smooth out a presentation.   

But again, that may be asking too much.

Ideas?

Keith

OK, I noticed something just now that I hadn't before: libpng.so.2 is
provided by the libpng10 package; that's probably the one you need to
install to get gd installed.

Red Hat 9 installation tree. They should match the ones you've
downloaded:

On Fri, 2004-03-12 at 15:57, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> Are there any applications that do real-time full-motion screen capture
> for X-Windows displays, perhaps over the network?

There used to be a few different ways to record VNC sessions... one
which was used for a test at tightvnc.com, but it is no longer mentioned
there.  Google says http://www.cs.ubc.ca/~bsd/vncrecording.html might be
able to do the job for you.

There are utilities to export an existing X session out over VNC.

That should do the trick for you.  That's how *I* would go about it, not
knowing of better alternatives.

Rob

On Fri, Mar 12, 2004 at 11:09:13AM -0800, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Fri, 2004-03-12 at 11:03, Paul Johnson wrote:
> 
> > Switch to Debian, leave dependency hell behind.
> 
> I haven't seen a binary distro out there yet that doesn't have some very
> messed up dependencies.  Source distros still have a few messed up
> dependencies, but far fewer than any binary distro.

dpkg doesn't allow screwed up things like dependencies on a particular
file, and folks making .debs tend to follow Debian guidelines instead
of making up their own package names and standards.  Therefor, any
.deb, any distro.  None of that retarded "It's a Red Hat package that
only works on Mandrake" bullshit.

Thank all of you who responded to my question.
It looks like either dia or xfig would work, but neither of them are
any where close to as nice and smooth as Visio.  The main differences
are that:

         -  Visio seems to have better clip art
         -  Visio allows one to attribute objects in a meaningful
            manner.  (Of course, Visio doesn't allow one to do 
            anything useful with these attributes.)

Of course, these conclussions are based on limited experience with
dia and extremely limited experience with Visco.  

On the other hand, I use to use xfig a certain amount in my former
life in GIS.  It works pretty well, but is far from perfect.  I did
remember that it had clip art objects in it.  I guess I never used
these.


Anyway,

                                                     Thanks,
                                                     Dave

> standards.  Therefor, any .deb, any distro.  None of that retarded
> "It's a Red Hat package that only works on Mandrake" bullshit.

RPM repositories have come a long way in the past couple years. Both
yum and apt are superior tools for non-trivial rpm installations and
upgrades.

At work, I now point most Red Hat and Fedora boxes at a local
yum-ified repository, and package updates/installations work just as
smoothly as they do on the Debian boxes I've got at home.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

Dave,

With a little work you can make your own objects. Dia uses XML to
describe its objects.  Modify the supplied objects as you like and make
your own library.

Dia's data is stored in compressed ascii if you are interested in bit
fiddling.

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403111623180.27780@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403111623180.27780@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, 11 Mar 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   On my Slackware-9.1 notebook xpdf sometimes cannot find the appropriate
> fonts to display a document. I've not before encountered this problem on my
> other systems. Perhaps I don't have enough fonts loaded on the new machine.

  Got this one resolved, too. Xpdf was looking for fonts in a non-existent
directory. So, making a symlink from the directory where they are located to
the directory xpdf wanted to use fixed the problem. It's been reported to
the support team at Slackware.

Adding Debian to SuSE's boot loader might be best,
assuming that you use NTLDR to boot either XP or
Linux. Then selecting Linux from NTLDR's menu would
lead to another choice, from GRUB, of SuSE or Debian.

Pro, which might be more convenient but probably would
not perform as well as a native installation.

On Sat, Mar 13, 2004 at 06:58:23PM -0800, jarrod wrote:
> 
> what would be the best way of becoming free of windows with out killing
> my linux system in the process.

I'd think you should be able to re-format the Windows partition from
within Linux and then just use it as bonus hard drive space. This ought
to work fine if you don't feel the need to rearrange everything after
removing Windows. AFAIK, Linux doesn't really care what the type the
freshly wiped partition is marked as.


Paul

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Mar 14 19:43:01 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun Mar 14 19:43:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] getting rid of windows
In-Reply-To: <20040315033200.GA30876@nellump.net>
References: <1079233103.2428.10.camel@x1-6-00-40-f4-82-41-d5>
 <20040315033200.GA30876@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403141939120.19451@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Sun, 14 Mar 2004, Paul Mullen wrote:

> I'd think you should be able to re-format the Windows partition from
> within Linux and then just use it as bonus hard drive space. This ought to
> work fine if you don't feel the need to rearrange everything after
> removing Windows. AFAIK, Linux doesn't really care what the type the
> freshly wiped partition is marked as.

  To add to what Paul wrote: if you use fdisk (or cfdisk), as root and on a
console, you can change the filesystem type of /dev/hda1 to 83 (linux) while
keeping it as the bootable partition. However, you'll need a mount point for
it and most distributions (well, at least Red Hat and Slackware) want to put
/ on /dev/hda1.

  What would most likely turn out to be the quickest, easiest and least
frustrating would be to back up everything you want, repartition the drive
and re-install the OS. If the partition was anything but /dev/hda1 I think
you'd find it a lot easier.

Rich

Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President

<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

From chris at maybe.net  Sun Mar 14 20:30:03 2004
From: chris at maybe.net (Chris Jantzen)
Date: Sun Mar 14 20:30:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] auth.log
In-Reply-To: <1079321971.3240.33.camel@www.kosmal.net>
References: <1079321971.3240.33.camel@www.kosmal.net>
Message-ID: <20040315042959.GJ3326@maybe.net>

On Sun, Mar 14, 2004 at 07:39:31PM -0800, Marv wrote:
> What is "reverse mapping checking getaddrinfo for
> 66-42-36-140.sttl.dial.netzero.com" all about??

Do "host 66-42-36-140.sttl.dial.netzero.com" (or nslookup or dig or
whatever's appropriate) and it'll return an ip address. Then do "host
xx.xx.xx.xx" on that ip address. If they don't match, the isp is doing
something wrong, or someone who controls their reverse lookup was
trying to take advantage of host-based authentication (which you
shouldn't do anyways) to break in. If they do match, your DNS server
may have had a hiccup, or they "cleaned up their act". The benign
answers (incompetent isp and dns hiccup) are, unfortunately, the most
likely answers. ("Unfortunately", in that it's a bit like Chicken
Little.)

-- 
chris kb7rnl =->

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun Mar 14 21:39:03 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun Mar 14 21:39:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: local-ish rack suppliers?
Message-ID: <20040315053754.GA20742@gate.kl-ic.com>

If you are on a tight budget but have some time, then consider some
surplus solutions.  The Tektronix RAMS (recycle and material salvage)
store often has 19 inch racks.   The Tek store is open on Thursdays
from 2 until 5, call ahead.  There might also be some racks at Wacky
Willie's.

But a better way to go is a small modification of Rich's suggestion,
LOBOS, lots of boxes on shelves.   Rather than fixed shelves, get
some of those wire-shelf on roller pole systems ( www.metro.com).
This means you can move the system up against the wall, or turn it
around to work on.  The open-wire shelves are nice to wire-tie cables
and power strips and hubs to.  If you can't find these racks used at
one of the surplus places above, they are expensive new.  There are
very expensive but pretty versions at Storables;  but you can go there
and see some of what is available.  In any case, these might be the
way to go for stacks of odd sized boxen.  

Keith

Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From drl at drloree.com  Mon Mar 15 00:53:01 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Mon Mar 15 00:53:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] getting rid of windows
In-Reply-To: <1079233103.2428.10.camel@x1-6-00-40-f4-82-41-d5>
References: <1079233103.2428.10.camel@x1-6-00-40-f4-82-41-d5>
Message-ID: <1079340782.10287.117.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Sat, 2004-03-13 at 18:58, jarrod wrote:
> well from my understanding the partition table for all systems is on
> hda1. I also have my winxp on the same hda1. All my linux partitions are
> on higher number partitions. 

No, the partition table isn't stored on a partition, it is stored in a
special set of sectors that are not included in any partition scheme.
> 
> So I want to get rid of windows. If I delete my hda1 partition with the
> linux fdisk program it seems like I would destroy my partition table and
> lose my ability to get into my linux system. 

Good move, getting rid of windows lets in lots of fresh air.  Deleting
hda1 won't delete any other partitions, but it will delete the windows
boot loader.  This may or may not be a problem, depending on how your
linux boot loader is configured.  If it is configured to load from the
master boot record (/dev/hda and not /dev/hda?) then you should have no
problems.
> 
> what would be the best way of becoming free of windows with out killing
> my linux system in the process.

There is no real answer to this question, you have lots of options.  The
"best" way depends on how your boot loader is configured, what you want
to do with the partition, how the rest of the drive is partitioned, and
how much free space you have left on those other partitions.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

On Sun, 14 Mar 2004, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> But a better way to go is a small modification of Rich's suggestion,
> LOBOS, lots of boxes on shelves.  Rather than fixed shelves, get some of
> those wire-shelf on roller pole systems ( www.metro.com). This means you
> can move the system up against the wall, or turn it around to work on.
> The open-wire shelves are nice to wire-tie cables and power strips and
> hubs to.  If you can't find these racks used at one of the surplus
> places above, they are expensive new.  There are very expensive but
> pretty versions at Storables;  but you can go there and see some of what
> is available.  In any case, these might be the way to go for stacks of
> odd sized boxen.

I have LOTS of this style of shelving.  Some of it is from Storables and
some of it is genuine Metro stuff (culled from dumpsters and garage sales
and the like).

I can attest that they are highly compatible (the desk at which I sit now
has a Metro 36x24 shelf and a Storables 36x24 sliding shelf on Storables
vertical supports)... but it's not 100%.  Basically, you can mix the
shelving all you want and all the accessories work perfectly with the
latest Storables stuff (some of their old shelves had lengthwise grills
instead of width-wise) and classic, unchanging Metro stuff, but for a
given shelf, you have to choose either Metro or Storables (I forget their
upstream vendor's name) poles.  While they are both marked at 1"
increments, there are little double-bumps every five inches on the
Storables poles that makes perfect alignment impossible above five inchess
off the ground.

Anyway, I've got piles of this stuff (all in use and almost always
wanting/needing more) and heaps of experience with the various little
bits, so I'm surely going overboard here.

J.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon Mar 15 10:42:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon Mar 15 10:42:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: local-ish rack suppliers?
In-Reply-To: <20040315144113.29739.86823.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040315144113.29739.86823.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040315184105.GB25866@gate.kl-ic.com>

Keith says:
> > But a better way to go is a small modification of Rich's suggestion,
> > LOBOS, lots of boxes on shelves.   Rather than fixed shelves, get
> > some of those wire-shelf on roller pole systems ( www.metro.com).

Brent replies:
> I'm a huge metro shelving fan, they provide half of the total storage in 
> my kitchen and allow me to roll around the TV along with 200lbs of AV 
> equipment in the basement with something approaching ease - but I'm 
> looking to go fully enclosed now for  noise and aesthetic reasons.

Keith responds:

I see where you are trying to go.  Your problem will be cooling;
anything closed up will interfere with case cooling.  One thing I have
done on my machines in the past is put foam cushioning tape between the
big metal sides of hinge cases, and the metalwork inside - it reduces
the "guitar sound box" effect and muffles the fans.  There seems to be
quite a lot of quiet-fan activity among the case modders, and those
see-through plastic cases they are fond are a little less resonant than
the metal cases, though they would look ugly with foam tape added.

Now, I am imagining modifying one of those Honeywell HEPA air cleaners
to feed a dryer duct, and run that from outside somewhere to the back
of a large wooden cabinet, on rollers, with doors front and back.  Too
wierd and expensive, probably, but it would look nice and be quiet.
Wood = quiet compared to a metal case.   Of course, wood = flammable,
too.

But keep in mind cooling - the insides of computers get too hot anyway,
and those cheap sleeve-bearing fans fail easily.  Plan on fan upgrades
(to quiet/reliable) for all your computer cases before you stick them
in anything closed up.

Perhaps another alternative, if it all goes into a sealed metal case,
is to remove all the computer case covers and operate them open, and
blow air through the entire cabinet.  I read somewhere that the noise
from a fan goes up as the 5th (!!!) power of the air velocity, other
things being equal.  So a 2X radius fan (4x area) moving the same air
volume will need 1/4 of the velocity, resulting in ( 1/1024 (V^5) x 4 (A) )
or 1/256 of the noise - 24 dB less.  So imagine a cabinet with a 4
foot Casablanca-style fan sucking air through a furnace filter and
blowing air through open cases.

More realistically, you have better things to do than invent funny
cases with big fans.  Do the fan mods, find some metal shelving
with an open front, line it with sound-absorbing material (fiberglass
insulation?) and turn it around so you don't have to look at your
computers.  But don't restrict the airflow, or Mr. CPU will get cranky
and write binary obscenities on your hard disk, and Mr. Power Supply
will sing some flame thrower kareoke.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

in the area of spam-suppression. I realize that I'll take a

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Mar 15 10:53:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Mar 15 10:53:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: local-ish rack suppliers?
In-Reply-To: <20040315184105.GB25866@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20040315144113.29739.86823.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
	 <20040315184105.GB25866@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <1079376758.5969.381.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Mon, 2004-03-15 at 10:41, Keith Lofstrom wrote:

> Now, I am imagining modifying one of those Honeywell HEPA air cleaners
> to feed a dryer duct, and run that from outside somewhere to the back
> of a large wooden cabinet, on rollers, with doors front and back.  Too
> wierd and expensive, probably, but it would look nice and be quiet.
> Wood = quiet compared to a metal case.   Of course, wood = flammable,
> too.

I think water cooling is where you need to be looking.  A single 120mm
fan can cool a system fairly well... and very quietly.  Assuming you
aren't using some super-hot video card, you'll do better with water
cooling than with air cooling, just in the temperature department.

> But keep in mind cooling - the insides of computers get too hot anyway,
> and those cheap sleeve-bearing fans fail easily.  Plan on fan upgrades
> (to quiet/reliable) for all your computer cases before you stick them
> in anything closed up.

Invariably, people I know who try to close up their computers come to me
to replace their failing hard disk after about a year.  It just doesn't
work unless it is done properly.

Again... water cooling pretty much helps this out.

> Perhaps another alternative, if it all goes into a sealed metal case,
> is to remove all the computer case covers and operate them open, and
> blow air through the entire cabinet.  I read somewhere that the noise
> from a fan goes up as the 5th (!!!) power of the air velocity, other
> things being equal.  So a 2X radius fan (4x area) moving the same air
> volume will need 1/4 of the velocity, resulting in ( 1/1024 (V^5) x 4 (A) )
> or 1/256 of the noise - 24 dB less.  So imagine a cabinet with a 4
> foot Casablanca-style fan sucking air through a furnace filter and
> blowing air through open cases.

When dealing with traditional air cooling, you *need* that directed flow
over components.  If you have lmsensors installed, watch your CPU
temperature go up as you open the side of your case.  Your drives won't
get the directed air flow, either.  Neither will your video card. 
Instead all the not-hot stuff gets as much air as the hot stuff does.

If you don't direct the air flow, you're going to need a lot more of it
to keep everything cool.  That'll lead to more noise.

> More realistically, you have better things to do than invent funny
> cases with big fans.  Do the fan mods, find some metal shelving
> with an open front, line it with sound-absorbing material (fiberglass
> insulation?) and turn it around so you don't have to look at your
> computers.  But don't restrict the airflow, or Mr. CPU will get cranky
> and write binary obscenities on your hard disk, and Mr. Power Supply
> will sing some flame thrower kareoke.

Water cooling is going fairly mainstream in the last few years.  Check
it out... you can cool a whole system, assuming it isn't something
really hot, with a single 120mm fan.  Toss a second 120mm fan in there
to cool the PSU and disks with a little added airflow if you want...
120mm fans are darned quiet compared to what is in your system now.

Rob

It's hard to keep current information in journal style 
materials, but it's annoying to run into so much stuff 
that's way off that this problem has to be put in 
perspective.  At least there's a real question when
a search can produce anything if you ever want to 
search alone.

If plug list shouldn't be used as a search engine in any
sense, then why does it exist at all other than the
occasional OT post everyone loves, the question that 
google doesn't answer ( uh, I meant OT question again, 
google must have the answer ).  

I don't see how questions on how to use Openoffice's help 
affectively is OT, it was very difficult to find what I 
needed where I cheated by copying the character
I wanted out of the help file once I finally found
a useful page.

I don't think I'm the only one who feels the Internet
is more like a street that cuts through the good and 
bad parts of the world than anything else.  To go to 
a place like that to answer technical questions is 
well, controversial.  For those who say content is 
holy and it's people who make some content a problem,
they've never been addicted to anything or they
don't see anything wrong with addiction.

Maybe searching for Lambda doesn't in most cases produce
links to unsavory sites, but what if you need to find out
about a virus named after a woman.  I guess the best bet
is to simply not search alone, but I wish there was a
better answer.

> Rob
> 
> 
> _______________________________________________
> PLUG mailing list
> PLUG at lists.pdxlinux.org
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug

In-Reply-To: <1079233103.2428.10.camel@x1-6-00-40-f4-82-41-d5>
References: <1079233103.2428.10.camel@x1-6-00-40-f4-82-41-d5>
Message-ID: <200403152039.34918.phillk6751@comcast.net>

On Sunday 14 March 2004 2:58 am, jarrod wrote:
> well from my understanding the partition table for all systems is on
> hda1. I also have my winxp on the same hda1. All my linux partitions are
> on higher number partitions.
>
> So I want to get rid of windows. If I delete my hda1 partition with the
> linux fdisk program it seems like I would destroy my partition table and
> lose my ability to get into my linux system.
>
> what would be the best way of becoming free of windows with out killing
> my linux system in the process.

You can always reformat the hda1 partition to your liking and if it doesn't 
boot you can use a boot disk, chroot to your current linux 
enviornment(/dev/hda2?) and run lilo/grub, that should fix any problems with 
that. Might have to edit the bootloader config though.

-phil

From phillk6751 at comcast.net  Mon Mar 15 21:30:02 2004

On Tuesday 16 March 2004 5:11 am, cabbey wrote:
> I can't imagine batteries lasting too long with that combination.

Actually in the benchmarks that i've pounded through(all on 32 bit windows). 
The AMD-64 laptops give 2+hours of gaming on battery, and 3-3.5 hours doing 
standard things such as web browsing and simple tasks, and dvd playing 
somewhere in-between. On windows the Athlon-64 underclocks to 800mhz(although 
doesn't affect performance as expected) from 2ghz when on battery saver mode, 
so it saves quite a bit of battery life when you don't need the "extra 
performance".



From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Mon Mar 15 21:56:02 2004

Subject: [PLUG] Athlon-64 Laptops

Message-ID: <16470.38625.129695.202861@bebop.local>

I'm running dual-opteron 240's in a (currently) 32-bit debian
install, and it is extremely zippy.  (2.4.18 kernel compile in 1:06).

While I haven't played with the laptops, and the AMD-64's have less
I/O than the opterons, I would still reccomend them over a p4 or
p4m.  I wouldn't expect to run a 64-bit environment without a great
deal of work though.  

Looking at the Gentoo-64 technotes/forums may be a good thing to do,
since many of the issues that arise there are not tied to gentoo.
(For example, lilo dosen't work with amd-64 at the moment, and grub
dosen't compile under amd-64--not a big deal, but worth knowing).

phillip writes:
 > Actually in the benchmarks that i've pounded through(all on 32 bit
 > windows).  The AMD-64 laptops give 2+hours of gaming on battery,
 > and 3-3.5 hours doing standard things such as web browsing and
 > simple tasks, and dvd playing somewhere in-between. On windows the
 > Athlon-64 underclocks to 800mhz(although

Just a side note about AMD-64 performance.. the amd-64 chips are a
great example of frequency (mhz) as a meaningless measurement.  The
1.4ghz opteron is _much_ faster than the 1.4 ghz Athlon MP, even in
32-bit environments.

 > doesn't affect performance as expected) from 2ghz when on battery saver mode,

WAP's are not OS specific, if you have a card with drivers that work, it
should communicate with any WAP that uses the same protocol. 
Wellenreiter and my Zaurus loaded with OPIE have hooked up to many
different AP's, it is truly amazing how many open AP's are out there.

HTH,

Derek Loree

The only AP that I have not been able to configure from linux was an
Apple Airport, but that was because it was setup to only communicate
with the Apple-talk protocol.  I have not come across an AP that
requires Active-X or that proprietary browser from Redmond, and the IP
protocol is used as the default by everyone but Apple (and that may have
changed as well).

I must also add that my favorite AP's are just computers running linux,
Gibraltar (http://www.gibraltar.at) being my live-CD distribution of
choice at this time.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Mar 16 18:26:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue Mar 16 18:26:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Font problem: Slackware-9.1
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403161818170.26852@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  On my notebook with Slackware-9.1, xpdf would not display many files. It
was looking for fonts in a directory where they weren't located:
/usr/share/fonts/default/Type1. The fonts it sought were in
/usr/share/ghostscript/Type1, so we made a symlink from the former to the
latter. That was good for xpdf: it displayed documents without error
messages. However, ...

  Now I cannot invoke X. When I watched the system boot just now I saw that
the attempt to update the X font indexes (by running
/usr/X11R6/bin/fc-cache) failed; fc-cache seg faulted. Same thing happens
when I try to run fc-cache from a console.

  A google search indicates this happens with some freetype fonts or Hershey
fonts. None of this was a problem with Slackware-8.1 or 9.0 on my other
notebook and it's not a problem with xpdf on my Red Hat systems.

  I'd greatly appreciate some suggestions on how to get fc-cache to run and
update while still being able to use xpdf to view all documents.

TIA,

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Mar 17 08:48:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed Mar 17 08:48:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Font problem: Slackware-9.1
In-Reply-To: <20040317040845.GA28305@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403161818170.26852@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <20040317040845.GA28305@brian.brianandkellyderr.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403170839320.28843@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 16 Mar 2004, Brian Derr wrote:

> All this from a simple symlink?  Is the symlink
> /usr/share/ghostscript/Type1 -> /usr/share/fonts/default/Type1 or vice
> versa?

Brian,

  Believe it or not ... yes! I just did some futzing and here's what I've
discovered.

  The fonts that xpdf requires for many documents are located in
/usr/share/ghostscript/fonts/, but xpdf is looking in
/usr/share/fonts/default/Type1/ for them. So, we made a link from
/usr/share/fonts/default/ that pointed Type1 to
/usr/share/ghostscript/fonts/. X won't load because fc-cache seg faults on
boot. If the system is booted with this configuration, xfce won't complete
loading because the panel crashes.

  If I remove the symlink and run /usr/X11R6/bin/fc-cache, X will come up
just fine, but xpdf won't properly display several files I'm using for
tests.

  Next, I copied all the fonts from /usr/share/ghostscript/fonts/ to
/usr/share/fonts/default/Type1/ after making the last directory. Same
problem as with a symlink: X won't load. Or, at least when booted, xfce
won't load because the panel crashes. Remove all those fonts and X loads
just fine.

  This is something I've not seen in the years I've run linux. I'd be
pulling out my hair over this but there's not enough hair left to pull. If
you -- or anyone -- can help me figure out why I must choose between running
X or being able to display _all_ pdf files, I'd greatly appreciate the
solution.

Thanks,

Rich

-- 
Dr. Richard B. Shepard, President
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc. (TM)
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>

Hi,

I work for a computer training group at Portland Community College.  We
offer general computer courses, certification tracks in Cisco, Oracle,
and Microsoft, as well as courses in OSS. Our URL is
http://www.computers.pcc.edu  

We are revising our offerings and I would like to get feedback from the
open source and Linux community.  We are also looking for people
interested in teaching.

My overall question is what courses would the OSS community like to see.
Some ideas are below but we welcome your thoughts.

Applications - mysql, php, ???

Apache - would people want a short course (a day or less) on
installation and configuration or more advanced topics (if so, which
ones?)

Programming - are there particular stand-alone programming languages
(Python for example) that people want or would programming be more
useful in the context of use in industry, for example J2EE and Web
services.

Small Office/Home Office - is there a need for a course on Linux and OSS
to get a small business up quickly (or encourage a shift from MS).  What
should be included?

Is Linux certification desirable?  Is there anyone with a Linux
certification who has found it worthwhile?

default-lease-time 720;
max-lease-time 86400;
option subnet-mask 255.255.255.0;
option broadcast-address 10.0.1.255;
option routers 10.0.1.4;
option domain-name-servers 206.26.36.34,  198.107.0.14 ;
ddns-update-style ad-hoc;
host apollo {
     hardware ethernet  00:07:95:B0:19:76;
     fixed-address 10.0.1.19;
}
subnet 10.0.1.0 netmask 255.255.255.0 {
    range 10.0.1.21 10.0.1.40;
}

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Mar 17 10:50:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed Mar 17 10:50:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dhcp
In-Reply-To: <1079548163.25426.6.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1079546431.25426.3.camel@apollo.spears.org> 
 <1079546874.28106.289.camel@dell.linux.box> <1079548163.25426.6.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0403171033370.12437@pecos.madboa.com>

On Wed, 17 Mar 2004, Bill Spears wrote:

> default-lease-time 720;
> max-lease-time 86400;
> option subnet-mask 255.255.255.0;
> option broadcast-address 10.0.1.255;
> option routers 10.0.1.4;
> option domain-name-servers 206.26.36.34,  198.107.0.14 ;
> ddns-update-style ad-hoc;
> host apollo {
>      hardware ethernet  00:07:95:B0:19:76;
>      fixed-address 10.0.1.19;
> }
> subnet 10.0.1.0 netmask 255.255.255.0 {
>     range 10.0.1.21 10.0.1.40;
> }

I think you'll want to wrap most of those options in the subnet
declaration and most your host declaration into a group. Plus, I'd
bump up the default lease time on hosts that get static addresses:

# global stuff
ddns-update-style ad-hoc;

# local subnet
subnet 10.0.1.0 netmask 255.255.255.0 {
  option domain-name-servers 206.26.36.34, 198.107.0.14;
  option broadcast-address 10.0.1.255;
  option subnet-mask 255.255.255.0;
  option routers 10.0.1.4;
  # declared hosts get longer leases
  pool {
    default-lease-time 21600;
    max-lease-time 43200;
    deny unknown clients;
  }
  # unknown hosts get shorter leases
  pool {
    default-lease-time 360;
    max-lease-time 720;
    range 10.0.1.21 10.0.1.40;
    allow unknown clients;
  }
}

# known hosts
group {
  host apollo {
     hardware ethernet  00:07:95:B0:19:76;
     fixed-address 10.0.1.19;
  }
}



>
> --
> Bill Spears <bspears at easystreet.com>

On Wed, 2004-03-17 at 10:49, Bill Spears wrote:
> OK, when I used static   addresses instead of dhcp, a simple /etc/hosts
> file let me move about my giant network.  How does this work with dhcp?
> I hope this  doesn't mean I have to run DNS.

How giant is that network?

The way I handled moving over from a network of static IPs to DHCP is...
assigning the static IPs via DHCP, assigned by MAC address.  :-)

I think, however, you'd find running bind with a local zone would be
worthwhile.  It isn't difficult to set up and gives you a little bit
more flexibility... no messing around with 50 /etc/hosts files.  You
make a change in one place and it is changed everywhere.

There's another way to handle this... the ddns stuff... I haven't gotten
in to that yet, although I hope to shortly.  Perhaps I'll try that stuff
out during spring break.  :-)

Rob




From sean at fork.com  Wed Mar 17 11:07:02 2004
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Wed Mar 17 11:07:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] dhcp and /etc/hosts

You should set up DNS anyway.  It's not hard and it will help you grow.

You can assign static host names to all the DHCP IP's and that can be
done as one line in a DNS file

or you can allow your user's to update a dns server with their
hostnames.


Sean

> chose a subrange of 10.0.1.21 10.0.1.40, but one client came up as

Something must be misconfigured, or you have another DHCP server running
on the network.  My guess is the later, because a fresh DHCP server will
almost always dish out addresses sequentially.

More info would be needed if you are positive that that is the only DHCP
server on the network.

Is the firewall configured to prevent traffic on port 80 _originating_
from the firewall to go out?

i.e.

traffic on port 80 originating from firewall == not okay

Mar 17 12:06:22 server sendmail[19557]: i2HK6LfR019557:
ruleset=check_rcpt, arg1=,

be forged), reject=550 5.7.1 ... Relaying denied. IP name possibly
forged [www.xxx.yyy.zzz]

when a LAN user sends mail. Sending mail from the server itself goes

Keith

> This looks like DNS isn't setup properly for your LAN. How do you
> manage name lookups internally (e.g., /etc/hosts, DNS)?

The server is running bind, so the server itself is the DNS
server. LAN clients are resolving Internet sites itself.

Reading on the sendmail site I get:

"Here the (may be forged) is the important part: it means that the DNS
data for the host is inconsistent, and hence the name is not used for
the relaying check but only the IP number. So this is the same
situation as before. If the host name would be used, it would be
simple to circumvent basic anti-relaying checks because the PTR
records might be under the control of an attacker, so he can chose any
name he wants for his IP address. That is, he can select a name for
which you allow relaying because that name is one that you control
(your domain name). However, the forward (A) lookup will fail or give
at least a different IP address, hence the name is marked as (may be
forged)."

>From the server and externally I can dig gw.domain.com,
mail.domain.com, and domain.com and they all point back to the correct
public IP address.


thanks,
Keith

From ehem at m5p.com  Wed Mar 17 19:01:01 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Wed Mar 17 19:01:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] "New Horizons" Scam
Message-ID: <200403180259.i2I2xTFl020220@m5p.com>

People involved with PLUG may be aware of more incidents with "New
Horizons". Pretty much they're a high-tech training company, enticing
people to pay based on the suposed shortage of high-tech jobs. We of
course notice there is only a shortage if you're trying to bring people
into the country, the reality is quite different.

At the moment there is a search for people who have encountered them to
help with the volume of complaints. If know anyone knows people who have
used their services, please pass this along:

-----8<-----------------------------------------------------------8<-----
Back in August of 2003, we succeeded at changing an advertisement found in the Sunday Oregonian for New Horizons Computer Learning Center in Beaverton.  The paper describing the problem is still on our website at:

http://www.ortech.org/newhoriz.html

Unfortunately, this is not the end of the story.  Some New Horizons students have contacted me regarding this article and have shared their personal experiences as students at New Horizons.  Unfortunately, they have not been satisfied with their experiences and are now facing the realities of our current economy and profession.  I will not go into the details of their experiences as this is really their story to tell and not mine.  

To date, a total of 8 ORTech members have been involved in the original as well as an on going investigation of New Horizons.  In general, New Horizons sells the idea of a shortage of IT workers in an attempt to sign up unemployed, underemployed, and desperate Oregonians into a 6-8 month program costing $17,635.  The bait used to lure students is the promise of high paying careers just waiting at the end of their program.  Over the next few weeks, there will be more details regarding the current situation and it is appalling to say the least.  

I have sent complaints to the Oregon Department of Education regarding New Horizon?s business practices.  After a number of conversations with them and with the Oregon Department of Justice, it turns out that the state of Oregon does not investigate so much based upon the quality of evidence presented, but rather on the quantity of people complaining.  

If anyone has been to a presentation at New Horizons in Beaverton or has any other experiences they would be willing to share, the students need your help.  Even a short email note to the Dept. of Education would be of great help at this point.  As always, feel free to pass on this email to anyone you think might also have an experience worth sharing.  Be sure to send a copy of anything you write to info at ortech.org for our records.  

Send your email comments regarding New Horizons to:  

ray.lindley at state.or.us

Or if you prefer snail mail:  

Raymond E. Lindley
Oregon Dept. of Education
Public Service Building
255 Capitol St.  N.E.
Salem, OR  97310
-----8<-----------------------------------------------------------8<-----

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Wed Mar 17 19:01:13 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
