Subject: [PLUG] Time format conversions....
Message-ID: <1079578805.4983.8.camel@dell.linux.box>

I set up an InfoBot on an IRC channel I'm op in... and wish to use his
logs to provide HTML-ized logs of the channel.  I already have pisc
(something like that, anyway) generating neato-toledo stats.

HTML-izing the logs won't be too difficult, except I'd like to keep the
timestamps... they're currently of the 1079578515 type format, which I
understand is the number of seconds since 01011970 00:00.

I can use perl or bash and any standard utilities on the system... I
have bits of a python script that does this conversion, among many many
other things.  I haven't had much luck ripping it out yet, though... and
would rather avoid python for this (the box in question is a 32MB RAM
UML, I want as little as possible on the box).. but if need be, I can do
python...

Anybody have any thoughts on how to accomplish this conversion?  I think
date -d might be the solution, but how to use that isn't very well
documented (unzipping the code now)...

Rob




From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Wed Mar 17 19:16:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed Mar 17 19:16:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Time format conversions....
In-Reply-To: <1079578805.4983.8.camel@dell.linux.box>
References: <1079578805.4983.8.camel@dell.linux.box>
Message-ID: <1079579716.4975.11.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Wed, 2004-03-17 at 19:00, AthlonRob wrote:

> HTML-izing the logs won't be too difficult, except I'd like to keep the
> timestamps... they're currently of the 1079578515 type format, which I
> understand is the number of seconds since 01011970 00:00.

Well, after looking for a few hours and finally giving up on finding a
solution myself, a friend IM'd me after discovering a lot more
information on the GNU date utility.

rob at dell rob $ date -d '1970-01-01 UTC 1079578994 seconds' +"%Y-%m-%d %T %z"
2004-03-17 19:03:14 -0800

...works like a charm.  :-)

Rob

#####################
#!/usr/bin/python
#
# Quick script to convert a UNIX timestamp to a
# human-readable date string.
#
# $Id: unix2date,v 1.1 2003/01/28 23:00:12 wcooley Exp $
                                                                                
import sys, time
                                                                                
mytime = int(sys.argv[1])
                                                                                
print time.strftime("%a, %d %b %Y %H:%M:%S +0000", time.gmtime(mytime))
#####################

I think you can also do it in a Perl on-liner.  Doing a single-format
conversion in C would be pretty easy too.

Wil

From ian at znark.com  Wed Mar 17 19:58:01 2004
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Wed Mar 17 19:58:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] .fonts.cache-1 question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403171655110.29686@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403171655110.29686@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <40591E14.9020205@znark.com>

Rich Shepard wrote:
>   What controls the contents of ~/.fonts.cache-1? I'm wondering if that is
> where the xpdf problem I'm having with Slackware-9.1 originates.
> 
>   If I have fonts in /usr/share/ghostscript/fonts/ that xpdf uses for some
> files, can I add that path to /etc/XF86Config?
> 

~/.fonts-cache-1 and the fonts.cache-1 files in /usr/share/fonts are 
produced by the fc-cache utilities for fontconfig.  fontconfig is for 
client-side fonts; I don't think xpdf uses fontconfig so that likely 
isn't the problem.  But having fc-cache crash when running X is not a 
good thing.

On Fedora, xpdf requires the Type1 fonts in urw-fonts.  These are in 
/usr/share/fonts/defaults/Type1.  It sounds like they are in 
/usr/share/ghostscript/fonts for you.

Are you using xfs?  Or fonts directly from XFree86?  With xfs, add the 
path to /etc/X11/fs/config.  Otherwise add it to XF86Config; I forgot 
the syntax.  Also, you need to run mkfontdir to rebuild the fonts.dir 
files.  On Fedora, /etc/init.d/xfs script does this automatically.  It 
should be "mkfontdir /usr/share/ghostscript/fonts".

  - Ian

-- 
ian at znark.com
http://www.znark.com/

I've also been looking, though probably won't buy until sometime this 
summer.  The current models from E-Machines (M6805, M6807) are 
apparently oem models from a company called Arima (sp?).  There is a 
website around somewhere talking about running Linux on these systems. 
I don't have the exact url at the moment, but it's relatively easy to 
find using google.  The summary seems to be it's another "mostly" 
working situation, with problems getting acpi support exactly right, and 
one device needs a driver that's only available in binary.

Another Athlon-64 laptop is the one from Hypersonic 
(www.hypersonic-pc.com).  This one looks like it's intended more as a 
desktop replacement notebook.  There are more speed options; more 
configuration options, etc.  You can order it without paying the Windows 
tax (e.g. they can ship it to you with only a formatted hard disk 
installed).  You can also have the case painted in many different 
colors.  It's a bit more expensive than the E-machines system; probably 
between 2000-2500 depending on configuration.

I've heard that Alienware also has an Athlon-64 notebook; I haven't 
checked that yet.

From gilmanhunt at comcast.net  Thu Mar 18 09:16:02 2004
From: gilmanhunt at comcast.net (gilmanhunt at comcast.net)
Date: Thu Mar 18 09:16:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] "New Horizons" Scam 
Message-ID: <031820041714.21556.1546@comcast.net>

I'm not sure I'd call this a "scam." However, I would place it on the "PLUG-TALK" list. 

It's my humble opinion that a lot of training places (not just New Horizons) have under-qualified instructors.  I'm recently employed (in a shop in Vancouver) after being unemployed for four months and that free pizza was sounding awful tempting. I was actually more interested in the LapTop training courses- I liked the idea of getting an "extra" laptop. 

My only previous association with NH was giving them money a few years ago to take my MCSE tests (yes yes whatever. drool over there please). But I've worked with another place like NH (affiliated with a state instution of higher learning) and I have to admit- some of the teachers were great, some were not-so-great. 

Something I've learned over the years; the most important thing about taking a class is how you approach it yourself. If you have a good teacher but you don't apply yourself in a learning frame of mind, you're not going to get it. If you have a mediocre teacher, she/he will keep you more or less on track as you learn. If you have an underqualified teacher- at least you've got the time spent going to the classes and learning in a group. The group would be the second most important thing about learning. Followed by the teacher.

I wouldn't classify "New Horizons" as a scam- or their selling methods that way either, unless you also go after IT Tech, Laptop Training and any other "school" that's going to charge you (a lot of money) to train you for a position that may or may not exist- and if you believe their salespeople (who just want butts in chairs) without doing your own research on job availability... you're at fault too.

Russ
(who, after rambling for four paragraphs, realizes just why he generally lurks)

I guess the main question is: What is the updates URL for my

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Mar 18 09:58:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu Mar 18 09:58:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Redhat Psyche updates
In-Reply-To: <20040318174325.GC13326@ahapala.net>
References: <20040318174325.GC13326@ahapala.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0403180948460.18540@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Thu, 18 Mar 2004, Keith Nasman wrote:

> Is RedHat still providing updates for 8.0? Is Fedora providing
> updates for 8.0 or are Fedora updates only for Core 1 and newer?
>
> I guess the main question is: What is the updates URL for my
> situation?

1. download yum:

   http://linux.duke.edu/projects/yum/download/1.0/yum-1.0.3-1_80.noarch.rpm

   You'll also need to install the librpm404 and rpm404-python
   packages if they aren't already on the system(s) in question.

2. concoct a decent yum.conf, e.g.,

[main]
cachedir=/var/cache/yum
debuglevel=2
logfile=/var/log/yum.log
pkgpolicy=newest

[base]
name=Red Hat Linux $releasever base
baseurl=http://download.fedoralegacy.org/redhat/$releasever/os/$basearch

[updates]
name=Red Hat Linux $releasever updates
baseurl=http://download.fedoralegacy.org/redhat/$releasever/updates/$basearch

[legacy-utils]
name=Fedora Legacy utilities for Red Hat Linux $releasever
baseurl=http://download.fedoralegacy.org/redhat/$releasever/legacy-utils/$basearch

3. as root, grab the current header set and look for updates (may take
   a couple minutes):

   yum check-update

4. do needed updates:

   yum update

5. put a cron job in place that does periodic reporting; at work, I
   put this script in /etc/cron.weekly:

#!/bin/bash
#
# yum.cron -- weekly report on what packages need to be updated
#
# $Id: yum.cron,v 1.2 2004/02/02 22:48:48 heinlein Exp $
#
YUM="/usr/bin/yum"
echo "####################################################"
echo "#"
echo "# Yum update report: $(/bin/hostname)"
echo "#"
echo "####################################################"
echo
if test -x "$YUM"; then
  $YUM check-update
else
  echo "$YUM is apparently unavailable."
fi
unset -v YUM
#
# eof
#

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From miken at hotsushi.com  Thu Mar 18 12:03:02 2004

Hi,

It looks like the Linux network administration class will finally have
enough students to be held Spring term at PCC (Sylvania campus in room
SS103).  It is part of a sequence designed to prepare students for an
entry-level position as a system administrator of a network utilizing the
Linux network operating system. Networking, TCP/IP, DNS, DHCP, NFS, Apache,
Postfix, Samba and a bit of network security are covered.  Text is TCP/IP
Network Administration, 3rd ed. by Craig Hunt:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/tcp3/.  We cover most of what's in the book
plus some.

Prerequisite: CIS 240L or knowledge of computer concepts, *nix file and
directory system, common command line utilities, basic shell scripts,
installation,  configuration and basic administration of a stand alone
Linux box.

Class meets Tuesday evening from 6 to 8:50 starting March 30 for ten weeks.
 Send me questions, register online (www.pcc.edu, CIS279L) or just come to
the first class and we'll work you in.

Thanks,
Mike

From cstevens at gencom.us  Thu Mar 18 13:12:02 2004
From: cstevens at gencom.us (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu Mar 18 13:12:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Courier/Postfix relay after authenticating?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403181351320.30658-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403181351320.30658-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>

On Thu, 2004-03-18 at 12:54, Matt Alexander wrote:
> Does anyone have an easy solution for allowing remote users to relay mail
> through a mail server after they've been authenticated by the IMAP server?
> 

I have a client who travels a lot. Unfortunately, there's no way to know
in advance what network he's coming from so I check the sender's
address. This way, if the sender originates from my_networks or they
have a sender address of client at client.com then we relay the mail.

Yes, I know that a spammer could "hijack" this address and use the
server to spam through it. I watch the server closely and it really
hasn't been a problem. If someone tried that, I'd know about it almost
immediately.

In /etc/postfix/main.cf:

smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
    permit_mynetworks
    check_sender_access hash:/etc/postfix/sender_access
    reject_unauth_destination

In /etc/postfix/sender_access:

userone at yourdomain.com	OK
usertwo at yourdomain.com	OK
....
lastuser at yourdomain.com	OK

Note: be sure to "postmap /etc/postfix/sender_access" to has the file.

I hope this helps!


-Coop

Date: Thu Mar 18 13:18:02 2004

	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403181351320.30658-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <1079644664.25553.1.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Thu, 2004-03-18 at 12:54, Matt Alexander wrote:
> Does anyone have an easy solution for allowing remote users to relay mail
> through a mail server after they've been authenticated by the IMAP server?
> 
> The few solutions I've discovered so far require rebuilding the software,
> etc.  It'd be nice if there's a simple way to add this feature to my
> Postfix/Courier-IMAP setup.

There's DRAC, but I don't know if it works with Courier and in any case
it's something of a hack.  Almost all MTAs now support SMTP AUTH, which
isn't too hard to set up with Postfix, once you work out file permission
problems (which can be nil if using saslauthd).

Wil

From srau at rauhaus.org  Thu Mar 18 14:35:03 2004
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Thu Mar 18 14:35:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Perl strategies for parsing multi-line configs
Message-ID: <20040318223453.GB5353@rauhaus.org>

I often have to compile information from things like Cisco configs, and
I'm hoping for some suggestions to deal with this in a more elegant
fashion than my normal mess of "if (/^interface/) { ...blah...; }".

Here is part of a typical config:

interface FastEthernet0/16
!
interface FastEthernet0/17
 description cubicle x
!
interface FastEthernet0/18
 description Company CEO laptop
 duplex full
 speed 100
 switchport access vlan 152
!
interface FastEthernet0/19
 description Crappy Server
 switchport access vlan 51
!
interface FastEthernet0/20
!

So each interface is the basic unit I'm working with, but there are a
variable number of items that follow each interface.

If I want to make a list of, for instance, interface, vlan, and
description, is there a cleaner way to do it rather than testing for
'/^interface/' and setting $description to empty and $vlan to 1 (the
default) each time I hit a new interface line?

What I would really like to get are generalized strategies for reading
multi-line, variable-length text records.

Thanks,
--Stafford

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Mar 18 16:32:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu Mar 18 16:32:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Courier/Postfix relay after authenticating?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403181351320.30658-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403181351320.30658-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403181623170.28958@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 18 Mar 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:
> Does anyone have an easy solution for allowing remote users to relay
> mail through a mail server after they've been authenticated by the IMAP
> server?
>
> The few solutions I've discovered so far require rebuilding the
> software, etc.  It'd be nice if there's a simple way to add this feature
> to my Postfix/Courier-IMAP setup.

So, does your postfix not have SASL support?

I believe all you need to do is put this crud in your
/etc/postfix/main.cf:

smtpd_sasl_auth_enable = yes
broken_sasl_clients = yes
smtpd_sasl_security_options = noanonymous

smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
<whatever your real stuff is, plus>
                                permit_sasl_authenticated

smtpd_sender_restrictions    = check_sender_access <some lookup method,
mysql, pgsql, hash, whatever>

Then you need to create something like /etc/postfix/sasl/smtpd.conf:
pwcheck_method: PAM <or whatever method you like>

And then create a PAM thingie for smtpd in /etc/pam.d/smtpd:
auth	requisite	pam_modulename.so options
account	required	pam_modulename.so options

I think that's all I had to do...

J.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Mar 18 16:41:01 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu Mar 18 16:41:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Courier/Postfix relay after authenticating?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403181623170.28958@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403181351320.30658-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403181623170.28958@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1079656793.25553.23.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Thu, 2004-03-18 at 16:31, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> Then you need to create something like /etc/postfix/sasl/smtpd.conf:
> pwcheck_method: PAM <or whatever method you like>

Actually, you want to use 'saslauthd' here, and run 'saslauthd' with PAM
authentication.  Before Cyrus-SASL 1.5.27, you had to dance carefully
around permissions to do PAM authentication because Postfix, Cyrus IMAP,
OpenLDAP, etc drop priviledges and can't automatically read /etc/shadow.

> And then create a PAM thingie for smtpd in /etc/pam.d/smtpd:

The PAM auth name is smtpd, even if you use saslauthd.  (Actually, I
think it's just 'smtp'.)

Wil

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Mar 18 17:57:01 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu Mar 18 17:57:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] .fonts.cache-1 question
In-Reply-To: <40591E14.9020205@znark.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403171655110.29686@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <40591E14.9020205@znark.com>

On Wed, 17 Mar 2004, Ian Burrell wrote:

> ~/.fonts-cache-1 and the fonts.cache-1 files in /usr/share/fonts are
> produced by the fc-cache utilities for fontconfig.  fontconfig is for
> client-side fonts; I don't think xpdf uses fontconfig so that likely isn't
> the problem.  But having fc-cache crash when running X is not a good
> thing.

Ian,

  It crashes only if 1) there's a symlink from the directory in which xpdf
is looking for the fonts and the directory where those fonts are actually
located or 2) I copy the fonts from the latter directory to the former
directory.

> On Fedora, xpdf requires the Type1 fonts in urw-fonts.  These are in
> /usr/share/fonts/defaults/Type1.  It sounds like they are in
> /usr/share/ghostscript/fonts for you.

  On Slackware-9.1 there was no ../fonts/defaults/Type1 in /usr/share. We
added the /fonts/default directory then used Type1 as a symlink to
/usr/share/ghostscript/fonts.

> Are you using xfs?  Or fonts directly from XFree86?  With xfs, add the
> path to /etc/X11/fs/config.  Otherwise add it to XF86Config; I forgot the
> syntax.  Also, you need to run mkfontdir to rebuild the fonts.dir files.
> On Fedora, /etc/init.d/xfs script does this automatically.  It should be
> "mkfontdir /usr/share/ghostscript/fonts".

  There is no xfs running as a process. However, there is /usr/X11R6/bin/xfs
which can be started from within rc.local using the '-daemon' option. I just
added /usr/share/ghostscript/fonts/ to /etc/X11/fs/config, ran 'mkfontdir',
killed X and restarted it. No change.

  What next? This is a real puzzler to me and the folks on aols haven't been
any help.

Thanks,

Rich

From cstevens at gencom.us  Thu Mar 18 21:54:02 2004
From: cstevens at gencom.us (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu Mar 18 21:54:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Courier/Postfix relay after authenticating?
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403181351320.30658-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403181623170.28958@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <405A897D.73BDEACB@gencom.us>

Jeme and Matt,

I think your solution, Jeme is more secure than mine. I hope to post a
summary.


-Cooper

Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> On Thu, 18 Mar 2004, Matt Alexander wrote:
> > Does anyone have an easy solution for allowing remote users to relay
> > mail through a mail server after they've been authenticated by the IMAP
> > server?
> >
> > The few solutions I've discovered so far require rebuilding the
> > software, etc.  It'd be nice if there's a simple way to add this feature
> > to my Postfix/Courier-IMAP setup.
>
> So, does your postfix not have SASL support?
>
> I believe all you need to do is put this crud in your
> /etc/postfix/main.cf:
>
> smtpd_sasl_auth_enable = yes
> broken_sasl_clients = yes
> smtpd_sasl_security_options = noanonymous
>
> smtpd_recipient_restrictions =
> <whatever your real stuff is, plus>
>                                 permit_sasl_authenticated
>
> smtpd_sender_restrictions    = check_sender_access <some lookup method,
> mysql, pgsql, hash, whatever>
>
> Then you need to create something like /etc/postfix/sasl/smtpd.conf:
> pwcheck_method: PAM <or whatever method you like>
>
> And then create a PAM thingie for smtpd in /etc/pam.d/smtpd:
> auth    requisite       pam_modulename.so options
> account required        pam_modulename.so options
>
> I think that's all I had to do...
>
> J.
> --
>    -----------------
>      Jeme A Brelin
>     jeme at brelin.net
>    -----------------
>  [cc] counter-copyright
>  http://www.openlaw.org

On Thu, 18 Mar 2004, Wil Cooley wrote:
> On Thu, 2004-03-18 at 16:31, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
>
> > Then you need to create something like /etc/postfix/sasl/smtpd.conf:
> > pwcheck_method: PAM <or whatever method you like>
>
> Actually, you want to use 'saslauthd' here, and run 'saslauthd' with PAM
> authentication.  Before Cyrus-SASL 1.5.27, you had to dance carefully
> around permissions to do PAM authentication because Postfix, Cyrus IMAP,
> OpenLDAP, etc drop priviledges and can't automatically read /etc/shadow.

Err... yeah, that's what I'm doing.  'Cept it ain't saslauthd, it's
courier's authdaemon (which is redundantly named authdaemond).

> > And then create a PAM thingie for smtpd in /etc/pam.d/smtpd:
>
> The PAM auth name is smtpd, even if you use saslauthd.  (Actually, I
> think it's just 'smtp'.)

Err... right:
jbrelin at loyale:~$ ls -l /etc/pam.d/smtp
-rw-r--r--    1 root     root          366 Nov 10 01:23 /etc/pam.d/smtp

Most of that was off of the top of my head.  Certainly not intended as a
"how-to" so much as a "good startin' place".

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Mar 19 08:39:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Mar 19 08:39:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] For-What-It's-Worth Department
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403190820330.5587@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  I just discovered a difference between Red Hat and Slackware that may be
useful to others here. Or, I may be the last person in the world to discover
this. Regardless, ...

  To convert from DOSs cr/lf to UNIX/linux's lf, Red Hat has the utility
called 'dos2unix' (and it's twin, 'unix2dos'). These are not found on my
Slackware system. But, thanks to the good folks at google (who are looking
to hire, by the way), I found the reason. The equivalent tools in Slackware
are called 'fromdos' and 'todos'.

  I wonder what else I'll find to step in on the conversion path.

Rich

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Fri Mar 19 09:01:02 2004
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Fri Mar 19 09:01:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Perl strategies for parsing multi-line configs
In-Reply-To: <20040318223453.GB5353@rauhaus.org>
References: <20040318223453.GB5353@rauhaus.org>
Message-ID: <20040319165944.GC539@dalsemi.com>

On Thu, Mar 18, 2004 at 02:34:54PM -0800, Stafford A. Rau wrote:
> I often have to compile information from things like Cisco configs, and
> I'm hoping for some suggestions to deal with this in a more elegant
> fashion than my normal mess of "if (/^interface/) { ...blah...; }".
> 
> Here is part of a typical config:
> 
> interface FastEthernet0/16
> !
> interface FastEthernet0/17
>  description cubicle x
> !
> interface FastEthernet0/18
>  description Company CEO laptop
>  duplex full
>  speed 100
>  switchport access vlan 152
> !
> interface FastEthernet0/19
>  description Crappy Server
>  switchport access vlan 51
> !
> interface FastEthernet0/20
> !
> 
> So each interface is the basic unit I'm working with, but there are a
> variable number of items that follow each interface.
> 
> If I want to make a list of, for instance, interface, vlan, and
> description, is there a cleaner way to do it rather than testing for
> '/^interface/' and setting $description to empty and $vlan to 1 (the
> default) each time I hit a new interface line?
> 
> What I would really like to get are generalized strategies for reading
> multi-line, variable-length text records.

The previous reply is right, look into Parse::RecDescent.  But
for this particular case, there is a very good, very simple
core Perl solution:

Each record is delimited by \n!\n.
Each element appears to be line delimited (\n)

So this should work:

#!/usr/bin/perl -w

use strict;

$/ = "\n!\n"; ##Input line delimiter set to record delimiter

while (<>) {
  my @fields = split "\n";
}

Now it's up to you to parse each element.

Colin

On Thu, 2004-03-18 at 12:00, Mike Neal wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> It looks like the Linux network administration class will finally have
> enough students to be held Spring term at PCC (Sylvania campus in room
> SS103).  It is part of a sequence designed to prepare students for an
> entry-level position as a system administrator of a network utilizing the
> Linux network operating system. Networking, TCP/IP, DNS, DHCP, NFS, Apache,
> Postfix, Samba and a bit of network security are covered.  Text is TCP/IP
> Network Administration, 3rd ed. by Craig Hunt:
> http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/tcp3/.  We cover most of what's in the book
> plus some.
> 
> Prerequisite: CIS 240L or knowledge of computer concepts, *nix file and
> directory system, common command line utilities, basic shell scripts,
> installation,  configuration and basic administration of a stand alone
> Linux box.
> 
> Class meets Tuesday evening from 6 to 8:50 starting March 30 for ten weeks.
>  Send me questions, register online (www.pcc.edu, CIS279L) or just come to
> the first class and we'll work you in.
> 
> Thanks,
> Mike

Hi,

It's about $250 plus the text, $30 from bookpool.  Plus you may want to
setup a lab at home, a linux box and another box with TCP/IP, two NICs and
a crossover cable.  You can use the lab at PCC but there is a special kind
of knowledge you get at 2 in the morning when you beat up a problem with
the assistance of loud music and peperoni pizza.

Cheers,
Mike

From drl at drloree.com  Fri Mar 19 21:26:01 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Fri Mar 19 21:26:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Configuration Snafu? System still deteriorating.
In-Reply-To: <200403191147.22155.guy1656@ados.com>
References: <200403171234.03450.guy1656@ados.com> <87ekrqel2l.fsf@ursine.ca>
	 <200403191147.22155.guy1656@ados.com>
Message-ID: <1079760325.767.15.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Fri, 2004-03-19 at 13:03, GLL wrote:
> > OK:
> > 
> > I have two Linux boxes. One is a gateway machine w/firewall, the other is a 
> > job-use machine which sits behind the firewall.
> > 
> > Now, when I fire up a browser on the job machine and point it to
> > www.ados.com,  all appears well. BUT, when I use the same browser
> > from the GATEWAY machine and point it to www.ados.com, I get
> > "No web site is configured at this address."
> 
> Derek Loree:
> Do both machines return the same IP address for that website?
> 
> On Wed, 17 Mar 2004, D. Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> > Is the firewall configured to prevent traffic on port 80 
> > _originating_ from the firewall to go out?
> 
> On Wednesday 17 March 2004 22:16, Paul Johnson wrote:
> :
> : DNS issues?
> 
> 
> First of all thank all of you for putting in some time with these suggestions.
> The problem at the gateway machine went away. I am a field engineer (PE in 
> mech eng,) but not a network admin - I know how to 'ping' but that's about 
> all the tools I can apply to the problem.
> 
> The only difference is that when I ping my ISP (ados.com) from the gateway 
> machine, I get : "Destination host unreachable."

Does the ping return an IP address, before the "Destination host
unreachable"?  Most firewalls these days will drop ping packets, because
they can be used for denial of service attacks.  A program called
tcptraceroute is much more useful, and most firewalls will allow traffic
from it.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

http://server.riverdale.k12.or.us/~danh/  and you might want to check out

Unix class, CS140U and a Linux Installation and Configuration class, CIS240L.

On Fri, Mar 19, 2004 at 08:37:39AM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   To convert from DOSs cr/lf to UNIX/linux's lf, Red Hat has the utility
> called 'dos2unix' (and it's twin, 'unix2dos'). These are not found on my
> Slackware system. But, thanks to the good folks at google (who are looking
> to hire, by the way), I found the reason. The equivalent tools in Slackware
> are called 'fromdos' and 'todos'.

Yowsers, I've been using slack for about five years and never noticed
the `todos' and `fromdos' commands!  I did however have `dos2unix' on my
box because I needed it and grabbed the source and compiled it.  Now
that I know about the two that come with slackware I can just toss
`dos2unix'.  Thanks Rich!

Brian

Subject: [PLUG] Cups Printing Problem
Message-ID: <1079794253.6203.12.camel@apollo.spears.org>

I have cups installed and running on three computers, all running
Fedora1. An hp1200 is installed on computer P and it works. Up until
recently it also worked across a network on computers L and O.  The only
thing I changed was the net work IP addresses and I now use dhcp. Yes,
they can ping each other.

P is set up to broadcast its printer and L and O show it in their admin
(http://localhost:631).
1 When L or O try to print a test page, a job is created locally but not
on P.
2. On L, lp works about like admin, it appears to create a  job, by
returning a request id, and nothing happens on P.
3. On O, lp says that no default destination available.
-- 
Bill Spears <bspears at easystreet.com>

Check permissions on P.  I think if I remember right be default, Cups

Then restart cups.

From laynerm at comcast.net  Sat Mar 20 22:35:03 2004
From: laynerm at comcast.net (Mike's Comcast Acct)
Date: Sat Mar 20 22:35:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Thanks for the help.
Message-ID: <405D3764.5020908@comcast.net>

I posted a plea on Friday, March 19, 2004 for info on where I could find 
some help getting my very first Linux installation to function.

Rich Shepard, Jeme Brelin, Mike Neal and Galen Seitz responded with 
blinding speed, telling me to turn up at the monthly clinic at Riverdale 
on 3/20/2004 at 1:00 p.m. and to bring my box, distro and problems.

Much to the amazement of Jeme, Russell and several other wonderful and 
incredibly generous guys, I did so.  I suspect that someone lost a bet 
on whether the guy with the stupid question would actually turn up the 
next day.   Lost bets notwithstanding, I received an incredible amount 
of help for which I am extremely grateful.

If you are a lurker or other newbie, don't be afraid to bring your 
computer down and join the fun.  These folks are nice, knowledgable and 
very helpful.  Next time I'll know to bring diet Coke or donuts, or 
something to fuel the crew.

Seriously, I'm reasonably competent in my own field and frequently 
volunteer my time to help new or otherwise inexperienced folks out.  I'm 
frequently rewarded immediately by learning something new and often 
rewarded later by a nice reference or referral.  All that said, I really 
appreciate the effort by Russell, Jeme, John, and all the other folks 
who were so welcoming and helpful.

I promise that if I ever learn anything, I'll be ready to give back as well.

Thanks again,

Mike Layne
Portland, Oregon

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun Mar 21 00:38:02 2004

Subject: [PLUG] sendmail/postfix config to save copies of sent mail

On Sat, 20 Mar 2004, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> I'm looking for a way to keep copies of mail I send through my own mail
> server. It's running RH8 postfix and sendmail.

Postfix AND sendmail?!?  That's... unusual.

In fact, I think there would be some definite stomping of toes with that
combination unless you're doing something really interesting and know
exactly what you're doing.

But anyway, are you just hoping to keep copies of the mail you send out
yourself or copies of other people's mail going out through your server?
If it's just your mail, I would think that you'd just want to set the FCC
in whatever MUA you're using (or use tee if you're sending it directly to
port 25 or using mailx or something otherwise strange).  If it's other
people's mail that's passing through your mail server, well, I don't think
I'd like to participate in getting that to work.

J.

On Sat, 20 Mar 2004, Mike De La Mater wrote:

> I'm looking for a way to keep copies of mail I send through my own mail
> server. It's running RH8 postfix and sendmail.
>
> Am I missing something basic here?

Mike,

  I suspect you are: your MUA. Whatever you use to write your outgoing
e-mail then passes it to the smtp tool (postfix). It's up to the MUA to save
that message.

  Pine and sylpheed certainly do, and those are the only two in use here.
I'm certain that they all do this.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sun Mar 21 10:55:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sun Mar 21 10:55:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] sendmail/postfix config to save copies of sent mail
In-Reply-To: <1079854918.4581.9.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
References: <1079854918.4581.9.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>
Message-ID: <1079895278.4362.211.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Sat, 2004-03-20 at 23:41, Mike De La Mater wrote:
> I'm looking for a way to keep copies of mail I send through my own mail
> server. It's running RH8 postfix and sendmail.
> 
> I've tried tweaking postfix, but it does not appear to have anything to
> do with outgoing mail. Google tells me to build a special version of
> sendmail and then compile it, something I'm not interested in.
> 
> Am I missing something basic here?

Postfix 1.x and later has 'always_bcc', which will send a copy of every
message to a particular address.  Later versions of 2.x (possibly only
in the snapshot) have more fine-grained controls.

Wil

No, I doubt it.  FAT filesystems are considerably simpler than NTFS
filesystems, so it seems unlikely.  OTOH, there might be a tool in the
ntfs-utils for Linux, but I don't know.  However, I seem to recall that
2k/XP also have a disk administration tool than can resize filesystems.

Quote:

  Marcelo Tosatti followed up his release announcement with another
  email highlighting security fixes in 2.4.25 and 2.6.3 [story]. He
  explains, "2.4.25 contains several security related fixes, including a
  fix for another sys_mremap vulnerability. Upgrade to 2.4.25 for those
  who use mainline kernels is recommended. [...] For those using 2.6,
  upgrade to 2.6.3 is recommended." Linus Torvalds added, "please
  upgrade if you allow local shell access to untrusted users."

So, make sure your distribution has at least back-ported fixes.

From ed at alcpress.com  Sun Mar 21 11:30:02 2004
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Sun Mar 21 11:30:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Does FIPS work with Windows XP Pro?
In-Reply-To: <405DE8F7.2040707@comcast.net>
References: <1079891260.9975.5.camel@apollo.spears.org> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403211006260.17538@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <405DE8F7.2040707@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <405DED09.1070002@alcpress.com>

Mike's Comcast Acct wrote:
> Having experienced the fun of hauling a tower system to the Linux clinic 
> at Riverdale H.S., I want to non destructively re-partition the hard 
> drive on my old Toshiba Satellite 2545XCDT and make it a dual boot 
> system with Debian on the new partition.
> 
> I've read about fips and downloaded all the info from the Redhat distro 
> so I'm about ready to pull the trigger however I have this nagging 
> question that I haven't been able to answer thus far.
> 
> Will fips work with Win XP Pro with the NTFS file system?

fips is seldom useful when the partition you're trying to
shrink is a Windows partition of any type, including FAT.
Windows sets many of its disk blocks as "unmovable" and
fips cannot move these unmovable blocks. The disk defragger
program supplied with Windows also cannot move these blocks.

This means that the most space you can recover is from the
end of the partition to the unmovable block closest to the
end of the partition. In most cases this will not be enough
space to install Linux.

Partition Magic is the typical solution.

Ed

  I can confirm that fips will NOT work on NTFS. When I installed SuSE
9.0 Personal on this system, it took considerable effort to get it where
I wanted. I have a 60GB hd, so it seemed reasonable to slice off 20 or
so for Linux. The tool that came with my distribution worked to some
degree, but was quite conservative, and I was left with a much smaller
Linux partition than I wanted. I finally backed up my personal stuff,
then blew away everything. I reformatted to give a third each to
windoze, Suse, and future use. I'll probably eventually put Fedora in
the remaining space. After completing the Linix installation, I restored
WinXP, providing an NTFS partition (C:), and a FAT partition (D:). So,
here is what I see from here:

mel at d8qbcf21:~> df -h
Filesystem            Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/hda7              19G  5.4G   14G  29% /
/dev/hda5              16M  4.3M   11M  30% /boot
/dev/hda2              16G  5.8G  9.3G  39% /windows/C
/dev/hda3             2.1G  1.4G  698M  66% /windows/D
tmpfs                 125M     0  125M   0% /dev/shm
mel at d8qbcf21:~>


It's worked out nice so far.

On Sun, 21 Mar 2004, Mike's Comcast Acct wrote:
> Well, I'm now the proud owner of Partition Magic 8.0, now a Symantec
> Product by the way, and am busily wrecking the hard drive on my laptop.

Good luck with that.

Remember the install tricks we talked about yesterday.

The 2.4 kernel boot iso is here:
<URL: http://debian.linux.org.tw/pub/boot-floppies/cvs/bootbf2.4.iso >

It's a small iso and you can put it on the tiniest CD you've got (business
cards or whatever).

When the installation process asks if you'd like to add any additional apt
sources, go ahead and say yes, then change all of the "stable" lines to
"unstable" and save the file without exiting the editor, then hop to
another virtual console (alt+F2), login with the root account, and run an
`apt-get dist-upgrade`.  I THINK that will work.  If it says the apt
system is locked, just go ahead and go back to the first console (alt+F1)
and continue the process as directed.

> Meanwhile, on the desktop model, the install is plugging along.  I go
> down sporadically and add a -f command to whatever's going on and that
> seems to make it happy for a while.

Yeah... sometimes you've got to tell it to "fix" when you've interrupted
the process (as we did about five times yesterday!).

> More anon.

Huzzah.

J.

Message-ID: <86ptb5ids3.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> Haven't used grub yet... I'm wary, but not for expressable
Jeme> reasons.

Grub rocks.  Everything is determinable at boot time rather at the
last time you had the system running (and thus could re-run lilo).
You can start any kernel you have on your filesystem dynamically.  You
also don't get the "LI..."  messages.

LILO essentially "pre-cooks" your booting options.  When you run lilo
after modifying /etc/lilo.conf, you are writing a list of data block
addresses of your kernels, etc, to the second stage of the boot
loader.

Grub's second stage knows about various file systems and can read the
configuration files, kernels, initrd's etc at boot time.  If you screw
up booting from the harddisk somehow, you can build a simple Grub boot
floppy by dd'ing a couple of generic files onto the floppy and then
use any of the kernels already safely on the harddisk.  Much more
flexible.

For a nice explanation of how boot loaders work, see:

  <http://www.xs4all.nl/~lennartb/bootloaders/>

Grub does have some peculiarities, such as zero-based disk and
partition numbering, e.g. the first partition of the first disk is
called (hd0,0) in grub parlance.  This takes a little extra toll on
them arithmetic processing unit up there in the grey cells, but on
balance it seems worth the price.

I don't have _any_ LILO boxes anymore.  Grub is worth learning.

Not that I have an opinion or anything. ;-)

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

  I should have noted that the real problem with resizing the windoze
partition, wasn't because of the Linux tools. It has to do with
defragging in preparation. In theory, this is supposed to push all files
to the "front" of the disk, making all free space contiguous at the
"end" of the disk. You then carve your Linux partition from the free
space. I found that with WinXP, there were always some "unmovable" files
near the end of the disk.

  Mel

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Mon Mar 22 11:38:01 2004

Subject: [PLUG] Perl - Passing my script's arguments to another program
Message-ID: <1079984393.3841.10.camel@timmy>

I want my script to take any number of files as arguments, then pass
them off to a separate program for processing, and capture the output in
either a file or a variable. This would be easy, but the filenames may
have any number of weird or strange characters in them, including
spaces.

I have tried this:

open (TMP, '>', "/tmp/file");
select (TMP);
system ("command", @ARGV);

That sucessfully runs "command", but does not put the output in
/tmp/file.

There is no switch for the command to output to a file.

How can I do this?

Evan Heidtmann






From bhoran at hexdev.com  Mon Mar 22 12:37:01 2004
From: bhoran at hexdev.com (Brian Horan)
Date: Mon Mar 22 12:37:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Perl - Passing my script's arguments to another program
In-Reply-To: <1079984393.3841.10.camel@timmy>
References: <1079984393.3841.10.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <1079987764.16666.22.camel@catdog>

system() spawns a subshell.
you could have your script do the following

$outfile = 'Foo.out'
$command = "uname -a > $filename"
system($command);

as a side note, try to stay away from system() if you can.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Mar 22 13:18:01 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Mar 22 13:18:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Perl - Passing my script's arguments to another program
In-Reply-To: <1079989817.3845.19.camel@timmy>
References: <1079984393.3841.10.camel@timmy>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403221239510.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
	 <1079989817.3845.19.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <1079990232.4975.195.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Mon, 2004-03-22 at 13:10, Evan Heidtmann wrote:

> But even this breaks when the filenames passed to the bash script
> contain spaces.

Escape the spaces... or better yet, don't use filenames with spaces in
them.  :-)

Either use quotes or \'s:

rob at dell rob $ touch "a file with spaces in its name"
rob at dell rob $ ls *spaces*
a file with spaces in its name
rob at dell rob $ cat a\ file\ with\ spaces\ in\ its\ name
rob at dell rob $ cat "a file with spaces in its name"

Either way, the thing should all be passed as ARGV[1] to
perl/c/c++/whatever, or $1 in bash.  Since spaces are what seperates out
the ARGV's, if you don't escape them it assumes you meant to have
separate arguments.

Rob

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Mon Mar 22 14:06:02 2004
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon Mar 22 14:06:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Perl - Passing my script's arguments to another program
In-Reply-To: <1079989817.3845.19.camel@timmy>
References: <1079984393.3841.10.camel@timmy> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403221239510.13321@shaft.bitmine.net> <1079989817.3845.19.camel@timmy>
Message-ID: <20040322220601.GA2267@bavariati.org>

On Mon, Mar 22, 2004 at 01:10:17PM -0800, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> 
> So now my question is broader: How do I pass args to a command of this
> form:
>   command $ARGS > filename
> in any language?

command "$@" > filename

>From the BASH manpage (no RTFM implied, it's really, really long.)
@   Expands to the positional parameters, starting from  one.
    When the  expansion  occurs  within  double  quotes, each parameter
    expands to a separate word.  That is, "$@" is equivalent to "$1"
    "$2" ...   When there are no positional parameters, "$@" and $@
    expand to nothing (i.e., they are removed).





From cstevens at gencom.us  Mon Mar 22 14:08:02 2004

Hi All,

Every once in awhile, something really great comes along that just
perfectly fits the bill.

That was the case this morning with the 'mboxfull' script authored by
Dave Regan at Armored Penguin.

A little background: I sent an email recently asking if anyone had a
script that would monitor a user's Inbox and warn them if it were
getting too full. I had actually included a script that may be modified
to suit my needs and offered a $25.00 bounty for the first one to
produce a "production quality" product.

The next day, Dave sent an email that quoted as follows:

"There are a number of ugly things about the program you found such that
it will be easier to start fresh rather than modify it..."

Shocking for some, an inspiration for others; note what Doug McIlroy,
the inventor of Unix pipes and one of the founders of the Unix
tradition's words:

  "Make each program do one thing well. To do a new job, build afresh
rather than complicate old programs by adding new features."

Dave was right. 

Dave's mbox monitoring program was nothing short of spectacular. The
script was well thought out, cleanly documented, and indented
perfectly.  You'll see what I mean when you click through to his script
here:

  http://www.armoredpenguin.com/mboxfull/

In the first sentence of Dave's script site he writes, "mboxfull is a
trivial little program, without any runtime, to send email to users
whose email box is nearly full." If only he could see how happy his
script has made my client!

Oh, and the booty? Dave had this to say:

  "If you send me a check, I'll only spend it.  Instead, send it to
Pamela Jones at Groklaw."

A man of great character. Thank you, Dave.


Best,

On Mon, 22 Mar 2004, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
> On Mon, 2004-03-22 at 12:41, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> > This may turn out to be one of those utterly pointless and frustrating
> > responses we see on this list sometimes, but I have to ask.

> Not the case. Thanks for asking.

Yeah, this isn't a particulary perly task.  It'd probably faster to just
run it in a shell.

> I do know that, in bash, $* is the arguments passed to the script. So I
> tried this (the exernal program is metacam, my script is script.pl):
>
> #!/bin/bash
>
> metacam -ax $* > /tmp/metacam-tmp.xml
>
> script.pl /tmp/metacam-tmp.xml
>
> Then script.pl will read the file $ARGV[0] for further processing.
>
> But even this breaks when the filenames passed to the bash script
> contain spaces.
>
> So now my question is broader: How do I pass args to a command of this
> form:
>
> command $ARGS > filename
>
> in any language?

Here's a quickie bash way of doing it:

for file in "$@"; do
    command "$file" >output_from_"$file";
done

Dig that?  You quote the variable instances so that the literal characters
in the variables are used instead of splitting on the spaces or what have
you.

Season to taste.

J.

On Mar 22, 2004, at 2:06 PM, Michael C. Robinson wrote:

>
> For $1000 or less new, this is looking like the way to go.
>
>
>
One thing to keep in mind with a low end machine like this. It is very 
heavy in my opinion. My wife has an 1100 and I certainly wouldn't want 
to lug that around all day, compared to my ibook, it is just plain 
unwieldy. The graphics that come with it are also fairly anemic. I 
would upgrade to the separate graphics card if you can afford it. The 
onboard Intel card shares memory with the system, so plan for that. I 
personally think you are going to have a hard time keeping that system 
at under 1000 if you add anything that a student would most likely want 
like a cd burner and wi-fi card. The card dell sells isn't that great. 
I think you can get a better deal at best buy.
	As far as a software rebate, you do get disks, but they are not 
official application disks. I would be highly surprised if you are able 
to get any sort of discount or rebate on those.
	I know you are into linux, but you should really consider an ibook as 
well. These are highly usable and well under the 1000 mark with 
educational pricing. You can run PPC linux quite well if you want, but 
i think if you tried OS X you would be really surprised. It is a very 
friendly environment for a Unix hacker and with fink, you can get 
almost all of your favorite Open Source apps. Also, I have compiled 
several things from source and since you get gcc, its fairly 
straightforward. Just a though and an alternate view from someone who 
is doing what you hope to do in the future.

Doug

Dell stuff comes with installation media, but the preinstalled software
is configured in such a way that you just can't boot the thing (or even
get into the bios setup) without first agreeing to the Windows license
agreement, which makes you the sole user of the software whence you are
contractually bound to not resell the stuff and you can't trade it in as
unused.

Neat, huh?

Well, I talked to Dell and I have to say that at least they are
diplomatic unlike that gal at IBM.  They don't carry a Linux laptop
product line anymore, which is frankly disturbing.  A couple of places
have gone broke, so it doesn't look like anyone knows how to do it.

I would like to see some new laws after this ordeal.

    1) No diagonostic tool sold with an OEM computer shall depend 
       on a proprietary operating system to function unless these 
       tools only make sense for troubleshooting that system.  
       A customer that rejects the license for the installed OS 
       shall be offered a refund for it and any other charged 
       for software that depends on the presence of that system
       to function.  The refund offer must cover the full amount
       charged for this software or the best estimate possible
       must be offered.

    2) No computer manufacturer may be charged a tax on each 
       computer manufactured for a software product(s) 
       regardless of whether or not a customer wants 
       that product or a vendor installs the product.

    Violators of these above two proprosed laws should owe
a free laptop for each violation :-)

IBM has been advertising Linux, why on earth did I get an
angry and nasty woman when I called and asked for a Linux
Thinkpad?  Dell at least said, "let's try to find you a Linux
specialist."  A+ for effort Dell.  I signed up for a temporary
account and they did suggest the 300M and 500M models when
I told them 7 lbs is a bit much to carry.  Unfortunately,
I don't know that a Pentium M covers a Pentium III or better
requirement where it's $1500 for their 3 lb laptop, the 300M.  
The Dell Inspiron 5100 should take Linux okay.  If I had a 
digital version of each of the books I carry, the 7.22 lbs 
problem wouldn't be such an issue.  The battery indicator 
evidently won't work under Linux, so I should probably buy 
a second battery and run it the way they did with the old 
Volkswagons before fuel gauges were introduced.  I'm not 
settled on it yet, but it's nice to know that someone at 
Dell appreciates the guy that wants to run Linux ;-)

OEM's have right and I hope some day that these rights
can be protected so that consumers can ask for what 
they want without fear of Microsoft or any other
Goliath retaliating.

On Mon, 22 Mar 2004, Bill Spears wrote:

> I came across these links to commentaries by Eric Raymond about his
> similar experience with CUPS in which he says that we will have to make
> software much more discoverable and transparent if we want it to be widely
> used.

  It's too bad that it takes someone of ESR's stature to get a positive
response from folks like those at Easy Software. I went through the same
nonsense a few years ago. But, I discovered that configuring CUPS through
the command line interface didn't work; I _had_ to use the BUI to do the
job.

  This is, unfortunately, another validation of why developers should never
write documentation. They cannot see the software from the naive users'
perspective. In the late 80s I wrote a database program and asked a friend
at work to give it a usability test for me. He crashed it almost
immediately! I was watching at the time and asked him why he did what he
did. He shrugged and said it seemed like a fun thing to try. Well, with
Fred's help I blocked all the possible wrong things a user could do that
didn't even occur to me. It was a very good lesson, though.

Rich

Yeah, worst case, you'll have to restore from backup.

> Admittedly, it was over three years ago now, but when I a Compaq

> Remember, the worst you can do is destroy Windows.  Where's the big

Heh.

Also, I found that GNU PartEd would do a nice job of moving the data on
a FAT32 partition out of the way.  

This was particularly useful when I was setting up a new IBM laptop that
had WinXP preinstalled.  There was a FAT32 partition that'd boot,
configure Windows and then convert itself to NTFS.  So I caught it when
it rebooted to do the NTFS conversion and used PartEd to shrink it down
and make room for a Linux install.

NTFS ain't a bad filesystem.  It's a shame M$ seems to use it mainly to
shut out other OSes rather than, say, enhance the security of PCs.

Actually, you can get ffmpeg packages in binary form if you put this in
your sources.list:

deb http://marillat.free.fr/ unstable main

You might want to also include the Rarewares resources for some of the
other video/audio utilities:

deb http://pessoal.onda.com.br/rjamorim/debian/ ./
deb http://www.rarewares.org/debian/packages/unstable ./

I use them and they work[1] handily for multimedia!

On Mon, Mar 22, 2004 at 02:06:01PM -0800, Aaron Burt wrote:
> command "$@" > filename
>
> >From the BASH manpage (no RTFM implied, it's really, really long.)
> @   Expands to the positional parameters, starting from  one.
>     When the  expansion  occurs  within  double  quotes, each parameter
>     expands to a separate word.  That is, "$@" is equivalent to "$1"
>     "$2" ...   When there are no positional parameters, "$@" and $@
>     expand to nothing (i.e., they are removed).

Thanks! In the meantime I had cobbled together a perl regex to escape the
funny characters, but I knew that was a kludge. Now it's much better: a
wrapper bash script first calls metacam and then my script.

Thanks again,

From drl at drloree.com  Tue Mar 23 08:21:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Tue Mar 23 08:21:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Best source for pre-configured Linux Boxen?
In-Reply-To: <20040323022020.GA27501@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Mon, 2004-03-22 at 18:20, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> I have a San Jose client that will be jumping into Linux with both
> feet (Yay!).  They want to buy about a dozen preconfigured Linux boxes.
> Unfortunately, to be compatable with the expensive CAD software they
> will be buying, they will probably be running Redhat 7.2 on most of
> them (Boo!).  Given the driver-sensitivity of some of the older distros,
> they will need some pretty lemonade boxes with no need for fancy drivers.
> They will also want screaming speed.  What's a hacker to do?
> 
> They would rather buy pre-configured boxes from IBM, HP, Dell, or Sun,
> even if they are 2X-3X cost.  They don't want to spend a lot of time
> fiddling with BrandX boxes, and they want hardware support.

Seems like you could put together white boxes, and for less than 2x-3x,
send them extras.  If a machine goes down, they will have extras already
on site, loaded and ready to go.  

The best thing that you can do for speed is fast hard drives, either
SCSI spinning at 15,000 RPM, or SATA spinning at 10,000 RPM (like the
Western Digital Raptor).  Dual Channel DDR is nice, but in my
experience, the hard drive is the biggest bottle neck.  I just built a
machine using the ASUS P4P800-DELUXE that could run the SATA drives in
"legacy" mode, making them appear to the OS as regular IDE drives.  I
was pressed for time, so I wasn't able to try loading linux on it, but
I've never seen 2k run so fast.

I also have had to do less repair on the white boxes that I build
compared to the branded boxes that my clients bought.

Just some food for thought,

Derek Loree





From linux at chrisroberts.org  Tue Mar 23 08:22:02 2004
From: linux at chrisroberts.org (chris)
Date: Tue Mar 23 08:22:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] CUPS, Commentary on Crappy UI
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403221851420.22045@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <1080006886.10924.161.camel@apollo.spears.org> <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403221851420.22045@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200403230830.21390.linux@chrisroberts.org>

on the whole "developers debugging their own program" topic. it is not 
possible for a developer to debug their own program well. for that matter, it 
is not possible for a developer to do a very good job debugging a program 
they know well. this has nothing to do with the intellegence of the 
developer. it has to do with the fact that the developer knows what the 
program is supposed to do, and how to make it do the things that it is 
supposed to do. since they are predisposed to this information, doing the 
things that the system aren't able to handle never come into perspective 
because knowing how the system works, there would be no reason to do that, 
since it should do nothing. 

i guess the point is, i just wanted to back up Rich in saying that you always 
want a third party to test and try and break your application. and finding a 
regular user as opposed to a fellow developer is a plus as they will be more 
likely to do the random things that are likely to cause problems.

chris

From zot at whiteknighthackers.com  Tue Mar 23 08:47:02 2004
From: zot at whiteknighthackers.com (Zot O'Connor)
Date: Tue Mar 23 08:47:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Making just a module under a redhat kernel
Message-ID: <1080060378.26721.20.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I have to look this up every 6 weeks it seems so I thought I would post
it.  The issue is how to create just *one* module for a pre-built redhat
kernel (say for wireless, ntfs, alsa, etc).

The pattern follow.  It create the kernel tree, dependcies, paths, and
include files.  You can include "MODULES=ntfs" to make just one module.



cd /usr/src/linux-2.4
edit Makefile, remove "Custom" from EXTRAVERSION
make mrproper
make distclean
cp config
make xconfig ->save
make dep
make modules


--

Good point, the biggest problem in this regard, these days, is the
built-in video that shares system RAM and use the main processor for
most of the GPU operations (the Intel on-board video is an example of
this).  These make anything displaying more than a text console very
slow.  

Most 4x AGP cards should be quite fast at rendering 2D, and fast 3D is
not very expensive any more.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Mar 23 15:51:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Mar 23 15:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] grub question
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403231545230.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>

OK, so after Russell's ringing endorsement, I installed grub on a box at
work.  Havoc ensued.

So, whatever I did, the system was unbootable for a while.  I eventually
figured out how to make it bootable and even wrote a barely functional
/boot/grub/menu.lst to boot the thing.

Seems OK, but not perfect.  Here's the sitch and the concerns:
/dev/hda1 is /boot, ext2.
/dev/hda2 is /, reiser.

Debian creates symlinks for the current version of the kernel and initrd
image in / (/vmlinuz and /initrd.img, respectively).

I want a grub menu item that will default to the current kernel image and
associated initrd, but the symlinks span filesystems.

What's a boy to do?

If I simply create symlinks in /boot, will I have to do this with each
kernel upgrade or will Debian do the right thing automatically?

Does everyone that uses grub with Debian just manually update the menu.lst
every time they update their kernel?

J.

From dzl at frenetic.com  Tue Mar 23 16:06:02 2004
From: dzl at frenetic.com (Daniel Logghe)
Date: Tue Mar 23 16:06:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] grub question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403231545230.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> Does everyone that uses grub with Debian just manually update the menu.lst
> every time they update their kernel?

Well, if you use the "update-grub" script it will create a menu.1st file 
for you (well, it will regenerate a portion of it, but leave your 
changes) with all the kernels you have installed, and the latest at the 
top (and therefore the default), this is the most useful most of the time.



From dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us  Tue Mar 23 16:11:01 2004
From: dan_young at parkrose.k12.or.us (Dan Young)
Date: Tue Mar 23 16:11:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] grub question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403231545230.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403231545230.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1080086956.6773.16.camel@dan.parkrose.k12.or.us>

On Tue, 2004-03-23 at 15:50, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> Does everyone that uses grub with Debian just manually update the menu.lst
> every time they update their kernel?

In /etc/kernel-img.conf:

postinst_hook = /sbin/update-grub
postrm_hook = /sbin/update-grub
do_bootloader = no
do_initrd = Yes

-Dan Young
-Parkrose School District




From seniorr at aracnet.com  Tue Mar 23 16:32:01 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Tue Mar 23 16:32:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] grub question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403231545230.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403231545230.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <863c7zm6fo.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> Does everyone that uses grub with Debian just manually update
Jeme> the menu.lst every time they update their kernel?

I don't know about "everyone", but as for me, basically, yes.  

  make oldconfig ; make ; su -c 'make install ; make modules_install ; vi /boot/grub/menu.lst'

Also, I don't have a separate /boot partition, which makes grub work a
little nicer.  The separate /boot partition requires (when I saw this
~6 months ago at a PLUG clinic) a small kludge.  See the GRUB docs or
FAQ for your choice of kludge.

My menu.lst files look like:

   default	saved
   timeout	5

   title	Linux 2.4.25
   root	(hd0,0)
   kernel	/boot/vmlinuz-2.4.25 root=/dev/sda1
   savedefault

   title	Linux 2.4.22
   root	(hd0,0)
   kernel	/boot/vmlinuz-2.4.22 root=/dev/sda1
   savedefault

   title	Linux 2.4.20
   root	(hd0,0)
   kernel	/boot/vmlinuz-2.4.20 root=/dev/sda1
   savedefault

The "savedefault" does the obvious thing, it makes the corresponding
index the default on the next boot, presumably by stashing the value
on disk somewhere.

You could probably hack /sbin/installkernel to modify menu.lst if you
wanted to avoid the manual editting.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

Subject: [PLUG] Multiple C library versions OK?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403231415050.5677@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403231415050.5677@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040324012459.GA28938@bavariati.org>

On Tue, Mar 23, 2004 at 02:17:49PM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I know that I can have different versions of various libraries on the
> system at the same time (e.g., gtk+, python). Can I also have multiple
> copies of gcc on my system?
> 
>   Red Hat 7.3 comes with gcc-2.96. An application I want to build and
> install requires the 3.x series, preferable 3.2.x. Could I do an install and
> have the compiler versions coexist -- happily?

I've done it, on RedHat I think.  What happens is that the gcc binary is
installed as gcc-[version] and 'gcc' is a symlink to the version you're
using.  Change the symlink to change the version of GCC.

I think some makefiles can be told which version to use, too.

Good luck,
  Aaron

References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403231545230.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <20040324075743.GA13815@edge>

On Tue, Mar 23, 2004 at 03:50:10PM -0800, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> OK, so after Russell's ringing endorsement, I installed grub on a box at
> work.  Havoc ensued.
> 
> So, whatever I did, the system was unbootable for a while.  I eventually
> figured out how to make it bootable and even wrote a barely functional
> /boot/grub/menu.lst to boot the thing.
> 
> Seems OK, but not perfect.  Here's the sitch and the concerns:
> /dev/hda1 is /boot, ext2.
> /dev/hda2 is /, reiser.
> 
> Debian creates symlinks for the current version of the kernel and initrd
> image in / (/vmlinuz and /initrd.img, respectively).
> 

It seems wrong that your kernel is not in /boot. I mean what else is /boot for?
One solution would be to  put the kernel and initrd in /boot, put the symlinks 
there also and grub  will have no trouble with the symlinks. 
The other possibility is to skip using /boot and point grub to / instead.

Bill Barry




From dzl at frenetic.com  Wed Mar 24 03:13:01 2004
From: dzl at frenetic.com (Daniel Logghe)
Date: Wed Mar 24 03:13:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] grub question
In-Reply-To: <20040324075743.GA13815@edge>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403231545230.13321@shaft.bitmine.net> <20040324075743.GA13815@edge>
Message-ID: <40616D1D.5060204@frenetic.com>

Bill Barry wrote:

> It seems wrong that your kernel is not in /boot. I mean what else is /boot for?
> One solution would be to  put the kernel and initrd in /boot, put the symlinks 
> there also and grub  will have no trouble with the symlinks. 
> The other possibility is to skip using /boot and point grub to / instead.

The kernel is in /boot, there are just automatically installed symlinks 
that reside in /. This is old and pretty standard behavior, useful for 
lilo, but not so useful for Grub, at least if you have a seperate boot 
partition.

Mike;
I did basically this, last fall- and I can tell ya that Home Depot has the stuff you need. They have ethernet cable, snap-together jacks that come with the worlds worst working punchdown tool (and semi-coherent instructions), and a patch panel (I overspent and bought the one that will do cable tv and phone, but they allegedly have just the patch panel). 
Once I figured out that the patch panel was not equal to a hub, I was golden.

On a wall in my basement is mounted the comcast cable modem, the hub, the patch panel and cables out to my work area in the basement and the living room.

My wife still ruminates about the holes in the walls, but they're mostly scabbed over now, and we're not going to talk about me drilling UP from the basement through the hard wood floor to get the ethernet cable up to the living room.

IMHO the hardest part was the wall-stuff. We have plaster and lathe and it's hard to patch a big hole so that it looks semi-normal. I was content to run the ethernet cable around the top of the ceiling in the basement.

boring version of Linux that is rock-solidly stable and slow to mutate,
supports Apache 1.3 and Perl 5.6, is widely used by the clueful and has

for security updates, and installs reliably and straightforwardly on
very standard hardware.

missing some low-hanging fruit (like, "nobody uses the standard ISOs
since they have no drivers on them, just buy a CD set from XYZ Corp with

From sean at fork.com  Wed Mar 24 09:38:02 2004
From: sean at fork.com (Sean Whitney)
Date: Wed Mar 24 09:38:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Is Debian that hard to work with, or am I that dumb?
In-Reply-To: <4060B605.CAA77F9F@tercent.net>
References: <4060B605.CAA77F9F@tercent.net>
Message-ID: <1080149825.2785.43.camel@einstein.seansdomain.org>

> These last two times were with a Compaq ProLiant server and a Dell
> Dimension -- both extremely ubiquitous units, one old and venerable and
> one new and up-to-date.  However, both times, I had to play all kinds of
> games with kernel recompilation just to get the NIC working, and I never
> did get XFree86 up.
> 
> What I want more than anything for production machines in future is a
> boring version of Linux that is rock-solidly stable and slow to mutate,
> supports Apache 1.3 and Perl 5.6, is widely used by the clueful and has
> good documentation on how to secure it, has an automated update system
> for security updates, and installs reliably and straightforwardly on
> very standard hardware.
> 
I have had similar difficulties with Debian in the past.  Specifically 
with a Compaq DL-380.  The current (at that time) Debian installation
didn't recognize the HW Raid disk partitions or the NIC card.  I asked
my team to give me some time to fix the problem and they agreed.

After much teeth nashing I found a website (which I can't find right now)
that explained how to install your own custom kernel on the debian 
installation disk.  I built a custom kernel, which I do on all my 
computers (production or not) which supported the Compaq array and the
NIC card and proceeded with the installation.  I think I had to go to 
another terminal at one point to run one command manually.

Ok, so that doesn't sound like it was worth it.  However, that same server
has been up for over 3 years now.  The kernel has been patched twice, and 
all the software has been kept up to date with apt-get.  The server has 
reboot twice in three years for kernel upgrades, less than 5 minutes each
time.  That is my book puts that server at over 5x9's of availability.

Red Hat has had three new OS versions so far.  Reinstalling the latest OS 
or running a very old OS isn't an option that I would want to support.  
All the time I see people running RH6.0 (for example) and wondering how 
to get the newest ssh installed on it.

I guess my point is spend the time up front getting it to work right the 
first time and you will spend less time supporting it in the end.

One final note: Try the Debian BF2.4 installation disks they have a pretty
good selection of equipment support

ftp://ftp.debian.org/debian/dists/woody/main/disks-i386/current/images-1.44/bf2.4/

Sean

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Mar 24 09:44:02 2004

Subject: [PLUG] PDF display problems in xpdf: Solved
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403240940190.26284@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  For the record, at last weekend's clinic we discovered the source of my
inability to display certain pdf files using xpdf on my notebook. The
incorrect font paths were in ~/.xpdfrc. Because I had never needed to do
anything with either a global or local rc file for xpdf I didn't even know
that one existed.

  Editing the font paths in that file made all the difference. Another day,
another linux lesson.

I should have mentioned that in my post.  I always use the 2.4
boot-floppies netinst cd image for stable.

You probably should replace that kernel after installing, though... either
with a debian kernel package or with your own.  (For one, there is no
generic scsi or ide-scsi on the bf2.4 kernel image, so you can't write to
an IDE CD burner with that kernel. -- Don't mistake that for no SCSI
support, though.)

Subject: [PLUG] upgrading disk without reinstalling anything
Message-ID: <200403241802.i2OI250K020913@barrierb241.nike.com>

Now that my MythTV box has been kickin' ass for more than a month, I need to boost the hard drive capacity so I can keep my son's Scooby Doo episodes and still record Survivor and MadTV. I need to replace the existing hard disk with a bigger one, rather than just add a disk. The reason I don't want to just add another disk is because the cabinet that this box is in gets a little warm, and adding another disk to the system will not help in that respect. The box will take a second disk so I can have both new and old disk in the box at once. I guess my plan is as follows:

1. Install the new 120G disk as a IDE slave
2. Boot up. Partition and format the new disk.
3. Sync the files from the old disk to the new disk, one partition at a time.
4. Install the bootloader on the new disk. (How do I do this part??)

Does this sound like the path of least resistance? If so, how do I do step 4?

Thanks,

"Outside of a dog, a book is probably man's best

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Mar 24 10:43:01 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed Mar 24 10:43:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] upgrading disk without reinstalling anything
In-Reply-To: <200403241802.i2OI250K020913@barrierb241.nike.com>
References: <200403241802.i2OI250K020913@barrierb241.nike.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403241036240.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 24 Mar 2004, Anderson, Rob (Global Trade) wrote:
> 1. Install the new 120G disk as a IDE slave
> 2. Boot up. Partition and format the new disk.
> 3. Sync the files from the old disk to the new disk, one partition at a time.
> 4. Install the bootloader on the new disk. (How do I do this part??)
>
> Does this sound like the path of least resistance?

It should work, but I would do it all in single user mode so you don't end
up with all your pidfiles and things copied across.  That could be a real
mess.

> If so, how do I do step 4?

It depends on what you're running and how you want to go about it.

One very easy way would be to just copy everything to the new disk,
install remove the old one and install the new one in the master position,
boot with a boot disk of some sort giving root=/dev/root/on/new/disk on
the command line, then run the boot loader's command to install it in the
MBR.

There are other options; many that do not require a boot disk.

In fact, I think with grub you wouldn't have to do anything but install it
in the MBR of the second disk right away.

J.

On Tue, Mar 23, 2004 at 10:09:39PM -0800, Keith Morse wrote:
> But speaking to the original topic.  One particular thing that I know LILO 
> does but have not seen with GRUB is the ability to test boot on a new 
> kernel and if that fails the subsequent reboot go back to the previous 
> kernel.

In addition to the "default" directive in menu.lst, use the "fallback"
directive.

This (and for LILO too, I believe) only helps if the physical disk
blocks fail or the kernel entry point fails. It's still difficult for
an x86 platform to figure out if an OS load fails late into the boot
process.

> > 2. Boot up. Partition and format the new disk.

> 
> It should work, but I would do it all in single user mode so 
> you don't end
> up with all your pidfiles and things copied across.  That 
> could be a real
> mess.
> 
> > If so, how do I do step 4?
> 
> It depends on what you're running and how you want to go about it.
> 
> One very easy way would be to just copy everything to the new disk,
> install remove the old one and install the new one in the 
> master position,
> boot with a boot disk of some sort giving 
> root=/dev/root/on/new/disk on
> the command line, then run the boot loader's command to 
> install it in the
> MBR.
> 
> There are other options; many that do not require a boot disk.
> 
> In fact, I think with grub you wouldn't have to do anything 
> but install it
> in the MBR of the second disk right away.

From barryb at proaxis.com  Wed Mar 24 12:07:02 2004
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Wed Mar 24 12:07:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] upgrading disk without reinstalling anything
In-Reply-To: <200403241802.i2OI250K020913@barrierb241.nike.com>
References: <200403241802.i2OI250K020913@barrierb241.nike.com>
Message-ID: <20040324200621.GA32534@edge>

On Wed, Mar 24, 2004 at 10:01:53AM -0800, Anderson, Rob (Global Trade) wrote:
> Now that my MythTV box has been kickin' ass for more than a month, I need to boost the hard drive capacity so I can keep my son's Scooby Doo episodes and still record Survivor and MadTV. I need to replace the existing hard disk with a bigger one, rather than just add a disk. The reason I don't want to just add another disk is because the cabinet that this box is in gets a little warm, and adding another disk to the system will not help in that respect. The box will take a second disk so I can have both new and old disk in the box at once. I guess my plan is as follows:
> 
> 1. Install the new 120G disk as a IDE slave
> 2. Boot up. Partition and format the new disk.
> 3. Sync the files from the old disk to the new disk, one partition at a time.
> 4. Install the bootloader on the new disk. (How do I do this part??)
> 
> Does this sound like the path of least resistance? If so, how do I do step 4?

You can do step 4 (before step 2) by copying over the mbr using dd
dd if=/dev/hda of=/dev/hdb bs=512 count=1
This copies over the partition table also, so you will have to do it before step 2
and then repartition the drive.

Bill Barry




From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Mar 24 12:13:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed Mar 24 12:13:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] upgrading disk without reinstalling anything
In-Reply-To: <20040324200621.GA32534@edge>
References: <200403241802.i2OI250K020913@barrierb241.nike.com>
	 <20040324200621.GA32534@edge>
Message-ID: <1080159123.13426.3.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Wed, 2004-03-24 at 12:06, Bill Barry wrote:

> You can do step 4 (before step 2) by copying over the mbr using dd
> dd if=/dev/hda of=/dev/hdb bs=512 count=1
> This copies over the partition table also, so you will have to do it before step 2
> and then repartition the drive.

Oh man I wouldn't do that.  I've tried using dd to copy one filesystem
to another and while it works, it's dreadfully slow.  I'd use something
like cp -a or rsync on each of the filesystems.  Plus, with the above
method, you end up creating partitions with the same sizes as before. 
And I'm not sure how it handles differing geometeries...

Wil

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Mar 24 12:22:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Wed Mar 24 12:22:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: grub question
In-Reply-To: <20040324190426.GV2782@maybe.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403231634140.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403232147260.9849-100000@mail.mpcu.com> <20040324190426.GV2782@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403241220130.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 24 Mar 2004, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> This (and for LILO too, I believe) only helps if the physical disk
> blocks fail or the kernel entry point fails. It's still difficult for an
> x86 platform to figure out if an OS load fails late into the boot
> process.

Naw... the way 'lilo -R' works is that it boots a particular image on NEXT
reboot only, so if it fails, it'll reboot and come back as the old
default.  Then, when the system comes up, you can change the default to
the new kernel if you like.

It would be nice to be able to tell grub to boot to a particular image on
next reboot only.

J.
