From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Wed Mar 24 13:13:02 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Wed Mar 24 13:13:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] upgrading disk without reinstalling anything
In-Reply-To: <200403241802.i2OI250K020913@barrierb241.nike.com>
References: <200403241802.i2OI250K020913@barrierb241.nike.com>
Message-ID: <13156-84947@sneakemail.com>

On Wed, 24 Mar 2004, Anderson, Rob (Global Trade) Rob.Anderson-at-nike.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> 1. Install the new 120G disk as a IDE slave
> 2. Boot up. Partition and format the new disk.
> 3. Sync the files from the old disk to the new disk, one partition at a time.
> 4. Install the bootloader on the new disk. (How do I do this part??)
>
> Does this sound like the path of least resistance? If so, how do I do step 4?

This sounds like a good way to do it.  In step 3 be sure to use a program
that preserves permissions and isn't stupid about things like block
devices.  Most Linux utilities do this well.  The only tricky part really
will be limiting your copies to one partition at a time or else you'll end
up copying your new drive back to itself ad infinitum.  I find the
"--one-file-system" option to cp, rsync, or tar to be especially useful.

To reinstall GRUB, refer to the manual:

http://www.gnu.org/software/grub/manual/grub.html#Installation

I'd suggest making a GRUB boot floppy and testing it before installing
GRUB in the MBR of your new drive.  This lets you back out easily if
"something" goes wrong with no risk to your current setup.  The
alternative of "grub-install" will probably work, but if it doesn't, your
system might be rendered unbootable.

Use the "native installation" method documented at:

http://www.gnu.org/software/grub/manual/html_node/Installing-GRUB-natively.html

You may want to either print this out or have it in a browser on another
PC since you'll be referring to it while your MythTV PC is down.

The process would be:
  1) Make a GRUB floppy per the instructions
  2) shut down your PC
  3) disconnect the IDE master and make your new drive the master
  4) boot from the GRUB floppy
  5) install according to the above instructions
  6) reboot your PC, GRUB should boot Fedora

If it doesn't work, you can always hook your original drive back up and
your PC will be back where it was until you have time to figure out what
went wrong.

  -- Steve



From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Mar 24 13:19:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)

  <20040324201606.GA32648@edge> <1080160546.13426.16.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
 <Pine.LNX.4.58.0403241242580.5491@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403241317290.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Wed, 24 Mar 2004, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Wed, 24 Mar 2004, Wil Cooley wrote:
>
> > > I just suggested copying over the mbr, not the whole file system,
> > > Note the count=1.
> >
> > Oh yeah, I'm an idiot.  Still, it seems more difficult and esoteric
> > to me than re-running the install command for whatever bootloader.
>
> You can also just chroot into the new disk environment and install your
> boot loader that way...

I thought of that, but then realized that you can't.

Your running kernel is going to have the drive mapping all wrong.
Remember that the drive is going to change controllers/position before the
system boots to that disk.

You don't need to chroot to install the boot loader in the MBR of the
secondary disk, though.  And that should work.

J.

  I'm running Suse 9.0, so I think it would be similar. Go into Yast,
configure the ethernet card (NIC) for dhcp. Exit Yast. The system will
broadcast a dhcp request, and the router/hub should provide a tcp/ip
address. Once done you should be connected.

Availability/Cluster Technology (?)  -MySQL  -unixODBC  -XML (why is this
right where it is?)  -Apache  -iPlanet products  -Proxy and portal products
Languages:
 -ANSI C
 -C++
 -Java
 -J2SE
 -Perl
 -Flash (rofl)
 -(Ba)sh
 -ksh
 -csh
Parallel/Distributed Systems:
 -PVM
 -OpenMP
 -SunMPI
 -MPICH
Parallel/Scheduling Systems:
 -Sun Grid Engine
 -Globus Toolkit

I must say... if I had a strong grasp on all of that, I really don't think I
would be willing to work for $75K.  Make it $120K and we could talk.  Sure,
a lot of this stuff is the kind of stuff you could pick up rather quickly
for a job, given a little bit of training... but does anybody really come
into a position meeting all this criteria?

Am I the only one who thinks these job requirements are a bit nutso?

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Wed Mar 24 18:00:02 2004
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Wed Mar 24 18:00:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] GNU Scientific Library
Message-ID: <20040325015246.29189.qmail@web9601.mail.yahoo.com>

The GNU Scientific Library is a remarkable
application. The manual that goes with it is available
as a bound volume (and I have it), and there is at
least one Internet mailing list devoted to it.

Invoking it, however, isn't quite as straightforward
as in the case of some other applications. The program
bessel.c is a "Hello World" type of program to
calculate one value of a Bessel function and display
it.

If shared libraries are used, as you can see, a
LD_LIBRARY_PATH statement must be used for every
instance of executing a binary made by the program.
Could I avoid this by including something in my
profile?

It would be nice to use a makefile to take care of the
libraries. What is a good source of information about
such files?

The answer I get is accurate to only 15 decimal
places, but this error is utterly miniscule. The "make
check" provided with this application passed in every
case. Is this degree of precision about typical for
such applications?

[rtk at dhcppc1 gsl]$ gcc -I/usr/local/include -c
bessel.c
[rtk at dhcppc1 gsl]$ gcc -L/usr/local/lib -lgsl
-lgslcblas -lm bessel.o -o bessel

[rtk at dhcppc1 gsl]$ ./bessel
./bessel: error while loading shared libraries:
libgsl.so.0: cannot open shared object file: No such
file or directory

[rtk at dhcppc1 gsl]$
LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH
./bessel

J0(5) = -1.775967713143382642e-01
 

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

From freyley at gmx.net  Wed Mar 24 19:01:02 2004
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Wed Mar 24 19:01:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Is Debian that hard to work with, or am I that dumb?
In-Reply-To: <87hdwdznqe.fsf@ursine.ca>
References: <4060B605.CAA77F9F@tercent.net>  <87hdwdznqe.fsf@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <1080183576.4824.56.camel@zadie>

On Wed, 2004-03-24 at 18:04, Paul Johnson wrote:

> > However, the last two times I went to install Debian, I gave up in
> > frustration and broke out the RedHat ISOs after a couple days of misery.
> 
> Well, there's your first mistake.

And this, not to put too fine a point on it, is what gives Debian a bad
name.

*sigh*

Debian isn't particularly easy to install. And configuring X can be a
pain in the ass. There are tools and tricks to make it easier, but if
you don't know about them, they're kinda hard to try. And debian zealots
don't make anything easier.

Just a few notes for anyone else looking to install debian:

1) lspci is your friend. A handy Knoppix cd is also your friend. With
the exception if ISA and older hardware, where you Just Have To Know It,
the two of these can report your hardware very well. Booting Knoppix,
hitting ctrl-alt-f1, and typing lsmod is extremely handy for finding out
what modules to load to get hardware working. 

2) And Knoppix's XFConfig-4 file, while slightly less bleeding-edge than
you might want optimally, works fairly well for configuring X. 
It's good, if possible, to get debian and X to work together as friends.
dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xfree86 (assuming it's installed) will attempt
to reconfigure the xserver. Read the XF86Config-4 file and you'll know
what to put in the boxes, making upgrades a tad easier.

3) apt-get only works if your sources are right. Check out
/etc/apt/sources.list and look on the web on your other computer, or
with a knoppix cd, to find usable sources.list files. Here's mine:

deb http://debian.oregonstate.edu/debian/ testing contrib non-free main
deb http://debian.oregonstate.edu/debian/ unstable contrib non-free main
deb http://ftp-mirror.internap.com/pub/debian/ testing contrib non-free
main
deb http://ftp-mirror.internap.com/pub/debian/ unstable contrib non-free
main
deb http://non-us.debian.org/debian-non-US testing/non-US contrib
non-free main
deb http://non-us.debian.org/debian-non-US unstable/non-US contrib
non-free main 

4) ignore the zealots. Debian is wonderful in some ways, and the
community can be incredibly helpful and friendly. Sadly, some people
take love of debian too far.

Jeff

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403242120480.27704@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 24 Mar 2004, Alice Corbin wrote:

> I've been sent, as a pdf file, a map that looks to be about 3' by 4'.
> Is there any way that I can break it into pieces that can be printed
> on separate pages?

Ali,

  Yes. You need the pdfpages tarball and documentation and pdfnup_0.96
(that's the latest; I got it yesterday). I tried sending these as
attachments an hour ago but the message was too large for the list. Contact
me directly for copies of the files.

  The latter requires the former and enables you to print pdf docs N-up on a
page, select certain pages to print from the whole thing and -- probably --
let you tile your large map so it can print on multiple sheets of paper.

HTH,

Rich

'ldconfig -v' afterwards, instead.

  $ clisp -q
;; Loading file /home/russell/.clisprc ...

[1]> (long-float-digits) 
64
[2]> pi
3.1415926535897932385L0
[3]> (setf (long-float-digits) 640)
640
[4]> pi
3.141592653589793238462643383279502884197169399375105820974944592307816406286208998628034825342117067982148086513282306647093844609550582231725359408128481117450284102701938521105559644622948955L0
[5]> (setf (long-float-digits) 6400)
6400
[6]> pi
3.

... and on top of it all, it is reasonably fast!

From mikedela at theplatinumrule.com  Wed Mar 24 22:05:03 2004
From: mikedela at theplatinumrule.com (Mike De La Mater)
Date: Wed Mar 24 22:05:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Recommend a Cable Puller + ??
In-Reply-To: <1080193447.19367.102.camel@griffin>
References: <1080193447.19367.102.camel@griffin>
Message-ID: <1080194694.2105.4.camel@rhws.theplatinumrule.com>

On Wed, 2004-03-24 at 21:44, Robert Munro wrote:
> But your electrical work needs to comply with safety and building codes,
> so I'd suggest getting bids from several licensed electricians for that.

According to Oregon law, both high and low voltage must be run by
licensed electrical people. The law makes no distinction. There are
allowances for do-it-yourself, and "limited remodeling" but the law
comes into full effect if you pay someone to help, IIRC.

I've pulled a lot of wire for pay and for trade, sometimes people are
willing trade just to have someone who knows what to do look over their
shoulder. You might find someone who needs your speciality that knows
cabling.

IANAL

-- 
Mike De La Mater
Small Business Networks and Computers
Your key to technology that works
mikedela at ipns.com
503-702-6749

   So here I am trying to figure out a good book to use.  My preference is 
to use the man pages and on-line resources but sometimes the students

HPUX system for that but the world is quickly becoming GNU/Linux/BSD.

box and don't encounter them very often.

What are your suggestions for a good (cheap) book to use for a UNIX Intro
class?  OS installation instructions are less of a need but usage 
(command-line), configuration, and software installation/upgrade are really 
important.

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403242120480.27704@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, Mar 24, 2004 at 09:22:46PM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Wed, 24 Mar 2004, Alice Corbin wrote:
> 
> > I've been sent, as a pdf file, a map that looks to be about 3' by 4'.
> > Is there any way that I can break it into pieces that can be printed
> > on separate pages?
> 
> Ali,
> 
>   Yes. You need the pdfpages tarball and documentation and pdfnup_0.96
> (that's the latest; I got it yesterday). I tried sending these as
> attachments an hour ago but the message was too large for the list. Contact
> me directly for copies of the files.
> 
>   The latter requires the former and enables you to print pdf docs N-up on a
> page, select certain pages to print from the whole thing and -- probably --
> let you tile your large map so it can print on multiple sheets of paper.
>

I looked at the documentation for pdfnup and found that it has the same
functionality as psnup.  It will combine multiple pages into a single
page, but it won't split a single page into multiple pages.

So I went grepping around on the internet again, and found a ps utility
called poster.  It's actually meant for blowing up a ps file and printing
it on multiple pages, but I thought that it should work for printing a
big sheet at its real size.

So I downloaded an rpm and a tarball for poster.  The rpm installed OK,
but then segfaulted when I tried to run it.  The tarball ran OK and 
produced a 16-page ps file that gs chokes on.  

So I'm back to square one.  Maybe I can use ImageMagick to split the
map into pieces.

Ali

bonobo-activation-server.

Sometimes I find multiple instances of nautilus, but killing those is

On Thu, 2004-03-25 at 11:51, Mel Andres wrote:
> I'm running Suse 9.0 Personal, XD2 environment. I have to reboot every
> once in awhile because I eventually run out of swap. I once thought that
> I had narrowed it down to cupsd, but I have found that it isn't the only
> contributer. I posted my findings to a larger group, and was told to
> just wait for the 2.6 kernel. Now, I know that Evolution has some
> processes that keep re-spawning, and if I kill those processes, I gain
> back a little of my swap space. Overall, I am fighting a losing battle.
> Is this indicative of a memory leak? There is a memory profiler in the
> development tools, but there is no documentation for it. If I increase
> my physical memory, will that resolve my problem, or just buy me more
> time?

A memory profiler is a coder's tool; it probably won't help you much. 
The easiest thing is probably to use 'top'--start it an press 'M'
(capital, lower-case).  Pay attention to the RSS column; this stands for
Resident Set Size, which is the amount of actual physical memory in
use.  For reference, here's some of my most memory-heavy processes on my
laptop with 512MB memory and the same in swap:

  PID USER     PRI  NI  SIZE  RSS SHARE STAT %CPU %MEM   TIME CPU COMMAND
 4120 root      15   0 86784  56M  8668 S     3.1 11.1 277:11   0 X
15140 wcooley   15   0 53216  51M 18236 S     0.5 10.3   3:57   0 mozilla-bin
17320 wcooley   15   0 44356  43M 16508 S     0.0  8.6   2:15   0 evolution
 4541 wcooley   16   0 17772  16M  8476 R     1.7  3.1   4:03   0 gnome-terminal
 4482 wcooley   15   0 20388  14M 13448 S     0.0  2.9   0:23   0 nautilus
 4491 wcooley   15   0 15948  14M 12164 S     0.0  2.8   1:13   0 gaim
 4480 wcooley   16   0 14144  12M  8788 S     0.1  2.4   0:40   0 gnome-panel
 4419 wcooley   15   0 22556  11M  2180 S     0.0  2.2   1:15   0 gconfd-2
17322 wcooley   15   0  8912 8912  7060 S     0.0  1.7   0:00   0 evolution-womba
 4528 wcooley   16   0  9440 8804  7164 S     0.5  1.7   1:15   0 wnck-applet
 4536 wcooley   16   0  8864 8556  7208 S     0.0  1.6   0:15   0 netspeed_applet
 4350 wcooley   15   0  9332 7444  7236 S     0.0  1.4   0:04   0 gnome-session
 4532 wcooley   16   0  7956 7392  6688 S     0.0  1.4   0:04   0 wireless-applet
 4530 wcooley   15   0  7880 7104  6524 S     0.0  1.3   0:02   0 mixer_applet2
17324 wcooley   15   0  6940 6940  5940 S     0.0  1.3   0:00   0 evolution-alarm


> Right now I have:
> 
> Two instances of evolution-alarm-notify.
> Eight instances of evolution-wombat, and eleven instances of
> bonobo-activation-server.

This are usual.  You're not actually seeing multiple instances in most
cases, you're seeing multiple threads.  2.6 and 2.4 with NTPL threading
back-ported only show one process entry for a group of threads.

> Sometimes I find multiple instances of nautilus, but killing those is
> worse than living with them. It invokes a nautilus-throbber process, and
> lots of windows of my home directory pop up. 

Don't do that.

Wil

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Mar 25 13:36:01 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu Mar 25 13:36:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Swap usage keeps increasing
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F31TgIvvSKXUil00057358@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY9-F31TgIvvSKXUil00057358@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <1080250580.17320.71.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Thu, 2004-03-25 at 13:24, Vincent Yau wrote:

> Is there any reason why the Mem usage is always almost 90% of the total 
> size?
> On some of these boxes, I don't have anything special running (other than 
> whatever
> is needed to keep the box going).  At most, I have mysqld, tomcat, apache 
> httpd
> and that is it.....

Free memory is wasted memory.  Any memory not used recently by a running
program is used by the kernel as filesystem cache or other buffers. 
Part of the black magic of VM subsystems is deciding when to free memory
used by processes in preference of filesystem cache.  It's frightfully
difficult to make the right decisions.

A small amount of memory is generally kept free to prevent memory
fragmentation, for basically the same reasons a small amount of
filesystem space is reserved to prevent filesystem fragmentation.

Wil
--

Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Mar 25 14:23:01 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu Mar 25 14:23:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Swap usage keeps increasing
In-Reply-To: <1080244287.4743.38.camel@d8qbcf21.comcast.net>
References: <1080244287.4743.38.camel@d8qbcf21.comcast.net>
Message-ID: <18895-90426@sneakemail.com>

On Thu, 25 Mar 2004, Mel Andres mel97215-at-comcast.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Is this indicative of a memory leak?

This looks like a memory leak since you say it's creeping upwards over
time.  A 768MB total virtual memory space should be adequate for what
you've mentioned.  256MB real memory is a bit low, but not completely out
of the question.

> If I increase my physical memory, will that resolve my problem, or just
> buy me more time?

I suspect this will just buy you more time.  It may be easier to simply
boost your swap space if you're not seeing any performance problems.

If you *are* seeing performance problems, then get the memory.

To identify the culprit, try running this for a day or so:

-----
while true; do
    FILE=/tmp/$0.`date +%Y%m%d-%H%M%S`
    echo "Collecting process size info and storing it in $FILE"
    ps -e -o pid,command,fname,vsz | sort -n +4 > $FILE
    sleep 3600
done
-----

After it's run for a while do a "diff" on the first and last files to see
how memory usage has changed for each process.  Those with a large delta
for the same PID are likely to be the source of your problems.

Once identified, then you can just restart that program periodically to
avoid the memory leak.

Or just add swap.  ;-)

  -- Steve

unices. After having read the Red Hat-specific books to install and

colleague in North Carolina whom I'm trying to push out the Windows.

I think a handful of O'Reilly Pocket Reference books would be ideal.

They're cheap and you can pick and choose.

Here's my suggested list:
Essential System Administration
Linux
sed & awk

For a one credit course (that's just an hour a week, right?), that should
be PLENTY of material.  Simple concepts, straightforward task-oriented
explanations.

Sample chapters available online.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Thu Mar 25 15:31:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Thu Mar 25 15:31:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] quiet IDE drives?
In-Reply-To: <86vfkso6kc.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86vfkso6kc.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <1080257286.27634.69.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Thu, 2004-03-25 at 15:22, Russell Senior wrote:
> I've got a noisy server that just moved into a working space.  I'd
> first guessed it was fan noise, and was set to replace the power
> supply, but opening the box, it turns out to be disk whine instead.
> What do people like for quiet drives these days?  I'll probably be
> buying at ENU, if that helps narrow the field.  Also, probably not one
> of the bigger ones, as we are on a tight budget.

Google and grep your way around some of the Quiet PC type websites...
they make these drive holders now that insulate the drive away from the
metal of the case, essentially suspending the drive on rubber bands. 
The result is a significantly quieter hard drive.  Of course, it has
been questioned whether or not this will degrade the performance and
life of the drive, as well as whether or not it will cause additional
heating of the drive... but it's worth investigating, I think.

That would be much cheaper, I believe, than buying a whole new hard
drive.

Rob

From steve at wirex.net  Thu Mar 25 15:47:19 2004
From: steve at wirex.net (Steve Beattie)
Date: Thu Mar 25 15:47:19 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Swap usage keeps increasing
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F31TgIvvSKXUil00057358@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY9-F31TgIvvSKXUil00057358@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <20040325234612.GA8949@wirex.net>

On Thu, Mar 25, 2004 at 09:24:48PM +0000, Vincent Yau wrote:
> But on ALL of these boxes, the usage is like 90% of all physical memory.
> For example on my most beefy box:
> 
>  Mem: 1030404k av,  981900k used,  48504k free
>
> Is there any reason why the Mem usage is always almost 90% of the total 
> size?

What Wil said is basically accurate. A useful utility in addition to top
is the 'free' command, which will show you the total amount of physical
RAM your applications are using, i.e. RAM used for buffers and cache
have been subtracted out. Here's an example output from my laptop:

[kryten steve]$ free 
             total       used       free     shared    buffers      cached
Mem:        512952     500796      12156          0     122104      230816
-/+ buffers/cache:     147876     365076
Swap:       787144      66508     720636

The "-/+ buffers/cache:" line shows that my apps are currently taking up
about 147MB of the 500MB of RAM in use, with buffers and cache taking up
the rest.

From miken at hotsushi.com  Thu Mar 25 16:03:02 2004
From: miken at hotsushi.com (Mike Neal)
Date: Thu Mar 25 16:03:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] UNIX(/Linux) Intor (text)Book
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0403250504120.4604-100000@main.cyber-office.
 net>
Message-ID: <E1B6eoO-0001ZS-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

>   So here I am trying to figure out a good book to use.  My preference is 
>to use the man pages and on-line resources but sometimes the students 
>prefer something to have and to hold.  Makes it seem more official.
>
>I need to cover actual UNIX variations and should(/will) have access to a
>HPUX system for that but the world is quickly becoming GNU/Linux/BSD.  
>Yeah the SUN still shines but I don't have access to a Solaris or SUN/OS
>box and don't encounter them very often.
>
>What are your suggestions for a good (cheap) book to use for a UNIX Intro
>class?  OS installation instructions are less of a need but usage 
>(command-line), configuration, and software installation/upgrade are really 
>important.

Hi,

For the first Linux class at PCC, we use Linux Installation and
Administration by Nicholas Wells, Course Technology:
http://www.course.com/catalog/product.cfm?isbn=0-619-13095-4 because it
covers most of what we want, it is written to the LPI certification
objectives, it includes a copy of Red Hat 7.3 and it is written as a
textbook with instructor supplements.  Also considered were Linux in a
Nutshell from O'Rielly (as a refrence book) and Mark Sobell's A Practical
Guide to Linux: http://www.sobell.com/LINUX/links.html

For Linux Networking we use TCP/IP Network Administration, 3rd ed. by Craig
Hunt: http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/tcp3/  becasuse nothing else comes close.

The Linux Security class was dropped for lack of interest but the Network
Security (Windows and *nix) is filling up and we will use Security+ guide
to Network Security Fundamentals by Cisco Learning
Institute:http://www.course.com/catalog/product.cfm?isbn=0-619-21294-2

You might want to check out the free books, aka "guides" at the Linux
Documentation Project: http://www.tldp.org/guides.html and also consider
the online books from Safari which includes all of O'reilly and lots of
others.

Good luck,
Mike




From pem at nellump.net  Thu Mar 25 16:10:03 2004
From: pem at nellump.net (Paul Mullen)
Date: Thu Mar 25 16:10:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] UNIX(/Linux) Intor (text)Book
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0403251335570.5964-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0403250554540.26359@pecos.madboa.com> <Pine.LNX.4.33.0403251335570.5964-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <20040326000930.GA10881@nellump.net>

On Thu, Mar 25, 2004 at 01:48:52PM -0800, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> 
> I'm looking for a book for the user with a technical background (not
> necessarily computer science) that needs to _use_ a UNIX/Linux/BSD
> system.

Take a look at the "Rute Users Tutorial & Exposition" (RUTE):

  Rute (Rute Users Tutorial and Exposition) is a book on GNU/Linux that
  aims to be the definitive guide for new users as well as sufficing as
  training course material, covering both the RHCE and LPI requirements.
  It covers essential theory to UNIX as well as giving practical
  tutorials on all fundamental aspects of Unix administration, from
  basic commands, the theory of TCP/IP, the Linux filesystem, through to
  configuration of mail, DNS, and other servers, through hardware
  configuration and package management. It is not Unix-specific but
  tends to give examples suited to Debian and RedHat-like systems. Rute
  comes in HTML and PDF formats.

<http://freshmeat.net/projects/rute>


Paul

> admin for the last two or three months, (at home, my roommate and I have 
> a goofy network setup,) My question is this, is the Linux+ 
> cert. something I should bother with. Or is it simply more 
> resume' padding? Or is this the right place to even ask this question?

I took the silly test only because one of my publishers wanted
me to and paid me to do it. It's a stripped-down A+ test with
Linux questions added. This means that you need to know PC hardware
and architecture even if you never run Linux on a PC. Many of the
questions and answers are silly. My favorite question asked what
I would do if I wanted a process to run more slowly (to get lesser
CPU cycles). Their correct answer was to stop the daemon and restart
it using the nice program. Apparently, the Linux wizards at CompTIA
don't know processes can be reniced without stopping them.

Ed

> So, in aptitude, how do I just look at the list of dependencies for a

HI,
Well I looked at my shelf and would like to recommend:

A practical guide to Unix by  Mark Sobell

Essential System Administration by Aeleen Frisch

Linux in a nutshell by Hekman

Unix in Plain English by Reichard and Johnson

The last two I have a hard time choosing between as they both are
useful and each has things not in the other.
If I had to choose just two it would be

A Practical Guide to Unix by Sorbell and Unix in Plain English

These are simple enough for Intro level and complex enough to keep on
the bookshelf for my failing memory.

From cmorthland at christenson.com  Fri Mar 26 08:14:01 2004
From: cmorthland at christenson.com (Morthland, Cam)
Date: Fri Mar 26 08:14:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Persistent MS virus
Message-ID: <8A331D75F9F3CD4CA589854776E6F2E602557BE1@hq-ex01.christenson.dom>

W32.BEAGLE.x (where x = spawn version).  VERY annoying - if you can, add
to your blacklist: 

support at yourorg.zzz
administration at yourorg.zzz
management at yourorg.zzz
noreply at yourorg.zzz
staff at yourorg.zzz

This will take out a number of them.  The most annoying version, which
has gotten me calls from people outside my organization is the version
where if a person is infected, the virus picks a RANDOM name from the
address book and sends ou SPAM/Viruses from that contact.  As a result,
you get calls like "I don't know anyone in your organization and I am
not a spammer"....(my spam filter sends a nice note back to the spammer)

Hope this is  not redundant info!

Cam

  This is the most annoying M$virus for a long time. There are so many
benign subjects and common-word, single sentences that it's impossible to
reliably filter them out.

specific body_check filters but the report to the originating ISP is blocked
by postfix on the way out! I've not yet figured out this one.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Fri Mar 26 09:48:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri Mar 26 09:48:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Chat/IM Server
In-Reply-To: <8A331D75F9F3CD4CA589854776E6F2E60255BBA8@hq-ex01.christenson.dom>
References: 
	 <8A331D75F9F3CD4CA589854776E6F2E60255BBA8@hq-ex01.christenson.dom>
Message-ID: <1080323260.19807.3.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Fri, 2004-03-26 at 08:06, Morthland, Cam wrote:
> I am looking for suggestions on Easy-to-use/administer Chat/IM server
> that I can set up for internal (corporate) use.  Also, what are some
> opinions on the best/easiest Windows-based IM clients to use with the
> suggested server.

As Paul and Derek suggested... Jabber.  It isn't terribly easy to set
up, but it isn't any more difficult than any other server, IMHO. 
Editing XML files by hand does suck a whole bunch, though.  It is very
feature rich and quite powerful.  You can do something as simple as just
an IM server (what I now have set up; I disabled my external
transports), or as complicated as something which has a chat server,
user database, AIM, ICQ, MSN, Yahoo, IRC, SMTP, and likely other
transports.

As for an IM client, I'm partial to Gaim.  The Windows port is moving
right along.  If not Gaim, I think Exodus is the most popular.

Rob




From geoff at agora.rdrop.com  Fri Mar 26 10:13:02 2004
From: geoff at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Fri Mar 26 10:13:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Swap usage keeps increasing 
In-Reply-To: <20040326015004.6C5608BCDA@grayscale.canids>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0403260933560.17256-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Thu, 25 Mar 2004, Felix Lee wrote:

> Wil Cooley:
> >   PID USER     PRI  NI  SIZE  RSS SHARE STAT %CPU %MEM   TIME CPU COMMAND
> >  4120 root      15   0 86784  56M  8668 S     3.1 11.1 277:11   0 X
>
> Mel Andres:
> >   PID USER      PR  NI  VIRT  RES  SHR S %CPU %MEM    TIME+  COMMAND
> >  3182 root      25   0  115m  30m 4504 S 35.1 12.1 442:02.83 X
>
> hm.  my X server right now is about 24M virt, 14m rss, but I
> restarted it today.  still, I don't think mine ever gets larger
> than about 50M virt during normal use.

The amount of resources that X uses depends on your Window Manager. I
remember my disgust with Gnome when I finally noticed that it needed
to use swap with 128MB of RAM; keep in mind this was when the contemporary
release of MS Windows ran adequately on half that much physical memory, &
was (well, still is) considered a resource pig.

If you are concerned with keeping resource use to a minimum, experiment
with other Window Managers. There's more than just the Gnome & KDE
desktop environments out there: for example, aewm has the lightest footprint,
but it is so minimalistic to make Fvwm look feature-rich; my
preference is AfterStep, which not only has a smaller footprint than
the best-known WMs (Sawfish, whatever KDE uses, Xfce, Window Maker), but
has its own set of eye candy competitive with these.
>
> >  4541 wcooley   16   0 17772  16M  8476 R     1.7  3.1   4:03   0 gnome-terminal
>
> I'm a little boggled that gnome-terminal is 16m rss.  that's a
> little larger than my emacs process, and twice as large as a
> full-screen 1600x1200x32 pixmap, and 3 times as large as the
> complete works of Shakespeare.  good thing RAM is cheap.

Again, if you are worried about resources, there are alternatives, the
most familiar being rxvt & aterm. Both drop some legacy support which
AFAIK is no longer used (i.e., Tektronix 4014 compatibility), while
adding some eye candy (e.g., translucent backgrounds, customizable
scrollbars).

Then again, as Felix wrote, RAM is cheap: almost anyone can now afford
a Gig of RAM in their home systems (which solves many problems). Yet many
of us do our computing on slender -- if not cashless -- budgets. It
never hurts to consider your priorities with regards with you do with
your computer: if all you do with your computer is surf the web, email
& compose text, then bloat in a WM is not an issue; however, if you
use your computer for resource-intensive projects (e.g., CAD, database,
gaming, etc.), then it makes sense to put X on a diet & allocate the
resources to the project.

After all, customization is one of the strengths Linux (well, any UNIX-like
OS) has over MS Windows.

Geoff

and BizNix user groups, is expanding the number of low-cost

courses will be from 3 to 8 hours in duration (short courses)
and cost from $25 to $100. We'd appreciate your help in deciding
which of the 40 new courses should be offered first and what

From kyle at silverbeach.net  Fri Mar 26 14:09:02 2004
From: kyle at silverbeach.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Fri Mar 26 14:09:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Athlon64 vs Opteron64
In-Reply-To: <1080333916.799.35.camel@kokopelli>
References: <1080333916.799.35.camel@kokopelli>
Message-ID: <200403261408.18013.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Friday 26 March 2004 12:45, Brian Beattie wrote:
> Anybody got a short description/explanation of the difference
> between these two?

Erm, AMD doesn't make it simple.  There are actually a couple of cores 
and three kinds of packaging just to keep things interesting.

All are based on the K8 core.  Some have 1MB of L2 cache, some don't.

The Opteron chips use a relatively large package, 940 pins.  They 
contain multiple HT links for ease of SMPing.  They have a double 
wide bus to memory (128-bit I believe).  Opterons require registered 
DDR sticks.  They are released at slower speed grades than the other 
chips and are intended for the server market.  

The current Athlon64 chips are divided into two broad chunks.  The two 
are the Athlon64 and the Athlon64 FX.  The latter appears to be 
something of an oddity.  It is really an Opteron as far as I can 
tell.  The low end, the Athlon64, has something like 754 pins on the 
package and contains only one HT link and has a single-wide memory 
interface.  However, it currently clocks faster and can use 
non-registered memory.

The Athlon FX appears to be a rebranded Opteron.  It is also in a 
940-pin package (soon to be 939-pin for reasons that make sense to 
AMD's marketing department).  I think it also needs to have 
registered memory.  I believe that AMD has disabled the SMP functions 
on these chips.  My only guess is that AMD released these because 
people wanted more performance for desktops but weren't willing to 
pay the premium for server chips.  No real idea.

AMD's road maps waver all over the place.  It appears that in the 
distant future (i.e. in a year or so) that there will only be 939 and 
940 type packages.  The Athlon64 will migrate to that.  One presumes 
that this means the extra HT links and memory bus will be added?  No 
idea. 

Some of the newer Athlon64 chips have 512MB of cache instead of 1MB.  
These are currently relatively cheap for the performance you get.  
Even with the missing memory bus, the memory bandwidth is reasonable 
and the memory latency is quite nice.  The ability to use cheap, 
off-the-shelf DDR400 RAM is nice.  If you need raw bandwidth, the FX 
is more expensive, but faster than an Opteron.

This is about as concise as I can make it.  AMD isn't making things 
very clear at all.  Perhaps their intention is to confuse us all to 
the point where we just buy something :-)

Best,
Kyle




From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Fri Mar 26 14:20:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Fri Mar 26 14:20:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Swap usage keeps increasing
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403261217130.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0403260933560.17256-100000@joan.burling.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403261217130.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1080339614.24249.46.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Fri, 2004-03-26 at 12:20, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> I didn't read this thread from the top, but did someone explain exactly
> what the "VIRT" column is showing?  It ain't swap, that's for sure.

Nope.  VIRT (or VSZ or SIZE) is the amount of memory mapped, regardless
of whether the page is read-only, shared, etc.  Basically, any memory
that could possibly be used by the process without malloc() or brk().
And don't confuse shared memory with SHM, also called shared memory but
is really an IPC mechanism.  Memory is a remarkably complex topic; I've
been reading Kernel Traffic for several years and it's always amazing
how complex it is.

> On my system, X is shown with 107m in the VIRT column, but I don't have
> any swap.
> 
> jbrelin at person:~$ free
>              total       used       free     shared    buffers     cached
> Mem:       1032816    1018408      14408          0     160840     663760
> -/+ buffers/cache:     193808     839008
> Swap:            0          0          0
> 
> 
> > The amount of resources that X uses depends on your Window Manager.
> 
> Uh... how's that work?  My window manager is its own process and I can't
> see how it could change the running size of the X server process.

Think about it like a print server.  When you want the print server to
print something, you send it a document and it renders it into something
the printer can understand and sends it to the printer.  The X
client/server model is similar--except for a continuous display model
things get hairier.  If I understand it correctly, it's possible for an
X client to tell the server to keep certain objects around even if they
aren't visible.  Plus there's stuff the X server or window manager
handles on its own, like backing store.  (Is backing store the same as
'save unders'?)  Oh, and fonts are cached server-side too.

Wil

The AthlonFX is for gamers.  It is to compete with the P4EE.  Very high
priced, very small market.  A decent chip with the dual-channel memory
bus.

> AMD's road maps waver all over the place.  It appears that in the

FWIW, the stuff I've read has indicated AMD is going to move all of
their non-server x86-64 chips to a single socket (which means AthlonFX
and Athlon64)... the 939-pin socket, I think?  Real Soon Now, anyway. 
So yeah, within a year.  I'm waiting for that before I think about
upgrading.

The information I've read about the transition has implied the
Athlon64's *will* move to the dual-channel memory bus at that point.  I
would be very surprised if they added the additional HT links necessary
for running the chips in an SMP environment... they want SMP users to
pay the premium for the Opteron chips.  The difference at that point
between the Athlon64 and the AthlonFX, if the AthlonFX survives that
long, will likely simply be additional L2 cache, I suppose.

From cstevens at gencom.us  Fri Mar 26 16:40:02 2004
From: cstevens at gencom.us (D. Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Fri Mar 26 16:40:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix Loopback
Message-ID: <1080347093.25370.141.camel@localhost>

Hello Everyone,

I hope you might have some ideas about a relay mail server
configuration. Here's the basic idea:

Postfix is designed to relay the mail from the outside, sanitize it for
an Exchange server and the relay the mail to said Exchange server. For
various reasons, it uses Procmail for the virus and spam checking. After
it's finished, Procmail forwards the mail to the final destination. In
this case the Exhange server.

Internet  --->  Postfix Relay Server  ---> (Procmail) -----> Exchange
server

When I pass the mail to the Exchange server, I cant pass it simply as:

  ENV_TO=$1 #Listed just to show that this is a variable for the user
  ! "$ENV_TO"@mydomain.com

I have to pas the mail off as:

! "$ENV_TO"@exchange.mydomain.com
 
If I forward the email using postfix to @mydomain.com, Postfix thinks
the mail is it's own and processes it in a loop forever!

Meanwhile on the Exchange side, it's a real pain to give every user two
receiving email addresses, user at mydomain.com and
user at exchange.domain.com.

How can I pass the mail to the Exchange server correctly without Postfix
grabbing it?

--

From boro at borosenclave.com  Fri Mar 26 16:58:02 2004
From: boro at borosenclave.com (borodimer)
Date: Fri Mar 26 16:58:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix Loopback
In-Reply-To: <1080347093.25370.141.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <NFBBJJGLMCCHDEEELDPGCENIEAAA.boro@borosenclave.com>

Check this out: http://www.spenneberg.com/postfix-amavisd-new.pdf

Basically Postfix can write to an external filter, amavisd-new in this case, loop it back to itself, and then deliver it to the internal mailserver.  I have successfully used that very guide to great success.

Phil Schultz
Head of SalemLUG


-----Original Message-----
From: plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org [mailto:plug-admin at lists.pdxlinux.org]On Behalf Of D. Cooper Stevenson
Sent: Friday, March 26, 2004 4:25 PM
To: lug at peak.org
Cc: PLUG Mailing List
Subject: [PLUG] Postfix Loopback


Hello Everyone,

I hope you might have some ideas about a relay mail server configuration. Here's the basic idea:

Postfix is designed to relay the mail from the outside, sanitize it for an Exchange server and the relay the mail to said Exchange server. For various reasons, it uses Procmail for the virus and spam checking. After it's finished, Procmail forwards the mail to the final destination. In this case the Exhange server.

Internet  --->  Postfix Relay Server  ---> (Procmail) -----> Exchange server

When I pass the mail to the Exchange server, I cant pass it simply as:

  ENV_TO=$1 #Listed just to show that this is a variable for the user
  ! "$ENV_TO"@mydomain.com

I have to pas the mail off as:

! "$ENV_TO"@exchange.mydomain.com

If I forward the email using postfix to @mydomain.com, Postfix thinks the mail is it's own and processes it in a loop forever!

Meanwhile on the Exchange side, it's a real pain to give every user two receiving email addresses, user at mydomain.com and user at exchange.domain.com.

How can I pass the mail to the Exchange server correctly without Postfix grabbing it?

--

| GenCom                  | Ph:  541.924.9434                |
| "Working For IT"        | Www: http://www.gencom.us        |

> chips for different cardinalities of SMP).  I also seem to recall that
> the opterons have three times the I/O, ammounting in something like

> anandtech comparing the opteron 244's with a dual 3ghz zeon, but I

All the K8s have an integrated memory controller... not so much a
northbridge, just the memory controller.  At least, that's how I
understood it.  There may be other northbridge functions in the core...
but things like the AGP are still controlled by the chipset.

the True Type text. The resulting image can then be used
by Word or Open Office to print labels, unless you want to

I think I found at least part of the problem. In the past, for various
reasons, I created several user accounts, some were deleted, and later
recreated. Turns out that /tmp/orbit-mel, contained a file that had the
wrong userid listed as the owner. A quick chown command seems to have
helped a lot. Still will monitor for awhile.

On Sat, 27 Mar 2004, Derwyn Harris wrote:
> I installed the Java Desktop to see what it was all about. It uses suse
> as it's linux distro. Then I decided I would like to learn PHP which
> lead me to installing Apache. In the instructions from the PHP site to
> get it all configured I'm supposed to run this line:
>
> ./configure --prefix=/www --enable-module=so
>
> at this point it fails telling me that:
>
> "Error: could not find any of these C compilers anywhere in your PATH:
> gcc cc acc c89 Configure terminated"
>
> I did a find and there is a gcc-lib and a gcc.html but not much else.
> The rpm -q does not turn anything up.
>
> Do I need to install gcc?

No.  Just install the binary apache package and the appropriate php
package and make sure you include the LoadModule line in your apache
config (httpd.conf) to point to mod_php4.so (or whatever it's called).

You don't have to compile either php or apache to make it work.

> Any suggestions? Am I headed down the right path?

You're reading instructions to build apache from source, but you already
have a binary apache distribution and it was surely built with loadable
module support.  So it doesn't need to be recompiled.

J.

On Fri, 2004-03-26 at 16:57, borodimer wrote:
> Check this out: http://www.spenneberg.com/postfix-amavisd-new.pdf
> 
> Basically Postfix can write to an external filter, amavisd-new in this case, loop it back to itself, and then deliver it to the internal mailserver.  I have successfully used that very guide to great success.
> 
> Phil Schultz
> Head of SalemLUG

It seems like there may also be a DNS issue here, postfix is configured
to receive mail that is allowed by $myhostname and $mynetworks, which
has nothing to do with a DNS lookup.  Postfix will do a DNS lookup to
relay the mail, if it is told by the DNS lookup that itself is the
machine to send the mail to, well, it will send it to itself.  Running
an internal DNS server may help straighten this out.

HTH,

Derek Loree

Geoff Burling <geoff at agora.rdrop.com>:
> The amount of resources that X uses depends on your Window Manager.

but.. why would this affect server-side memory usage by 50m or
so?  I can see different window managers having different memory
usage in their own address space, but I don't see what a window
manager could do that would consume a non-trivial amount of
memory in the X server's address space, unless the window manager
makes lots of pixmaps, like several full screen images.

> Again, if you are worried about resources, there are alternatives, the
> most familiar being rxvt & aterm. Both drop some legacy support which
> AFAIK is no longer used (i.e., Tektronix 4014 compatibility), while
> adding some eye candy (e.g., translucent backgrounds, customizable
> scrollbars).

customizable scrollbars should be a trivial amount of memory.
translucent backgrounds depends on how it's implemented, but even
if it needs a full-screen pixmap, that's only 8m at 1600x1200x32.

I really don't understand why programs are so memory hungry these
days, other than "RAM is cheap", which gives people license to be
sloppy.  the chat client I use is bigger than emacs in every way.
I'm sure in a few more years, emacs will be the most lightweight
program on my desktop.

On Sat, 2004-03-27 at 12:11, Aaron wrote:
> Can anyone point me to a good resource for configuring my LT2120
> Supraexpress 56i voice  (isa)modem on my system running debian 3.  I've got
> my netcard and x running fine.  I'm just trying to get diald running but the
> modem wasn't autodetected during the installation.  I'm pretty green when it
> comes to linux, but I'd appreciate any help that anyone can offer.

I can't remember if this is a win-modem or not, but when your computer
startup and shows the POST information, look for an extra com port
(usually you will have com1 and com2 built in, look for com3 or com4). 
That should be all the information that you need, if it is not a
win-modem.  If it is a win-modem, there are a couple of websites
dedicated to getting the things to work, but not all of them are
supported.

HTH,

Derek Loree

I have strange feelings about certifications in general and Linux ones
in particular, but:

    -  I think they are useful for people who lack 4 year degrees or
       have their degrees in an area like history or philosophy that
       isn't clearly related to computing.

    -  Certifications are also required or nearly required for certain
       jobs, especially in government and/or education.

    -  Certifications are also useful if not required when dealing with
       recruiters and HR people.

I never really thought certification meant much in terms of skills or
knowledge, but they are useful for certain people in looking for work.
And for this purpose, one is most interested in getting the most respected
certifications regardless in the certification's  "knowledge" value.  In 
those terms, the "+" series of certifications is pretty good.

                                                       Dave

From ehem at m5p.com  Sun Mar 28 00:12:02 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Sun Mar 28 00:12:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Swap usage keeps increasing
In-Reply-To: <20040327004102.13603.63080.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200403280810.i2S8AmMv044611@m5p.com>

> From: Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net>
> On Fri, 26 Mar 2004, Geoff Burling wrote:
> > On Thu, 25 Mar 2004, Felix Lee wrote:
> > > hm.  my X server right now is about 24M virt, 14m rss, but I restarted
> > > it today.  still, I don't think mine ever gets larger than about 50M
> > > virt during normal use.
> 
> I didn't read this thread from the top, but did someone explain exactly
> what the "VIRT" column is showing?  It ain't swap, that's for sure.
> 
> On my system, X is shown with 107m in the VIRT column, but I don't have
> any swap.
> 
> jbrelin at person:~$ free
>              total       used       free     shared    buffers     cached
> Mem:       1032816    1018408      14408          0     160840     663760
> -/+ buffers/cache:     193808     839008
> Swap:            0          0          0

It gets even more interesting than already pointed out. How much memory
does your display hardware have? XFree86 will map all of the display's
memory into its address space. The process size will include that in its
size, so if you've got a video card with 256MB of memory on it, the
X-server process will always be at least that large. I suspect the nVidia
driver (as well as the ATi one) also may map some of the memory into the
client's address space too, pushing the size of it too.

> > The amount of resources that X uses depends on your Window Manager.
> 
> Uh... how's that work?  My window manager is its own process and I can't
> see how it could change the running size of the X server process.

You know what a server is? A server controls a resource that clients want
to get to. In the case of the X-server that is the display, and input
(mouse/keyboard/other events). X-clients never actually touch the
framebuffer (the nVidia and ATi binary drivers may modify this, but the
clients can't expect to actually have direct access), they only do so
indirectly though the X-server.

So *everything* that gets drawn, gets drawn by the X-server. Need to draw
a line? Send a request to the X-server to draw a line somewhere. Need to
create a line? Send a request to the X-server, it will do so but likely
the WM will tell the server to add extra windows for the borders. Ever
realize that practically every single widget (button/slider/graphic)
creates a Window structure on the server? Try running `xwininfo -tree` on
a complex window, you might find a hundred window structures, each of
which has to be present in the X-server. Using OpenGL? Know how complex
those drawing commands are? Those are all done on the X-server. Every
little bit of drawing can potentially cause memory to be allocated by the
server, clients have a massive effect on the X-server process size.

This goes all the way to images, any time one is displayed it must be
created by the client then uploaded to the server for display. This makes
memory leaks a very tricky topic. A client instead of leaking memory in
its address space can leak X resources. Every one of those X resources
(notably images) equates to memory allocated on the X-server. A client
can start creating images on the X-server, and lose track of them. The
client process's size doesn't grow since the image isn't kept on the
client. Instead the X-server process keeps growing from the client's
leak. If the client disconnects the server will attempt to free all those
resources, but until it does it can look like the server has a leak not
the client...

From barryb at proaxis.com  Sun Mar 28 10:40:03 2004
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Sun Mar 28 10:40:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Supraexpress isa modem problems
In-Reply-To: <000001c41437$bba9ca00$262079a5@bobby>
References: <000001c41437$bba9ca00$262079a5@bobby>
Message-ID: <20040328183953.GA13716@edge>

On Sat, Mar 27, 2004 at 12:11:39PM -0800, Aaron wrote:
> Can anyone point me to a good resource for configuring my LT2120
> Supraexpress 56i voice  (isa)modem on my system running debian 3.  I've got
> my netcard and x running fine.  I'm just trying to get diald running but the
> modem wasn't autodetected during the installation.  I'm pretty green when it
> comes to linux, but I'd appreciate any help that anyone can offer.
> 

>From this page 
http://freewebhosting.hostdepartment.com/g/gromitkc/isa_list.html
I find that the Models 2121 2122 2123 2124 2125 are not winmodems
and are therefore linux compatible. I will assume that the 2120 
also fits into that category.

Are you using a 2.2 kernel or a 2.4 kernel? uname -a 
will tell you. I think that the 2.4 kernels usually handle
the pnp cards pretty well and should detect your modem.
Run dmesg | less 
and look through the output and make sure that the card was not detected.
If it is not there, a useful tool to start out with when configuring isa cards is
pnpdump. It is part of the isapnptools and will detect the modem
and tell us how it is configured. Just apt-get install isapnptools
and run pnpdump and see if it detects the modem.

Bill Barry

through wvdial that I need to add the dnsserver information into?


> Can anyone point me to a good resource for configuring my LT2120 
> Supraexpress 56i voice  (isa)modem on my system running debian 3.  
> I've got my netcard and x running fine.  I'm just trying to get diald 
> running but the modem wasn't autodetected during the installation.  
> I'm pretty green when it comes to linux, but I'd appreciate any help 
> that anyone can offer.
> 

>From this page 
http://freewebhosting.hostdepartment.com/g/gromitkc/isa_list.html
I find that the Models 2121 2122 2123 2124 2125 are not winmodems and are
therefore linux compatible. I will assume that the 2120 
also fits into that category.

Are you using a 2.2 kernel or a 2.4 kernel? uname -a 
will tell you. I think that the 2.4 kernels usually handle
the pnp cards pretty well and should detect your modem.
Run dmesg | less 
and look through the output and make sure that the card was not detected. If
it is not there, a useful tool to start out with when configuring isa cards
is pnpdump. It is part of the isapnptools and will detect the modem and tell
us how it is configured. Just apt-get install isapnptools and run pnpdump
and see if it detects the modem.

Bill Barry

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Sun Mar 28 19:08:01 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Sun Mar 28 19:08:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Chat/IM Server
In-Reply-To: <8A331D75F9F3CD4CA589854776E6F2E60255BBA8@hq-ex01.christenson.dom>
References: 
	 <8A331D75F9F3CD4CA589854776E6F2E60255BBA8@hq-ex01.christenson.dom>
Message-ID: <1080529671.5412.16.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Fri, 2004-03-26 at 08:06, Morthland, Cam wrote:
> I am looking for suggestions on Easy-to-use/administer Chat/IM server
> that I can set up for internal (corporate) use.  Also, what are some
> opinions on the best/easiest Windows-based IM clients to use with the
> suggested server.

As others said, Jabber is a good choice.  I just set it up for myself
and my reading indicated the the Jabber 2 server is still rather
unstable and 1.4 is the way to go for now.  (Based in part on the
messages at http://amessage.info.)

If you're using Red Hat 7.3 or ES3, I've built RPMs which are available
at http://ftp.nakedape.cc/nakedape/ (also apt-get-able).

The Jabber.org site has a big list of clients:
http://www.jabber.org/software/clients.php

I've been using Psi and Gaim, both of which are multi-platform (although
I haven't actually used them on Windows).  Gaim is simple and
multi-protocol, but doesn't have a lot of Jabber-specific features, like
service browsing, Jabber gateways, admin features, etc.  Psi is
Jabber-only and does have an easy way of using the gateways, browsing,
and admin features, but it's a tad ugly and Qt-based.

Exodus is supposed to be a nice Windows-only client.  I haven't had any
luck with Gabber on Linux.

Wil

Thanks for the help everyone.  I did a little searching and it turns out
that my ppp0 was not the default route for external addresses.  So I tried
using route add default ppp0.  This worked except that every time that I
connected I had to type this in the shell.  Im not exactly sure what this
did, but according to another forum I removed diald using apt-get and this
took care of the problem.  I'm assuming that a device was set as default
first and was set as a higher priority than ppp0.  Does this make sense?  To
make a long story short I skipped using wvdial and went to using pon and
poff with pppconfig.  Im up and running great now.  Thanks again for all the
input!

Aaron McIntosh

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon Mar 29 15:36:01 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Mon Mar 29 15:36:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Internal DNS
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403291450160.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403291450160.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <86wu53uszu.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> What's the best approach here?

[Caveat: I have no idea what is best.]

I am using bind9's "views", e.g.:

[...]

acl "internal" {
        127.0.0.1; 192.168/16;
};

view "internal" {
        match-clients { "internal"; }
        recursion yes;

        [...]

        zone "0.168.192.in-addr.arpa" {
                type master;
                notify no;
                file "/etc/bind/db.192.168.0";
        };

        zone "foo.com" {
                type master;
                notify no;
                file "/etc/bind/db.foo-internal";
        };
};

view "external" {
        match-clients { any; };
        recursion yes;

        [...]

        zone "foo.com" {
                type master;
                file "/etc/bind/db.foo-external";
        };
};

Seems to work fine.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com



From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Mon Mar 29 15:44:02 2004
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)
Date: Mon Mar 29 15:44:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Internal DNS
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403291450160.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403291539220.10830-100000@mail.mpcu.com>

On Mon, 29 Mar 2004, Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> 
> I have two questions today to pose to the gang.  They will be in separate
> messages.
> 
> I find myself, for the first time in my experience, in need of internal
> DNS.  I have a local DNS server that is providing lookups for my clients
> and also doing primary service for the domains served out of the local
> datacenter.
> 
> I need to have name resolution for internal hosts that do not have public
> addresses.
> 
> The one caveat is that the domain to which these devices believe they
> belong is wildcarded to a single address.
> 
> What's the best approach here?
> 
> Should I set up a separate internal DNS server that just serves local
> info or is there a way to serve that local info only to local clients from
> the same server as the public DNS?

This is how I implement "local" dns.  Have a local dns server for local 
resolution.  No dependency on a name server that might need to be broought 
down for maintenance or is having network connectivity issues.  You can 
use split views on one dns server to accomplish this, but given the low 
cost of moderately performing hardware an internal dns server is 
reasonable.


> 
> Is there a way to serve "domainless" name resolution so that a host "foo"

This is how I implement "local" dns.  Have a local dns server for local 
resolution.  No dependency on a name server that might need to be broought 
down for maintenance or is having network connectivity issues.  You can 
use split views on one dns server to accomplish this, but given the low 
cost of moderately performing hardware an internal dns server is 
reasonable.

I'm all for separate nameservers and zone files for internal and
public.  The public nameserver stays outside the firewall and has no
info about the inside, and can be moved about as you like without
impacting internal services.

Internal machines go on a separate domain name or a subdomain, which is
set as the default domain name.

From freyley at gmx.net  Mon Mar 29 18:42:02 2004
From: freyley at gmx.net (Jeff Schwaber)
Date: Mon Mar 29 18:42:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] PostgreSQL configuration.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403291455450.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403291455450.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <1080614443.16700.8.camel@zadie>

On Mon, 2004-03-29 at 14:58, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> I have an internal database server that is serving information to a series
> of CGI applications on a public webserver.

> Is there a way to configure postgres such that trust authentication is
> only used for certain database users and others are going to use pam or
> another authentication method?
> 
> Am I misunderstanding the postgres authentication model?

Put multiple lines in the config file, for different users.

so for example:
type	db	user				method
local	all	postgres			ident sameuser
host	all	all	127.0.0.1		password

means if you're connecting by tcp/ip from localhost, it asks for a
password. If user postgres is connecting locally, i.e. a unix socket, it
allows it in.

So to use trust for certain users, do

local	all	my_user				trust

rather than

local	all	all				trust

I may be misunderestimating[tm] the problem.

Jeff

> Thanks.
> J.




From allyn at well.com  Mon Mar 29 18:43:02 2004
From: allyn at well.com (Mark Allyn)
Date: Mon Mar 29 18:43:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] PostgreSQL configuration.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403291455450.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403291455450.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.58.0403291836060.26677@well.com>

I think that it's best to use password autentication for the
database user account for the web-cgi.

You would have to have the password embedded in one of the
cgi scripts, but you can have that script only executable by
the cgi user and not readable.

It is also best to have the web server on a separate machine
from the database server.

The database server should be on a lan that is not accessable
from the public internet. It should only have accounts for the
system administrator and the DBA. It should only have the
postgres port open to the web server. All other ports should
be blocked from the web server.  (Port 25 for ssh, used for
maintenance, should be only available from an inside host or
accessible via port knocking).

This way, if the web server is hacked, the person would be
in the web server as the www-user (or nobody, if so configured)
and could not:

1. Get into the database as the password in in a read locked
file

2. Get into any other postgres account because all the
postgres accounts are set to password access via the
pg_hba.conf file.

3. Get onto the postgres server itself without somehow
cracking in via the postgres port (hopefuly you will keep
postgresql up to current version).

Good Luck!

Mark Allyn

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon Mar 29 19:39:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Mar 29 19:39:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Knoppix file delete
In-Reply-To: <20040330032549.GA14651@themontagnes.com>
References: <20040330032549.GA14651@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <1080617916.24885.72.camel@dell.linux.box>

On Mon, 2004-03-29 at 19:25, Michael Montagne wrote:
> I need to delete some pesky trojan files from Win2000(ntfs) using
> Knoppix.  I can successfully do "mount -oremount,rw /dev/hda1" but
> when I try and delete the files I get "Operation not permitted".  I
> changed the permissions to 777 and still the same.  How can I get rid
> of these guys?

The Linux NTFS driver is very very lacking, not having any decent write
support.

*If* knoppix has started using Captive, then you should be able to
delete them that way.

Or *if* you're using a new enough version of Knoppix to have a 2.6
kernel onboard, you should be able to echo 0 > filename to wipe out the
contents of the file.  You can't actually delete it, though.

Rob




From kgmorse at mpcu.com  Mon Mar 29 20:27:02 2004
From: kgmorse at mpcu.com (Keith Morse)

On Mon, 29 Mar 2004, Chris Penwell wrote:

> > 
> > Is there a way to serve "domainless" name resolution so that a host 
> > "foo" can resolve to an address or do I use a domain zonefile and rely 
> > on the "search" parameter of the clients to add the domain name?
> 
> the only domainless way I'm aware of is thru host files and keeping them 
> up to date is problematic.
> 
> 
> Do all the host files need to be the same? If so, why couldn't person set up
> link to a hosts file somewhere central, like the file server?
> 
> (go easy, I'm kind of a newbie)


As Jeme alluded to but didn't explain, the above concept is chicken and 
egg in nature.  The file you require for name resolution requires name 
resolution in order for it to be read in the first place.


Host files were the way to get things done way back when, before DNS 
existed.  I' sure it quickly became untenable when the host list grew to 
more than a hundred or so entries.  Even 100 or so entries is a pain in 
the ass to manage, hence the origination of DNS.


Until last year, I had the pleasure to work in a environment that didn't 
have DNS and relied exclusively on hosts files.  You soon find out that 
Sendmail really doesn't like not having a name server to query against.  I 
mean really really doesn't like.  Doubtless other MTA's share this same 
behavior.




From ed at alcpress.com  Mon Mar 29 21:11:02 2004
From: ed at alcpress.com (Ed Sawicki)
Date: Mon Mar 29 21:11:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] RE: Re: Internal DNS
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403292014370.10830-100000@mail.mpcu.com>

Message-ID: <40690120.7020203@alcpress.com>

Keith Morse wrote:
> On Mon, 29 Mar 2004, Chris Penwell wrote:
> 
> 
>>>Is there a way to serve "domainless" name resolution so that a host 
>>>"foo" can resolve to an address or do I use a domain zonefile and rely 
>>>on the "search" parameter of the clients to add the domain name?
>>
>>the only domainless way I'm aware of is thru host files and keeping them 
>>up to date is problematic.

Creating "domainless" names in DNS is easy. I created the names
moe, larry, and curly on a DNS server. Here's the results with
the unimportant parts of the dig output snipped:

# dig @ns1.alcpress.com moe.
;; QUERY SECTION:
;;      moe, type = A, class = IN

;; ANSWER SECTION:
moe.                    1H IN A         208.151.249.202


# dig @ns1.alcpress.com larry.
;; QUERY SECTION:
;;      larry, type = A, class = IN

;; ANSWER SECTION:
larry.                  1H IN A         208.151.249.203


# dig @ns1.alcpress.com curly.
;; QUERY SECTION:
;;      curly, type = A, class = IN

;; ANSWER SECTION:
curly.                  1H IN A         208.151.249.204

Of course, this is the easy part. The harder part is convincing
your DNS resolver that a name like "moe" is fully-qualified
and not in need of "fixing". Sometimes, the RFCs are a curse.

Any chance of getting y'all in one of my DNS classes?

Ed

The part of the ntfs file module that supports writing files to the FS
is marked VERY EXPERIMENTAL. When I was experimenting with this feature
about a year ago, I found I could not delete files. I did some research
(there's a NTFS web forum that I found with Goodle), followed the
instructions I found there (IIRC, one had to mount the file system
twice, & then one could cp/mv/rm files in the NTFS space), & I still could
not get it to work. (The developers were trying to keep this functionality
out of the hands of small children, but succeeded in keeping it out of
practically everyone's hands. At the time, I wasn't worried about data
loss, & the warned data loss would have simply been something I could
have entertained my boss with.)

If I had the time, I would have poked deeper into this mystery, but
since I knew how to do what I wanted in other ways, I dropped this line of
experimentation.

Since what you are doing is very risky, why not simplify matters by simply
copying all of the files you want to a non-MS filesystem, burn them to one
or more CDs, then wipe & reinstall the system, & copy those files over? I
suspect (sadly) that this is what you will end up doing.

Geoff

From dzl at frenetic.com  Mon Mar 29 22:23:02 2004
From: dzl at frenetic.com (Daniel Logghe)
Date: Mon Mar 29 22:23:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] PostgreSQL configuration.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403291455450.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403291455450.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <40691226.10804@frenetic.com>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> I have an internal database server that is serving information to a series
> of CGI applications on a public webserver.
> 
> The database username does not correspond to any local username on the
> database host.  As it stands, I'm doing passwordless "trust"
> authentication from the Postgres server to the internal network.
> 
> Is there a way to configure postgres such that trust authentication is
> only used for certain database users and others are going to use pam or
> another authentication method?
> 
> Am I misunderstanding the postgres authentication model?
> 
> Thanks.
> J.

In short the answer is yes, you can do that. Postgresql's authentication 
model is capable of a great deal of precision.

You're looking for the pg_hba.conf file in /etc/postgresql (though this 
may be elsewhere depending on how it was installed.)

add a line that look like

local  database  username                           md5

or, for a remote database

host   yourdatabase  yourusername  ipofhostconnectingfrom  ipmask  md5

instead of for a specific user or database you can use the keyword all, 
and instead of md5 you can use "trust", "reject", "password", "crypt", 
"krb5", "ident" or "pam" for the various ways of storing passwords and 
asking or not asking for them. "password" stores it in plain text so 
should probably be avoided, I recommend md5 as the best method for 
passwords.

You'll need to make sure you either add the user or reset the password 
for the user again after you've changed the pg_hba.conf and reloaded 
postgres in order for it to store the password in the right way.

Also, when adding lines there be aware that it is a set of rules applied 
in order, so be sure to put your lines that allow stuff before the 
default lines that deny everything from everywhere.


The "createuser" program is useful for the creation of postgresql users 
btw.


I do recommend using passwords instead of just "trust" for web apps, it 
makes it so just anyone who may gain access to your local network can't 
automatically have access to the database, they'd have to also manage to 
get the password. It may not be much more, depending on how you store 
the password on the client side, but it is at least something.

I hope that was the information you were after.

Using apt/yum to upgrade from FC1 to FC2-test2 is NOT A GOOD IDEA(tm) ;-)

Using new ISOs should clear out the various potential problems with
the jump to a SELinux enabled kernel.

I just happened to "make a mess" of my laptop earlier this week. Rather
than take the wimpy route of letting the installer "automagically" fix
it for me, I tried to fix it by hand. From memory, I made sure I had
the policy, policycoreutils, policy-sources, and checkpolicy packages
installed.

Next, run the following commands and then reboot:
	
	cd /etc/security/selinux/src/policy
	make load
	make relabel


If things are still horribly broken, try rebooting with the following
parameters:

	selinux=0 enforcing=0

If you still have a problem after all of this, it is not related to
SELinux ;-)

-Eric

From john at johntelford.com  Tue Mar 30 09:25:02 2004
From: john at johntelford.com (John Telford)
Date: Tue Mar 30 09:25:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] IT Offshore Mania
Message-ID: <r02010100-1033-11198B6A826F11D8BF65000A959F4BC6@[172.27.1.100]>

Unfortunately, Linux jobs aren't immune from being shipped offshore. 

I'm going out on a limb and prophetize that IT offshore mania will soon
come back and severely bite many companies. Unplanned consequences of
intellectual property and trade secrets being ripped off will sting. In
some cases, the bite will be lethal.

The real pain will come when the back doors planted in returning
offshore software are remotely opened by lunatics hiding in caves or
spider holes somewhere in the world. A simple mouse click or push of a
button could render the victim company instantly broke and with empty
disks and databases.

Far fetched you say. Consider this. Most IT groups that aren't yet
pounding the pavement looking for work because of IT offshore mania,
spend precious little time walking through and inspecting software. When
IT offshore mania hits, the expensive programmers with years of
experience are likely shown the door first. After all, the rational of
IT offshore is cutting expenses.

So who's going to walk through and inspect returning offshore software
looking for devious back doors? The boss? I don't think so. It takes
skill and time for understanding software written by others. Few in
today's IT industry have the skill or the time. Those who may have the
skill are probably pounding the pavement because of IT offshore mania.

...John

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Mar 30 10:50:02 2004
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue Mar 30 10:50:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] samba
In-Reply-To: <BAY1-F18dTMVwVn20lb00018150@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY1-F18dTMVwVn20lb00018150@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <4069C13C.9040600@dimstar.net>

Raver Guy wrote:

> Do you know how to get to samba on a mandrake 9.2 machine I really 
> need to network share some files and I can't find samba or con figure 
> it.  Any help would be apreciated.  Thank you for your time 


Assuming you would have installed the Mandrake RPM for it, check to make 
sure it's installed with the following command:

rpm -qa | grep samba

This can be run as a regular user, and will return all packages with 
"samba" in their name.

If you don't get anything (i.e. the prompt returns without listing any 
packages) then samba isn't installed, and you need to install it.

My system returns the following:

$ rpm -qa | grep samba
samba-server-2.2.8a-13mdk
samba-client-2.2.8a-13mdk
samba-common-2.2.8a-13mdk

So, assuming you want the same, and the first command didn't return 
anything, the following command (as root) will install the same packages:

urpmi samba-server samba-client samba-common

If your system is configured properly, it will ask for the CDs it needs 
to find the packages, and install them.

Once that's done, smb.conf is in /etc/samba

It's well commented. In addition, there are excellent docs at www.samba.org

Good luck!

Russ

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Mar 30 11:52:02 2004

Date: Tue Mar 30 11:52:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Fedora Test problems (was: cooking with gas)
In-Reply-To: <20040330144118.24797.62971.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040330144118.24797.62971.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Russell Senior writes:


> Hi folks, I noticed that Fedora Core 2 Test 2 was released today, so I
> naively decided it was time to bootup the fedora option on my
> treble-boot (fedora/debian/gentoo) crashbox and see if I could update
> it.
...
> So, it looks like I hosed things but good.  Not that I lost anything
> important, this was just a crashbox to try things out on, but
> definitely a violation of the "least astonishment" principle.  Is
> fedora supposed to upgrade in place like debian, because at least in
> this case it didn't for me.  ;-) If so, how?  Also, is my botch
> recoverable in any practical manner or should I punt to new iso's?

Russ:

FC2T2 should probably be installed on its own disk, and probably will
not upgrade well.  This is pre-alpha code, and compatability with past 
and future versions receives no attention at all.  The only thing they
expect to work is upgrades from FC1 release to FC2 release.

Given recent traffic on the fedora-test list, I suspect Fedora Core 2
Test 2 is extremely hosed.  *LOTS* of people cannot even manage to do
a clean install on a plain vanilla FC1-proven machine from distro disks.
And the help they are getting amounts to "you are stupid".  

I posted a hundred line rant about testing mis-management on the test
list ( which is probably another reason not to read it :-) ) but I will
not subject you to it here.  While I like the way Redhat/Fedora does
a lot of things, the testing process may be broken.  Unless you want
to put up with a lot of bugs and a lot of abuse, you should avoid it.

In the larger sense, the 2.6 transition does not seem to be going well,
and we are getting a large influx of computer users from Windoze these
days.  So a lot of the old hands are stressed out, and are turning into
YASholes (YAS="you are stupid").   Maybe we should plan something fun
to help us chill out.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue Mar 30 12:28:02 2004

Subject: [PLUG] SPF records in DNS zone files
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403301221080.23479@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

  Are folks adding spf records to their dns zone files? Aracnet did so for
my domain when I asked this morning. The format is simple:

domain_name.tld		IN TXT	"v=spf1 a mx ptr -all"

  With this in place, spf-enabled MTAs can verify that mail supposedly from
your domain name was sent by a defined mail server at your IP address. Seems
to me this will help reduce spam once spf records are generally implemented.

  I took my MTA internal to my domain to cut down on spam. When my ISP
handled it, too many messages were addressed to their IP address rather than
mine. Since their mail server is trusted by my network, all the spam came
through. Now I aggressively filter spam with postfix and I'm much happier
with the results. Frankly, it doesn't matter if you run exim, postfix or any
other MTA as long as you understand how you have it configured.
