From felix.1 at canids.net  Tue Mar 30 15:06:01 2004
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Tue Mar 30 15:06:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] How dangerous is handling my own mail? 
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403301315360.23479@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> 
    on Tue, 30 Mar 2004 13:19:03 PST
    from Rich Shepard <rshepard@appl-ecosys.com> 
References: <20040330205716.GI3539@peak.org>  <Pine.LNX.4.56.0403301315360.23479@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> 
Message-ID: <20040330230519.06179AB3@grayscale.canids>

my instinct is that web servers are a lot more "dangerous" than
mail servers, and ideally any web server accessible by the world
should be outside your firewall.  if the web server just serves
static pages, then there's little risk, but few people want to
serve just static pages.  (and many of those people will still
use something like apache, which introduces a large amount of
complexity unrelated to static pages.)

mail servers are pretty innocuous these days.  after many
embarrassing security problems in sendmail (like the Morris Worm
in 1988), people in the 90s decided it would be a good idea to
design MTAs with a not-so-cuddly view of the internet and pay
careful attention to paranoiac security issues from the start, so
you have MTAs like postfix and qmail that have simple and robust
security models based on separation of privileges.

I think right now the main problem with mail servers is spam, and
sometimes DoS attacks.

... I'm just amused that the Morris Worm was a Big Deal, and it
motivated people to attack root causes of security problems.
it's 16 years later, there's a minor worm outbreak every week,
and people are spending an awful lot of energy on band-aids.
--

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Mar 30 15:17:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue Mar 30 15:17:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SPF records in DNS zone files
In-Reply-To: <4069E5F3.9020904@dimstar.net>

 <4069E5F3.9020904@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0403301512260.3607@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 30 Mar 2004, Russ Johnson wrote:

> My kids and my girlfriend live elsewhere in Oregon, and have a
> different connection to the net. They have email addresses on my
> server, and pick up from mail.dimstar.net.
>
> However, due to restrictions, they must send through the provider
> they are connected to. So their dimstar.net email will come from a
> centurytel.net mail server.

I don't know what restrictions are in place on the centurytel.net
network, but they're typically limited to outbound port-25 sessions.

If so, have you investigated opening the msa (587/tcp) port and
configuring your mail server to accept/relay only authenticated users
on that port?

That's the way I have my mail server setup at home. Others can send
through it by using SMTP AUTH over SSL. Most mainstream mail clients,
Eudora and Outlook included, will support AUTH and SSL.

That way, all dimstar.net mail could be relayed via the official
dimstar.net mail server.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From stever at woo-hoo.com  Tue Mar 30 15:44:03 2004
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Tue Mar 30 15:44:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT: Dual WAN routers?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403301031170.19867-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403301031170.19867-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>
Message-ID: <35306.207.173.0.68.1080690228.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

> I'll soon have both Cable and DSL Internet connections and I'm looking
> into products that will load-balance, auto-failover, etc.  Here's some
...
> http://www.xincom.com/twr602.html

I like the looks of the "Xincom" and the Linksys the best.  At least
Xincom gives a semi-plausible explaination of how they achieve load
balancing from the Internet towards the user network (round-robin DNS
responses, evidently).
What I don't understand (and perhaps they are not promising this) is how
load balancing occurs with non DNS-driven traffic.  Do they propose that
if you have 3Mbps cable and 1Mbps DSL that downloads will reach say,
4Mbps?

> The product from Hawking Technology is by far the cheapest, but I'm
> wondering if anyone has had experience with these products and can offer
> any additional information or recommendations.

Until hearing how it works, I would be somewhat skeptical of how robust
the failover capabilites are for either product.  In the absence of
Internet routing protocol, how does the router know when one connection
goes down?  A simple case of the ethernet cable being uplugged should be
easy to determine.  But how often does Comcast/et al have problems where
all you do is lose link light to the cable modem?  I imagine that the
router could send some form of proprietary keepalive to say, some black
box of the manufacturer's on the Internet.  If the keepalive fails, then
the router could presume that the cable modem has failed.  But my imagined
scenario seems somewhat contrived.

One other concern about outbound "packet" load balancing.  Potentially the
packets could be taking wildly divergent paths if sent to two different
providers and arrive at different times.  When they arrive at the
destination, it seems packet reordering may occur.  Would any bandwidth be
wasted by TCP receiving out-of-order packets and requesting
retransmission?  Reordering wouldn't be an issue if instead some sort of
flow-based load balancing were used instead of per-packet.  But then you
would not get any higher throughput than any single one of your
connections.

It is an intriguing concept- would love to be multi-homed to the Internet
at home :)

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0403301748180.20296-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org>

On Tue, 30 Mar 2004, Steven Raymond wrote:

> One other concern about outbound "packet" load balancing.  Potentially the
> packets could be taking wildly divergent paths if sent to two different
> providers and arrive at different times.  When they arrive at the
> destination, it seems packet reordering may occur.  Would any bandwidth be
> wasted by TCP receiving out-of-order packets and requesting
> retransmission?  Reordering wouldn't be an issue if instead some sort of
> flow-based load balancing were used instead of per-packet.  But then you
> would not get any higher throughput than any single one of your

>From what I understand, once a computer establishes a connection to a
remote host, all traffic for that session goes over the same Internet
connection.  If computer A is saturating the first Internet connection
then these routers should detect that and send new connections from
Computer B over the second Internet connection.  So you never get the
speed of both 'net connections combined.

From dzl at frenetic.com  Tue Mar 30 18:07:02 2004
From: dzl at frenetic.com (Daniel Logghe)
Date: Tue Mar 30 18:07:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] PostgreSQL configuration.
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403301126020.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403291455450.13321@shaft.bitmine.net> <1080614443.16700.8.camel@zadie> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403301126020.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <406A2787.3000709@frenetic.com>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:

> I'm not seeing anything in the docs about the order in which these are
> processed, though... For example, I'd like to trust one user and md5 all
> others.  Would that be
> local	all	all	md5
> local	all	my_user	trust
> or the reverse or something else?

In that case either order should work, as they are both explicit allow 
rules, however I'd still suggest putting the trust before the md5. The 
rules are processed in order, so the first one it hits that it matches 
will be the one it prefers.

relay.  Search Google for open relay test for sites that will test

> much risk is there in opening that port?

You assume correctly, there's not much risk.

Well, not in this case. Read carefully: I'm going with a huge initrd

if I wanted persistancy, rsync it back or something.) So, noatime
doesn't really matter.

> > Oh, right... make sure you never provide that kind of a useful public
> > service, else some people will block all mail from you and make so that
> > others block mail from you as well.
>
> Can one run an open relay and not be used by spammers?

Certainly not when everyone else's relays are closed.

But what's the harm in some of your bandwidth being used for spam when it
is also being used for legitimate email?

We're not going to beat spam by locking down every mailserver in the
world.  That's just an absurd notion.  Better to open up our servers and
beat the spam by potentially effective means.

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403301857380.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 30 Mar 2004, Paul Johnson wrote:
> I like how you make the suggestion, but please enlighten us as to what
> you call "effective means."

I run spamassassin.  It catches practically everything.  I disabled the
blackhole list checks by scoring them to 0.0.

> How long have you been fighting spam, Jeme?

I don't fight it, I just ignore it... I use some programs to make it
easier to do that.

Spammers will find a way to send so long as it is profitable to do so.
Nobody wants to make it more difficult or expensive to send email, so the
only way to decrease the profitability is to make the email yield no
sales.

The current methods have already driven spam to become largely illegible.
Clients that automatically load data from the internet (via URL or
otherwise) are probably the biggest problem at the moment as they make the
content unfilterable.

J.

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0403301920410.13321@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Tue, 30 Mar 2004, Paul Johnson wrote:
> The false-negatives really go down with them turned on.

That's not consistent with the mail I'm receiving at all.  Baseless
conjecture, really.

The relay checks don't count for more than 2 or 3 points, tops... and my
false negatives (three or four per week) usually score below 1.0 (due to
abused negative scores).  Hence, if you add the relay checks to the -2.5
(the score of the one false negative I received today), you'd still end up
well below my threshold of 5.0.

Spend a little time tweaking your scores and adding some rules and you'll
see how pointless those checks are.

I don't know if I'll ever convince you how backward and destructive
authoritarian systems are, though.  You'll just have to come to that on
your own.

Oh wait, you're going to do the first ANYWAY, so why bother doing the

From john at meissen.org  Tue Mar 30 20:04:02 2004
From: john at meissen.org (John Meissen)
Date: Tue Mar 30 20:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] How dangerous is handling my own mail?
In-Reply-To: (Your message of Tue, 30 Mar 2004 19:08:03 PST.)
             <20040331030803.20153.75430.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> 
Message-ID: <20040331040321.32AD173FFA@john.meissen.org>

Jeme A Brelin said:
> But what's the harm in some of your bandwidth being used for spam when
> it is also being used for legitimate email? 

and:
> > Can one run an open relay and not be used by spammers?

> Just checked the mail logs on one of my open mail servers... no
> messages there I don't recognize.  It's been open for a couple of
> years.

> So I guess it IS possible. 

That's a fool's argument.

What's the harm? I've seen it first-hand. When I worked at Pyramid the
mail servers were configured as open-relay, which was the default. One
night they got discovered by spammers, who relayed messages to sets
of addresses with millions of recipients. The entire mail system 
ground to a halt and the sysadmins spent literally weeks dealing with 
bounces and hate mail from people following the address trail. I believe
they told me they were getting roughly 300 messages per hour. Once they
were discovered it took months for the relay attempts to die off. For
weeks they were getting hit with several relay attempts per minute.

The issue isn't just stopping spam, it's also about leaving yourself
vulnerable. There is absolutely NO legitimate reason to allow 
unathenticated relaying through any mail server.

Now that the spammers have virus-infected home PC's to relay through the
problem isn't as bad. I'd say my personal mail server typically rejects 
only three or four relay attempts per day.

Claiming it's OK just because you've been lucky so far isn't a very good
argument.

john-

>
> That's a fool's argument.

It's proof.  He just asked if it CAN be done.  The answer, apparently, is
yes.

> What's the harm? I've seen it first-hand. When I worked at Pyramid the
> mail servers were configured as open-relay, which was the default. One
> night they got discovered by spammers, who relayed messages to sets of
> addresses with millions of recipients. The entire mail system ground to
> a halt and the sysadmins spent literally weeks dealing with bounces and
> hate mail from people following the address trail. I believe they told
> me they were getting roughly 300 messages per hour. Once they were
> discovered it took months for the relay attempts to die off. For weeks
> they were getting hit with several relay attempts per minute.

This is a result of closing all the other relays on the net.  If EVERY
mail relay was open, the spammers wouldn't have to focus their attention
on the few they can find and exploit them.

Those who use others' relays are bottlenecked down to a few and those
servers are ground to their knees.  This is a direct result of the push
for closed relays.

The harm isn't in the opening of the relay, but in the closing.

I'll grant that that can be argued from either side, but the point is that
the closing has OTHER negative effects, while the opening has ONE
potentially negative effect.  That negative is the potential use of the
relay to send spam, but I don't think there's any evidence at all that
closing relays has decreased the amount of spam on the net and I think you
can easily demonstrate for yourself that filtering is quite effective
without checking the source of the email.

Think about it.  Spam is unwanted email CONTENT.  It only makes sense to
filter it by content.  You don't want to stop receiving mail from certain
servers, you want to stop receiving mail of a certain type from ANY
server.  So deal with the real problem.

> The issue isn't just stopping spam, it's also about leaving yourself
> vulnerable. There is absolutely NO legitimate reason to allow
> unathenticated relaying through any mail server.

So everyone should have multi-homed email for failover?  Unauthenticated
relaying helps people who cannot reach their usual mail server to send
mail across the internet.  The more open relays, the more redundancy in
the system.

On how many mail servers do you have accounts?  I think I might have
access to two.  That's not a whole lot of options.  And they're BOTH in
Portland, so if there's some kind of catastrophic power failure, I'm
screwed for outgoing email.

There is ONE reason to close your mail relay... and it's not a very good
reason because it's not particularly effective at solving the problem it's
attempting to solve.

> Now that the spammers have virus-infected home PC's to relay through the
> problem isn't as bad.

Right.  Closing relays wasn't the answer in the first place.  It was a
kind of temporary stop-gap with serious unintended consequences.

Now, if we implement solutions to the spam problem that actually address
the real issue (mail content that we don't want to see), then they can
have all the mail servers in the world and it still won't impact us.

> I'd say my personal mail server typically rejects only three or four
> relay attempts per day.

Then it's definitely time to open that sucker up.

> Claiming it's OK just because you've been lucky so far isn't a very good
> argument.

I am not claiming it's OK because my mail server hasn't been ground to
dust.  I'm claiming it's OK because it's a public good with only one
potential drawback that you, yourself, admitted isn't much of an issue
anymore.

J.

Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> Is it "misconfiguration" or just default behavior not boarded up with
> extra administrative work that inconveniences everyone equally,
 > spammer or otherwise?
 >

It isn't default behavior with the newer MTA software.  Also, it is a 
carryover from a different world where network connections were 
unreliable and required relays to bridge the gaps.  Now, servers can 
have single functions: receiving email for a domain, or sending email 
from users.

> 
> Yeah.  Here's one:  mail.bikearmy.org
> 

It isn't an open relay.

RCPT TO:<ian at znark.com>
550 5.7.1 <ian at znark.com>... Relaying denied

> 
> The point is that a public one can be used by everyone and a private one
> can't be.  I don't do it for MY benefit, but for the benefit of others.
> 

How many other people have ever used it for relaying legitimate email? 
Have you posted it anywhere so people can find it?

> 
> Mail should work by picking a mail server and saying "deliver this for
> me".
> 

How does the client pick a mail server?  With DHCP, the server can use 
IP addresses.  Or it can be entered into the client, where 
authentication isn't much more burden.

> 
> What does "feeding in spam" mean?
> 
 > I don't understand why you had to shut down the service.
 >

The secondary server had weaker spam checks than the primary server. 
The primary server has to trust the secondary and can't do any filtering 
based on source.  The spammers deliberately connect to the secondary to 
bypass the filters.   Also, the secondary server does not know which 
mailboxes are valid so it accepts all the email.  When the primary 
rejected the email, then the secondary is obligated to send bounce 
messages.  It is a waste to deliver bounces to those you don't want or 
can't get them.

  - Ian

> This is a result of closing all the other relays on the net.  If EVERY

> Well, that's just it.  You take the pains on one side or the other.

than 2K bytes. But when they drop it on your system for relaying they
include as many recipient addresses as possible. How will your bandwidth
stand up to the overhead of DNS lookup, SMTP handshaking and message
transmission of a few million such messages per hour? It takes the spammer
a few minutes to hand off, but your mail server will be hostage until it's
finished processing all those addresses.

> mail server to send mail across the internet.

Email was never intended to be a reliable, immediate transport. How many

> temporary stop-gap with serious unintended consequences.

Wrong. It effectively eliminates one problem. The fact that there are
others doesn't mean we should re-open this one. We don't stop vaccinating
for measles because people still get sick from other sources, like colds.

> > I'd say my personal mail server typically rejects only three or four
> > relay attempts per day.
> Then it's definitely time to open that sucker up. 

You haven't been paying attention, have you? I didn't say three to four
relays, I said attempts. In my experience, if even one of those attempts
succeeded my available bandwidth would vanish and my mail server would
be rendered useless. And I'd be spending the next week cleaning up after
it. I'd say that's a good reason to leave it alone.

For you, it's all about making life tough for other people and staking a

My telephone doesn't use a robust protocol with diverse network paths and
multiple layers of packet and datagram retransmission (OK, a couple, but
not as many as TCP/IP across the internet).

Why can't we have something BETTER than what we had before?  I know the
telephone system is broke-ass... that's one reason why I like the internet
better.

I don't want something as good as the phone system.  I want something
better.  That's why we bother with this so-called progress in the first
place.

> > Closing relays wasn't the answer in the first place.  It was a kind of
> > temporary stop-gap with serious unintended consequences.
>
> Wrong. It effectively eliminates one problem.

That one "problem" isn't spam, though... it's a product of your greed and
selfishness.

To me, your whole idea of "theft of services" is a problem.

> The fact that there are others doesn't mean we should re-open this one.
> We don't stop vaccinating for measles because people still get sick from
> other sources, like colds.

We don't vaccinate for measles and tell people that it's going to cut down
on colds.

The folks that are out there yanking network connections from those who
would allow their mail relays to be used freely are not doing so to
protect those people from "theft of services".  They're doing it to "fight
spam".

Tell me, why would you encourage people to close their relays?

> > > I'd say my personal mail server typically rejects only three or four
> > > relay attempts per day.
> > Then it's definitely time to open that sucker up.
>

> relays, I said attempts. In my experience, if even one of those attempts
> succeeded my available bandwidth would vanish and my mail server would
> be rendered useless.

How narrow is your bandwidth?  I can understand limiting the use of
services on extremely small connections with mission-critical services
behind them.  Is that your situation?  And if that's really your concern,
why do you care if other people open THEIR relays?

> And I'd be spending the next week cleaning up after it.

If the server did it's job, what would you have to clean up?

> I'd say that's a good reason to leave it alone.

It might be a good reason for YOU to leave YOUR server alone, but your
whole argument revolves around a selfish idea of withholding services for
your own potential personal use.  It has nothing to do with other people
openning their relays nor does it include any argument against a general
notion that there should be as many open relays as possible on the
network.

I know I'm beating this dead horse.

  In light of this week's InnoTech show at the Convention Center, and that
too many clever and talented denizens of our group here are
under-/un-employed, I thought it worth while to pass on this message from

  Pooling talents to produce products that the blind could use to get
readable materials would be an effort with a high degree of satisfaction
even if it produces little or no income. Perhaps output to a voice
synthesizer would also be possible so printed material could be transformed
into braille or speech.

  My mother depends on the taped books she borrows from the library at the
New York Lighthouse for the Blind. Having access to FOSS software on
commodity hardware would allow many more publications to be made available
to those who can no longer see.

I was just listening to a BBC Radio 4 broadcast about the trouble the blind
in Britain have in locating books of any real quality to read. I wondered
why they weren't simply using scanners, OCR, and braille displays and/or
speech synthesizers along with printed books. It turn out that the basic
software sold to the blind is very expensive. This is $1000
(http://www.freedomscientific.com/fs_news/nr_OB7S.asp), not including a
speech sythesizer. (It's thousands more for a braille display).

It seems to me that someone could string something together using gocr, or
similar, to give the blind affordable software and hence better access. I
don't know if anyone is working on such a thing, but if so, you might want to
contact the BBC broadcasters at intouch at bbc.co.uk. The website is
http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/factual/intouch.shtml.

On Fri, 2004-02-27 at 20:13, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Fri, 27 Feb 2004, Evan Heidtmann wrote:
>            -- DementDJ at ccip.perkin-elmer.com (DementDJ)
> 
> Of course, it's not meant to sound like Dr. Seuss.. it doesn't follow his
> style at all.

While it is not Cat and the Hat, and I do not know "Turkey in the
Straw," it is a pretty close match to "I have a Wocket in my Pocket." 
Perhaps Dr. Seuss copied Turkey...  it is an odd book for Dr. Seuss. 
Remember Seuss did not have one cadence, but several.  Having read over
20-30 different Seuss books (I did not know he wrote that many) I can
attest that he has more flow to his words, once you get it, than most
authors.  When you read the same book 40-50 times, you notice these
things.  "What was I Scare of" and "Too Many Daves" clearly do not flow
like Cat and the Hat (Scared is fairly close to Ziegler's as well).

Oddly I am merely cleaning my emails at the moment, *and* I just read
Wocket to my daughter last night.  I can tell you it is the same
cadence.

I find it more annoying that due to mainstream press things become -like
or "derivative of" too easily.  In older times we called them styles. 
Yes a unique author may have started it, but others followed and it
occasionally improved the art.

Another example is Monty Python.  When doing Improv, if you dared do a
British accent, people would later refer to a that "Monty Python
Sketch," as though there was never any other absurdist comedians in
England.  While this is somewhat of an honor to Monty Python, it also
stifles a possible flow of art.

This impact OSS as well.  While there are plenty of half-ass projects
that do the same thing, people often say "you do not need to redo that,
Y already works."  Well, I think the broad spectrum of OSS improves
gradually, even if the project in question sucks rocks.


>

> 
> This is as annoying as every mildly humorous song on OpenNap being
> labelled as "Weird Al".

I agree about this.  Some of the songs I tried labeled as Wierd Al were
an isult to both the original artist, and Weird Al.

From john at meissen.org  Wed Mar 31 11:12:02 2004
From: john at meissen.org (John Meissen)
Date: Wed Mar 31 11:12:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] How dangerous is handling my own mail?
In-Reply-To: (Your message of Wed, 31 Mar 2004 06:42:54 PST.)
             <20040331144254.32551.85846.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> 
Message-ID: <20040331191142.2F47073FFA@john.meissen.org>

This thread has gone on too long, and strayed too far. It really belongs
in 'talk'. This is my final response.

Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> said:
> No, it proves that you can do whatever it is you have done and live. 

<sigh> No, you really know nothing about logic. It only proves that
I can do whatever I've done and that I've lived so far. It says nothing
about the future.

I said:
> > No, this was back when most of the mail systems were configured as
> > open relays.

Then Jeme A Brelin said:
> How long ago?  I didn't see anything like massively injected relayed
> mail until well after the closed relay movement started.  After all,
> if you've got pipe enough to inject millions of messages, you got pipe
> enough to run your own server or just bounce through a few hundred
> others.  You're just shooting yourself in the foot trying to pump it
> all through one that probably can't take the load. 

Around 1998. And you're still not grokking. If I'm a spammer who's
relaying through someone else, I'm not injecting a million messages - 
I'm injecting a single message with a million addresses. This expands
to a million messages on the server that has to do final delivery, i.e.,
the relay server. That's one of the major reasons they do it - it
offloads the processing onto some else's system. 

> If we provide an easy way for them to send their mail, they won't be
> looking for malicious ways to do it (e.g., planting trojans) and we
> can focus on eliminating the real problem -- unwanted email in
> people's inboxes. 

The easiest way for them to do it is to pay for and use their own
servers and connections. What's wrong with that? Now that we're
forcing them to do that instead of relaying, we ARE concentrating on
the unwanted email problem. That's why they use infected systems,
target secondary MX hosts and play word games to bypass heuristic tests
in spam filters.

> So you don't filter spam coming into your system?

I never said that. I do three levels of spam blocking/filtering. I have
certain default tests configured in sendmail along with my own blacklist,
I use Spasm (www.nspasm.org) as a milter with aggressive settings, and
I use spamassassin.

> Theft of services?  We're talking about a few megabytes a day per
> server tops. 

This whole discussion is pointless because you don't pay attention. First
of all, if we assume 2K per message and a million messages that's more
like 2GB. Per relayed spam. Plus it kills your mail server. Mail is
generally queued in FIFO order. Your server won't process anything else
until it's dealt with those million SMTP handshakes. Hopefully your
server is configured to limit the number of simultaneous processes, or
your system would trip over itself and die. With DNS lookups, ident
processing, connection filtering on the other end, etc., etc., it takes
finite time to process each message. Then there's the bounces, the flames,
etc. I don't know about you, but I have better things to do with my time.

> For you, it's all about making life tough for other people and staking a
> claim that "what's mine is mine!"

Right. That's why I pay for this out of my own pocket, and provide free
and unfettered access to my friends, all my relatives and my neighbors.
It's about being responsible.

> So you're implying that billions of spam messages go across the
> internet very hour?  I think you need to reassess the scale, there.

You think so? In Taiwan they estimate that 2/3 of all email is spam.
I've heard estimates of US spam being 50% or more of all email messages.
One estimate was that spam accounted for over 1/3 of all Internet traffic
(TCP/IP packets, not email messages).

> That one "problem" isn't spam, though... it's a product of your greed and
> selfishness.

My greed and selfishness. I see. Preventing someone from hijacking my system
for their own profit is an indication of MY greed.

Years ago I operated a UUCP node. I provided feeds to anyone who wanted
one. I relayed whatever came through. I do what I can now, within limits.
Communal resources are great, until someone starts abusing them. Then
those few ruin it for everyone else.

> We don't vaccinate for measles and tell people that it's going to cut down
> on colds.

OK, fine. We vaccinate for flu. But because people can get the flu from
other strains we don't throw away the vaccines we do have. Sheesh.

> It might be a good reason for YOU to leave YOUR server alone, but your
> whole argument revolves around a selfish idea of withholding services for
> your own potential personal use.

You know, you seem to have this notion that what I pay for and maintain I
should freely share with you and anyone else who wants to use it. So tell
me, do you have a car? Why don't you leave the keys in it in case someone
else has car problems and needs to use it to make a quick run to the store?
I share pretty much everything. But because of abuse, people have to ask
first.

I have to wonder about your real motivation for encouraging open relays.
Given that anyone with an Internet connection has access to a server that's
more reliable than their physical connection there just isn't any valid
justification for having open relays.

john-

Subject: [PLUG] Setting postifx to bounce on bad from->to pairs

So, I've been waiting for evolution to solve my stupidity problem of
sending mail to lists with the wrong FROM address.

It does not look like it is going to happen soon.

So I was planning on modifying Postfix to do it for me.

Has anyone does this already?  It seems I need a map (transport?) that
rejects ("6.6.6. You are a moron zot") relay access when it seems
something like this:

FROM				TO
zot at domain1.com 		@domain2.com
!zot_list at list.domain1.com	plug at lists.pdxlinux.com
zot at domain2.com			@domain1.com

Or something like this.

The first line might be bad for a lot of folks, but I have recipients
that I need to come from the right address that I can define pretty
easily.

The second one is a common issue.  I might even prefer something that
rewrites the FROM line to the appropriate one like this:

FROM_Orig		TO			FROM
zot at domain1.com		plug at lists.pdxlinux.com	zot_lists at list.domain1.com

But that could be difficult.

Any pages, hints, ideas?

Thanks!

From jeme at brelin.net  Wed Mar 31 12:56:02 2004

In-Reply-To: <20040331191142.2F47073FFA@john.meissen.org>

On Wed, 31 Mar 2004, John Meissen wrote:
> Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> said:
> > No, it proves that you can do whatever it is you have done and live.
>
> <sigh> No, you really know nothing about logic. It only proves that I
> can do whatever I've done and that I've lived so far. It says nothing
> about the future.

If I know nothing about logic, then you can't read.

I didn't WRITE anything about the future.  I simply stated that it is
POSSIBLE for a particular situation to arise.

> Around 1998. And you're still not grokking. If I'm a spammer who's
> relaying through someone else, I'm not injecting a million messages -
> I'm injecting a single message with a million addresses. This expands to
> a million messages on the server that has to do final delivery, i.e.,
> the relay server.

So refuse messages with long recipient lists.

The problem with totally closing relays is that it's too drastic a
measure.  There are other ways to achieve the goals you desire to achieve.

And it turns out it has nothing to do with blocking spam.

> > If we provide an easy way for them to send their mail, they won't be
> > looking for malicious ways to do it (e.g., planting trojans) and we
> > can focus on eliminating the real problem -- unwanted email in
> > people's inboxes.
>
> The easiest way for them to do it is to pay for and use their own
> servers and connections.

No, that isn't the easiest way because it results in blackhole lists and
the like.  It's a losing strategy.  Since they are exploitative profiteers
(i.e., capitalists), they will find another way to make their profits at
the expense of others.

> What's wrong with that?

It doesn't work.

> Now that we're forcing them to do that instead of relaying, we ARE
> concentrating on the unwanted email problem.

They are NOT forced to use their own servers, man!  They are using trojans
and bots.

> That's why they use infected systems, target secondary MX hosts and play
> word games to bypass heuristic tests in spam filters.

But they're not using "their own servers and connections" as you assert
above.

> > Theft of services?  We're talking about a few megabytes a day per
> > server tops.
>
> This whole discussion is pointless because you don't pay attention.

Ad-hominem will get you nowhere, sir.  Stick to the issues and there might
actually be progress.

> First of all, if we assume 2K per message and a million messages that's
> more like 2GB. Per relayed spam.

It's trivial to deny large recipient lists with just about any MTA in
modern use.

> Plus it kills your mail server.

PLUS?  You mean THEN, right?  This is a consequence, not a separate
action.

> Your server won't process anything else until it's dealt with those
> million SMTP handshakes.

Again, blocking long recipient lists would solve this without closing the
whole relay.

> Hopefully your server is configured to limit the number of simultaneous
> processes, or your system would trip over itself and die.

I think it might be a couple dozen.  I've never had a system crash under
load... even in large production environments.  I've had pipes saturated
and systems become I/O bound, but those issues eventually resolve
themselves even if you don't intervene.

> With DNS lookups, ident processing, connection filtering on the other
> end, etc., etc., it takes finite time to process each message.

Again, limit the number.

> Then there's the bounces, the flames, etc. I don't know about you, but I
> have better things to do with my time.

Why are you even bothering with the bounces?

The flames are a cultural problem caused by the closed-relay community
that wants to blame the mail server operator for the content that passes
through it.  That can change easily.

> > For you, it's all about making life tough for other people and staking
> > a claim that "what's mine is mine!"
>
> Right. That's why I pay for this out of my own pocket, and provide free
> and unfettered access to my friends, all my relatives and my neighbors.

You have a very narrow view of "friends, all my relatives and my
neighbors".  Any one of those categories could emcompass the entire
planet... especially when we're already narrowed down to human beings on
the internet.

> It's about being responsible.

If you really were concerned with the things you wrote about in this
message alone, you would simply limit the number of recipients a message
may carry or require authentication at certain times of day or process
authenticated mail at a higher priority.  But no, you choose the
all-denying policy that is most destructive to the social fabric -- most
selfish, most limiting to others and most ruthlessly authoritarian.

> > So you're implying that billions of spam messages go across the
> > internet very hour?  I think you need to reassess the scale, there.
>
> You think so? In Taiwan they estimate that 2/3 of all email is spam.
> I've heard estimates of US spam being 50% or more of all email messages.
> One estimate was that spam accounted for over 1/3 of all Internet
> traffic (TCP/IP packets, not email messages).

I've heard all kinds of estimates, too.  But two things lack in your
comments:  citations for quoted numerical data and real numbers instead of
ratios.

It may well be that 1/3 of all internet traffic is spam, but that doesn't
show that there are billions of spam messages sent every hour.  You'd have
to know how much of the traffic is email, generally, and then you could
guess based on the number of packets required per email message on average
and kind of come up with a number from there, but it would be prone to
some error.  If you could show somehow that spam was half of all email
messages transitting an internet backbone (and intranet email just can't
count here), then you'd have to further show that there were 4 billion
total messages each hour.

Billions are really big.

> > That one "problem" isn't spam, though... it's a product of your greed
> > and selfishness.
>
> My greed and selfishness. I see. Preventing someone from hijacking my
> system for their own profit is an indication of MY greed.

It's so deeply ingrained in your thought that you can't even express it
without using derogatory terms for shared use.

You're not JUST prevent spammers from using your systems.  If you only
wanted that, you could implement any of the several schemes I've
suggested.  No, you're preventing EVERYONE ELSE from using your services.

> Years ago I operated a UUCP node. I provided feeds to anyone who wanted
> one. I relayed whatever came through.

Well, you once had the right idea.

> I do what I can now, within limits.

> Communal resources are great, until someone starts abusing them. Then
> those few ruin it for everyone else.

It's only RUINED if you go to negative extremes to prevent the perceived
abuse.

I haven't even HINTED at the POSITIVE responses one could have to systems
being rendered unusable due to congestion:  larger pipes, better hardware,
faster resolvers, etc.

There are plenty of people who would suggest that, if a person cannot give
enough to satisfy others, that person is just not giving enough.  I can
think of one guy in particular... but they nailed him to a tree when he
suggested it.

> > We don't vaccinate for measles and tell people that it's going to cut
> > down on colds.
>
> OK, fine. We vaccinate for flu. But because people can get the flu from
> other strains we don't throw away the vaccines we do have. Sheesh.

Uh... no.  The folks at spamcop.net who go around coercing ISPs into
yanking other people's internet connections because of open relays are NOT
doing it to protect those poor souls from "theft of service".  They're
claiming it stops spam.

So will you join me condemning all people who want to close other people's
relays under the guise of spam prevention?

> > It might be a good reason for YOU to leave YOUR server alone, but your
> > whole argument revolves around a selfish idea of withholding services
> > for your own potential personal use.
>
> You know, you seem to have this notion that what I pay for and maintain
> I should freely share with you and anyone else who wants to use it.

Honestly, you're kind of dodging the issue here.  I'll take up your
comment in a moment, but I have to restate this:  You make arguments for
closing your OWN mail server, but why encourage others to do the same?
What is YOUR motivation THERE?

Personally, I think it's a subconscious desire to squelch sharing and
public-mindedness because it is a threat to the system that allows you to
sit in a superior position to other people and wield power over them.  But
maybe you have a different understanding.

> So tell me, do you have a car?

No, I'm not elderly or otherwise infirm.

> Why don't you leave the keys in it in case someone else has car problems
> and needs to use it to make a quick run to the store?

I lock my bicycle when it's not at home.  Mostly, that's because there is
no assurance that I will ever gain future access if my current access is
lost.  It's kind of a sick little game based on fear and deprivation that
allows those with control of massive resources to keep folks like me in
permanent desperation.

Internet pipes aren't like that AT ALL, though.  You sit atop the valve
and can reclaim it for your own needs whenever you like.  There's really
no reason NOT to allow public use so long as you can assure the use when
you need it.  You can do this with preferential routing and stuff.

> I share pretty much everything. But because of abuse, people have to ask
> first.

There's no reason for that with your mail server.  Your only real argument
here is that mail with large recipient lists bogs down your system.  So
limit recipient lists and give authenticated users higher priority.

Of course, it's not that easy because the self-appointed cops have control
right now and they will get your connection yanked or add you to a
blackhole list if you do anything as helpful as that.

> I have to wonder about your real motivation for encouraging open relays.

My real motivation is a subversion of conventional ideas of authority,
property, and control.

> Given that anyone with an Internet connection has access to a server
> that's more reliable than their physical connection there just isn't any
> valid justification for having open relays.

I don't get your "given" at all.  If your "physical connection" is
wireless, then your access is redundant all over town.  You just have to
go a few blocks further down.

And, quite frankly, you're the one proposing the restriction, so you're
going to have to do better than "no reason to not restrict" as a
justification.

I'm always going to argue for the least destructive policy.

Order Allow,Deny

J.

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

Dave,

Thanks much for the post.

Here is the full explanation of the project, as I originally promised.

Charles Stewart

****************************************

Much Thanks to Mr David Mandel for his fine post in response to my verbal/
phone request for PHP/MysSQL Programmer Assistance.
And what is really novel, is that I got behind on my promise to Dave for an
out-line of the work that needs to  be done, and he heroically made a very
effective post even with-out my outline.
Those are rare & precious standards. Thanks again Dave.

And for broader context, we have our own "Dedicated Server", so we have root
access to work on this project.  Also: I live in Sandy Oregon, just East of
Gresham; & so that is why I am focusing on the Portland/Linux-Group.
Further, I am 49 years old, the main organizer of this project, & I am a
dedicated open-source supporter, and linux supporter.  Also, I have been
studying such matters as constitutional-law & social-justice for well over
20
years.  I am dedicated to bringing power to responsibly self-govern to the
common American People.
  One of the main focuses of our much broader work here, is to defend the
open-source community from monolithic big-brother schemes from such
centralized-authority advocates as Microsoft & Mr Ashcrofts so-called
"Department of Justice".
But these caviets being said, here is the basic outline of the work I/we
need
help on. The basic web site is at:
http://vote.inetgov.net/

Potential programmers can go ahead & register to vote there. As can be seen
here-in, this is an effort at constructing cutting-edge on-line
direct-democratic electoral/voting process.  This is the focus here, because
the US Constitution commands that the common American People are the Supreme
Authority from which All Government Officers ultimately derive all of their
governing authority.
So, the task at hand, is simply to organize the common people to voice their
constitutionally-lawful demands for accountable/open government, especially
in such critically important areas as our "Open-Source Community" & the
survivability of Linux and the Internet in general.

To be more specific, we have constructed a "deep-hierarchy", under which the
whole planet can theoretically be self-governed.  It is my views that
"Strong
Local Government" (free from interference from unwanted meddling from
outside
larger jurisdictions), is both Constitutionally Required & a practical
Necessity.
For each propositional-issue (in our eventually very large & constantly
expanding database), there are 3 categories, which are: "Level of Support"
for each proposition/candidate, "Importance" of the proposition to that
voter, & "Efficiency" (& neutrality) of the wording of the proposition.
All of these elements are designed to be tabulated thru the MySQL Database,
&
displayed in a spread-sheet format; so that each individual can be fully
empowered to communicate his detailed voter preferences to the other
honorable members of his local & larger self-governing jurisdictional
communities.
Ongoing "Votes of Confidence" & "Instantaneous Recall" of elected officials
&
of governmental policies, is an essential sub-division of of the larger
"Level of Support" aspect of this project.  "Weighted Voting", aka:
"Preferential Voting" plays into this strongly.  We are using a scale of 0 -
99  to tabulate our "weighted votes".

That is a quick outline. I can specify more later. I think Ive got a more
detailed outline document some-where, or verbally I can narrow the focus.
It helps much to be on the phone and looking at the web page at the same
time. I can allow programmers who are working with us to have full access to
the domain , & eventually even to our dedicated server.

I have had 2 Oregon area programmers work on this project, for good pay, for

close to two years.  The first one abandoned it with-out honorable concern
for completing it.  He took the money and ran.
The second one was out of contact for an extended time, & he has spent a
very
long time getting things accomplished.  I had become worried that he had
abandoned it. He since has reassured me of his dedication to finishing the
project, & is actively making progress on it. And he seems to have good
explanations for his delays, personal problems & such which happen to us
all.
But it seems clear to me, that he needs some help in completing the project.
This project should have been completed long ago. I know that if a good
competent programmer or 2 or more were working on it steady, that things
would be up & running in a very quick time.  My present programmer says
things are 98 % ready to run. We seem to just need a few minor adjustments.
But I am not a programmer, yet; so I don't know for sure.
And I am sure that there will be "fine tuning" necessary, so that work for
the future could expand dramatically. We expect fully that this project will
be so popular that donations will come in from many local self-governing
communities.  Nothing like this presently exists, & the lost & confused
populace desperately needs forums like this to work-out their own
self-governing solutions.
When donations begin coming in, we will compensate our programmers
generously.  And we can pay a bit for those who can help at present.  We can
easily set-up & host domains as a barter/exchange for any programmers who
volunteer to work with us.
We are in the process of setting up mirror-image web-pages under our
dedicated server, from which individual programmers who are helping out here
can exercise full control.  And one way or the other, we will allow such
root
access as is needed.
I can probably arrange 3 -way phone conferences with our present programmer;
in Lincoln-City, Oregon; & who is intimately familiar with the code.  I
believe he will actively work with us, & that he will be glad to share the
duties of getting everything programmed to work together in an efficient
manner.

I look forward to working with any volunteers on this project.  Folks
dedicated to supporting Linux & Open-Source are preferred.  That may sound
screwy, but Ive seen it play out (in tangible results) too often to ignore.
Advanced programmers who can provide insight to efficiency improvements will
be compensated fairly & promptly; & all who work with us will receive
generous compensation when the donations begin to flow.
Of course; many have heard similar promises before, & are naturally
skeptical.  Thats ok.  But look a the basic work.  Does this look like the
work of an opportunistic scamm-artist?  "By their works ye will know them",
Bible quote.  Ive paid the 2 programmers who worked on it so far,
approximately one thousand dollars, total. I will pay what-ever is necessary
to get this work finished & effeciently functional. And deeply respectful
friendships will be established with those can afford to temporarily fore-go
immediate compensation in order to get it efficiently running soon.

Sincerely,

On Wed, 2004-03-31 at 15:14, Prutzer wrote:

> I need to put together a really good tool kit.

I couldn't live without mine. :-)

> You know, punch down tool, electric screwdriver,stripper, crimper,etc.
> Anyone know a good set anywhere and if not a set a good place to put
> together a good kit?

I haven't found one that includes a power screwdriver... but my parents
bought me two kits over the last few years.  One is pretty big the other
pretty small.  The big one is a Compaq kit, FWIW.  It included things
like a soldering iron.

> also, what do you consider need tools in a good tool kit?

A nice phillips head non-magnetic non-powered screwdriver with a
medium-small grip. 
I use a Black&Decker power screwdriver, too.  
A magnetic screwdriver is nice, too, to grab screws you drop.  
Cable ties are good to have.
A screwdriver socket set with all the heads you might possibly need
CAT5 cable crimping kit
something to grab those damned jumpers (small pliers, I don't have any)
a daily pill holder to hold screws when you're taking things apart
A wire stripper
Two BBC CDs - one with INSERT on it, the other with AdAware and AVG

I'm sure there's other stuff in there, I just can't think of it now. 
:-)

Rob

From drl at drloree.com  Wed Mar 31 17:27:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Wed Mar 31 17:27:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] IT tools
In-Reply-To: <406b4ff4.1805287@mail.aracnet.com>
References: <406b4ff4.1805287@mail.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <1080782785.754.37.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Wed, 2004-03-31 at 15:14, Prutzer wrote:
> Hi all,
> I need to put together a really good tool kit.
> You know, punch down tool, electric screwdriver,stripper, crimper,etc.
> Anyone know a good set anywhere and if not a set a good place to put
> together a good kit?
> 
> also, what do you consider need tools in a good tool kit?

I like having a ratcheting screw driver instead of a power screw driver,
it never runs out of power.  Even better, if it has removable tips, you
should be able to get a 1/4 inch drive and a small socket set and
extensions to go with it.  Small bent-tip needle nose pliers are also a
must.  I have ndiags (a Norton utility) on a bootable floppy along with
serial and parallel loopback devices, but haven't really used them in a
while.

Other things that I can think of,

-tube of heatsink compound
-wire ties (use sparingly)
-electrical tape
-cat-5 cable (just get a box of the good stuff)
-cat-5 cable ends
-cat-5 cable end crimper
-rubbing alcohol
-Q-tips
-air tank, or compressor, or both (much cheaper than canned air)
-air nozzle
-4-port hub (as a cheap cable tester)
-exacto knife, or other very sharp implement
-rescue disk(s)

Just to give you ideas, I'm sure there is more.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Wed Mar 31 22:56:02 2004
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Wed Mar 31 22:56:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] On hosing the kernel
Message-ID: <20040401065526.3656.qmail@web9602.mail.yahoo.com>

I seem to have a slight problem. I have a Logitech
Quickcam 3000 which works under Linux, but requires a
compressor module for maximum performance. The source
code for this module (pwcx.o) is not available; you
just have to download it for the right combination of
kernel version and compiler.

The closest match I could get with my kernel version
(2.4.21) was one for 2.4.23. Insmod complained about
it. If it won't fit, use a bigger hammer:

insmod -f pwcx.o

And the performance of the Webcam was good. While I
was browsing the Web, however, my system locked up,
and required a hard reboot. Then, when I rebooted the
kernel was unable to load any modules.

(I tried making another kernel, but apparently the
damage is too extensive to be repaired in this way.
Probably transferring the data from the installation
is the best I can do.

Linux has been making impressive strides toward the
desktop. But to secure good performance from one of
the most popular Web cams, it takes a diligent search
for a module and a kernel compilation. With Windows,
it's a five-minute download.)

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/
